abstract: Samuel Smith et al. vs. Benjamin F. Butler. -- The motion to remove this cause to the United States Circuit Court for trial was argued yesterday morning. The defendant claimed that under the act of Congress of 1797 the action could be removed on application in any case between a citizen of one State and a citizen of another, where the amount involved was over five hundred dollars. The plaintiff maintained that where both parties were nonresidents of the State in whose courts the action was brought, it could not be removed to the United States Court. The decision was reserved.
lead_paragraph: Samuel Smith et al. vs. Benjamin F. Butler. -- The motion to remove this cause to the United States Circuit Court for trial was argued yesterday morning. abstract: Richmond papers of Monday, the 28th, still maintain a forced silence regarding the news from Georgia. They manage to assert, however, that "the news is encouraging," though to which side they omit to say. The Examiner, of the 26th, very frankly admits that if SHERMAN.....
lead_paragraph: Richmond papers of Monday, the 28th, still maintain a forced silence regarding the news from Georgia. They manage to assert, however, that "the news is encouraging," though to which side they omit to say. The Examiner, of the 26th, very frankly admits that if SHERMAN succeeds in reaching the coast, communication between Richmond and the southwest will be entirely severed, and with still greater Frankness, says when JEFF. DAVIS ordered HOOD's last movement, he sent that army from where it could confront the enemy, and "stuck it in the mud between Tuscumbia and Florence." The Savannah Republican of the 24th contains contradictory statements as to SHERMAN's movements, particularly as to crossing the Oconee River. It says that the column operating on the Georgia road, kept the western side and struck off in the direction of Macon, as though contemplating a junction with the forces in that vicinity. It is stated that a strong force of cavalry is following SHERMAN. Some of the recently exchanged prisoners have reached Washington. They say that when they arrived at Savannah from Millen, they were kindly treated and furnished with the best food which could be procured, and that the people intimated that there were forces under BEAUREGARD and JOHNSTON at Macon and Augusta, to oppose SHERMAN; but they did not believe he would encounter them, or that the military authorities would in time decide where to concentrate the forces they had. At Savannah there were only 1,500 men, who would make but a feeble resistance.

abstract: At the opening of the Court this morning Judge Nelson read his decision in the case of Tilghman vs. Mitchell. This was an action brought by the complainant to restrain the defendant from infringing a patent granted to him for separating fatty substances into fatty acids and glycerine, by mixing them with water and subjecting them to heat under pressure. The Judge held that the defendant had infringed the plaintiff's patent, and ordered a decree for an injunction, and a reference to ascertain damages.

abstract: Parma, N Y--Ploss, Philip, by Lunatic Son
snippet: Parma, N Y--Ploss, Philip, by Lunatic Son
lead_paragraph: SHOCKING MURDER -- A FATHER SLAIN BY HIS SON. -- A shocking case of parricide occurred last night in the town of Parma in this county, PHILIP PLOSS, an elderly farmer and respectable citizen, was killed by his son ALBERT, a young man of 22, who is a mute, and supposed to be deranged. The boy left home and came to the city a few days since. On Saturday his father came here, found him at a relative's and took him home. The young man was sulky and evidently in a bad frame of mind. Last night, after the family had retired, Mr. PLOSS heard his son going up and down stairs and suspecting that something was wrong, he rose from his bed and while in the act of lighting a candle, the son stabbed him in the chest and fled from the house. The weapon used was a common case knife ground to a point, and the wound inflicted was very severe.

abstract: Silliman, Prof, Funeral
lead_paragraph: The funeral services of this distinguished and good man took place at New-Haven on Monday last. A private service, conducted by Prof. FISHER, of Yale College, was held at the residence of the deceased on Hillhouse-avenue, at twelve o'clock, attended by his family and immediate connections. The services were of a private character, and consisted of singing by the Beethoven Society of Yale College of "China," to the hymn "Why should we mourn departed friend" -- and a most tender and appropriate prayer by Prof. FISHER. The friends were then allowed to look for the last time upon the remains of him who in life they had loved and respected. After which the coffin was closed, and removed to the Center Church, accompanied by the Senior Class of the College, where the corpse was visible to the public until 2 1/2 o'clock, when the public funeral took place. Upon the coffin was a laurel wreath and a cross formed of white flowers -- fit emblems of the purity of the life of the deceased. The services were opened by Prof. FITCH, who read the 520th hymn, commencing, "Forever with the Lord. so Jesus let it be." Prof. CLARK, Pastor of Yale. then read appropriate portions of Scripture, after which President WOOLSEY, of Yale, delivered the eulogy. He eloquently described the many virtues of the noble departed, and the valuable services he had rendered to Yale and to the world, and read many extracts from the private diary of the dead, evidences of the high and noble motives which actuated every action of his life. Rev. Dr. BACON then offered prayer, after which the services were concluded by singing the 481st hymn. The singing of the college choir, under the direction of Prof. GUSTAVE STOECKEL, was excellent throughout, and highly creditable to them.

abstract: Pilot Commissioners vs Spofford, >amp;c; Unlicensed Pilot
snippet: Pilot Commissioners vs Spofford, >amp;c; Unlicensed Pilot
lead_paragraph: The Board of Commissioners of Pilots vs. Paul Spofford and Edward L. Howard, survivors of Thomas Tileston. -- This was an action to recover a penalty of $100 from the defendants for employing an unlicensed pilot. It appeared that the defendants, Spofford, Tileston & Co. employed one Maginn to take their vessel out of the harbor, and on the trial it was admitted that the licence of Maginn as a pilot expired on the 6th of September, 1860, and has never been renewed, and that he held no license from the State of New-Jersey. A law of this State imposes a penalty $100 for each offence where a party shall employ an unlicensed pilot, but an Act of Congress exempts vessels propelled wholly or in part by steam, and allows them to have pilots of their own. Under this act Maginn held a license. The defendants claim that while their vessel was on her way out, and under the charge of a pilot, she was not under sail, but was moved by a tug fastened alongside, and was, therefore, propelled by steam, and both the vessel and tug were under the control of the one pilot. The decision upon the questions of law was reserved.

abstract: Richmond Rebels Silent About
lead_paragraph: The Richmond rebels are now practicing the austere virtue of silence in reference to the movements of Gen. SHERMAN. They do this for our sake. They are anxious we should not share with them the "good news" they claim to be in possession of. They are anxious we should not find out the disasters that have overtaken SHERMAN. What damage it would do the Confederate cause to inform us of our ill fortunes, they do not say. Perhaps they do not wish to let the disastrous news out in dribblets; but may mean to hold the whole back until they can overwhelm and crush us by the revelation of some such awful fate as they have predicted for SHERMAN, in the whole of his army being turned over as prisoners to the keeping of "Hog WINDER." It is true, the Examiner has already considerately informed us that "several dispatches concur in the declaration that SHERMAN's army is ruined;" but then, SHERMAN's army, as well as our other armies, are so accustomed to being ruined by and in rebel columns, that it could not be expected we would be either greatly depressed or greatly benefited by another repetition of a circumstance of such trifling account -- especially when neither the time, the place, nor any of the details of ruin are given. It might, indeed, have produced a slight effect had the Examiner stopped short in its narration of news with the solitary sentence we have quoted. Had it, say under the dark caption of "Ruin," simply and baldly proclaimed in startling type, "SHERMAN's army is ruined," there would have been a gloomy mystery and a mysterious gloom; there would have been a horror and a hopelessness surrounding the grim sentence, that, it must be supposed, would have had an influence upon the minds of, at least, Wall-street bears. But even this is thoughtlessly prevented by the want of logic and consistency in the Richmond rebel paper; for, in a paragraph following the paragraph of ruin, there is a timidly and dubiously expressed rebel hope, which gets into print, that "SHERMAN will be brought to grief ere he reaches the sea-coast."
headline: {'main': 'The Rebels on Sherman.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Rebels on Sherman.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: has Cooperated for the Union; Not Appointed Engineer of Morris >amp; Essex Railroad
snippet: has Cooperated for the Union; Not Appointed Engineer of Morris >amp; Essex Railroad
lead_paragraph: About 5 o'clock yesterday morning flames were discovered issuing from the centre of the large lumber-yard of Messrs. OGDEN & Co., situated on Hubert-street, and extending through from Washington to West street. The yard was closely stored with mahogany and other valuable lumber and owing to its highly combustible state, the flames spread rapidly. Notwithstanding the prompt and vigorous efforts of the firemen and police to stay them. In a short time lumber and other property, valued at $80,000, was destroyed. The fire thence extended to the buildings Nos. 386, 388, 392, and 396 Washington-street, which were destroyed. Quite a number of families have thereby been rendered houseless. The aggregate loss will exceed $100,000. Messrs. OGDEN & Co. are insured for $69,000 in various city companies, There is no doubt but that the fire was the work of incendiaries. Fire Marshal BAKER and the Police of the Fifth Precinct are engaged in making an investigation.

abstract: -- It will be seen by advertisement that, under the auspices of the Historical Society, a series of three lectures is to be given upon the old, but always fresh and entertaining topic of investigation and thought, Egypt. The first of the series will be by Professor DRAPER, and will be delivered to-night. At the third or concluding lecture, a fortnight from this evening, the ancient mummy recently presented to the society, will be unrolled. We have no doubt that this circumstance alone will secure a brilliant audience to the lectures.

abstract: on Duty of our Young Men
snippet: on Duty of our Young Men
lead_paragraph: If I am to accept the regrets, very kindly expressed in several notes sent me, on a "Last Word on a Lasting Peace," as a true interpretation of the ephemeral articles of which this was one, and which the TIMES indulgently found room for in its crowded columns, like Mons. JOURDAIN in the Bourgeois Gentilhomme, who found out, to his surprise, that he had been speaking prose always, I have, it would seem, very unwittingly been for some time talking, or rather writing politics. Well, if I must accept this decision, let me say, in my justification, that it was not party politics that led me to write; nor did I write with a party or personal object. The great theme that, however ardent my desire, I feel I but feebly essayed to rise to, was my country's honor and integrity, which seemed to me on the point of being compromised, if not irreparably injured, by timid and traitorous counsels; in the support of which many true men, from sheer party fealty, had been enmeshed. Timid perhaps myself, to me the danger seemed imminent and the crisis appalling.

abstract: Not the True Issue of the War; Only Issue and True Solution of the War; Unity of the Nation the Only Issue
snippet: Not the True Issue of the War; Only Issue and True Solution of the War; Unity of the Nation the Only Issue
lead_paragraph: The continuance of this war, with all its terrible work, one day beyond an actual necessity, would be the most enormous of crimes. It is of supreme moment, then, to both sides to know just what constitutes this necessity, and just, where it will cease. On these points, Northern opinions and Southern opinions widely differ. But this difference is not so broad as is sometimes represented. A great many figments and a great many non-essentials have been constantly wrapped about the real issue. It cannot be too often stripped of these, North and South, it should be daily seen in its bare pith.
headline: {'main': 'The Only Issue and the Only Solution.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Only Issue and the Only Solution.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Smith, Goldwin, on England and America
snippet: Smith, Goldwin, on England and America
lead_paragraph: -- Prof. GOLDWIN SMITH has an article, admirable in tone and spirit, in the current number of the Atlantic Monthly, on the natural affinities between Great Britain and America. But, in one particular, we think, he has done scarcely justice to one section of the British aristocracy. There is no doubt that the great body of the privileged land class in Engand strongly sympathize with the slaveowners of the South, and sympathize from a regard to their own order. But there is equally little reason to doubt that several of the very foremost men of rank have been cordial well-wishers of the Union and freedom, from the commencement of the rebellion. We need but instance the Duke of ARGYLE, LORD DALHOUSIE, and the late Sir GEORGE CORNWALL LEWIS. Among the great moneyed men of the United Kingdom, too, it is perhaps well not to forget such friendly names as the late Sir WILLIAM BROWN, of Liverpool, Mr. THOMAS BARING, of London, and the famous BAXTERS, of Dundee. Among the Irish aristocracy, The O'DONOGHUE has stood conspicuously forward as an outspoken friend of the Union; and many lesser names will readily occur in the same connection, even to casual readers of current British history.

abstract: Our naval reporter visited the Royal Swedish screw frigate Vanadis yesterday afternoon, which has recently arrived at this port from Sweden via Plymouth, England. The Vanadis is a screw frigate of twenty-two guns and four hundred horse-power. She was built at the naval depot of Sweden, and her en-...
lead_paragraph: Our naval reporter visited the Royal Swedish screw frigate Vanadis yesterday afternoon, which has recently arrived at this port from Sweden via Plymouth, England. The Vanadis is a screw frigate of twenty-two guns and four hundred horse-power. She was built at the naval depot of Sweden, and her engines were constructed at the great private establishment of MOTALA, where nearly all of the engines for Swedish war vessels are built. The Vanadis is ship-rigged and rather light sparred, yet her officers state that she has made under steam alone over twelve knots per hour. She steams nine knots with only two or her four boilers. She is a fine sea boat, notwithstanding she carries a heavy battery for her tonnage.

abstract: Mr. LEACH is negotiating a peace again! That remarkable Member of Congress from North Carolina is always negotiating a peace by himself; and there is no doubt that he presides over a convention of all the States in his dreams by night. He has the indomitable constancy and consistency in devotion to one principle which characterizes the truly great man. Last session he was arranging terms of peace with himself quite contentedly: and having digested and matured them during the recess, here we have him, irrepressible as ever, again making peace.

abstract: In your article of this morning, entitled "Southerners in the City," &c., you touch upon one point which effectually covers all the ground, namely: to require each and every one from the insurgent States to take the oath of allegiance. Now this is just the thing to test them. I happen to know that many are here, among other reasons, simply because they would not take the oath of allegiance at home; and because, as they assert, they could live here, where amid the great multitudes, they would not be noticed. Let Gen. DIX but put this test to each of them, and you will see such a scattering of he and she rebels, blockade-runners, et id omne genus, as will surprise those who were not previously aware of the real state of things. SOUTHERNER.

abstract: The news from Georgia, now the most interesting of all, is exceedingly meagre and untrustworthy. [???] doubt can now be entertained of SHERMAN's design, [???] of his destination. When DAVIS sent, and [???] the only army apparent in the country off his [???]ders, and carried it through the mountains to stick [???] in the mud between Tuscumbia and Florence, SHERMAN determined to make an attempt on the lines of communication between Virginia, the Carolinas, and the rest of the Confederate States. His work in Northern Georgia was done, and for ulterior operations any point on the sea-coast would be a better base than Chattanooga. He risked much in appearance, but perhaps little in reality, by destroying his communications. A marching army can transport ammunition for at least three pitched battles, and for supplies at this season of the year, he might partly rely on the country through which he proposed to pass. If he could take Macon or Augusta by the way, he would accomplish great things; but the destruction of those towns was not his main object. His design was to destroy the railroads as far as he could, which ran from Southern and Western Georgia to Virginia and the Carolinas, and to rest his army at Beaufort and Port Royal.' That he would go to that point rather than Savannah is nearly certain, for if he directed his course to Savannah or to Charleston, he would find fortified and well defended cities, and his troops exhausted by a long march, both in strength and ammunition, would be wholly unfit to reduce either place. But the enemy already has possession of Beaufort. He would have no fighting to do there, and he would find transports laden with every species of supply awaiting his arrival. It is, therefore, reasonable to believe that Beaufort is the point of destination and that if he fails at Augusta, he will make his way thither as fast as the Confederate troops permit him. If the reader will glance at the map, he will perceive that when SHERMAN has passed from Chattanooga to Atlanta, and thence to Beaufort he will have severed every railroad between Georgia and Virginia. This severance will be easily repaired; but if he can establish himself permanently at Beaufort; he may be able to operate against those roads repeatedly. Furthermore, Beaufort lies between Charleston and Savannah, and can be conveniently used as the base of land operations against either city. It is evidently highly important that SHERMAN should never take Augusta or Macon, and should never reach Beaufort.

His design was to destroy the railroads as far as he could, which ran from Southern and Western Georgia to Virginia and the Carolinas, and to rest his army at Beaufort and Port Royal.' That he would go to that point rather than Savannah is nearly certain, for if he directed his course to Savannah or to Charleston, he would find fortified and well defended cities, and his troops exhausted by a long march, both in strength and ammunition, would be wholly unfit to reduce either place. But the enemy already has possession of Beaufort. He would have no fighting to do there, and he would find transports laden with every species of supply awaiting his arrival. It is, therefore, reasonable to believe that Beaufort is the point of destination and that if he fails at Augusta, he will make his way thither as fast as the Confederate troops permit him. If the reader will glance at the map, he will perceive that when SHERMAN has passed from Chattanooga to Atlanta, and thence to Beaufort he will have severed every railroad between Georgia and Virginia. This severance will be easily repaired; but if he can establish himself permanently at Beaufort; he may be able to operate against those roads repeatedly. Furthermore, Beaufort lies between Charleston and Savannah, and can be conveniently used as the base of land operations against either city. It is evidently highly important that SHERMAN should never take Augusta or Macon, and should never reach Beaufort.

abstract: The British steamer Solent, which arrived from St. Thomas, the 23d, sailed for Vera Cruz yesterday morning. Among other passengers, she carried the Baron DE WETTERSTEDT, Minister of Norway and Sweden at Washington, who goes to Mexico to oficially recognize the Mexican Empire, and to felicitate MAXIMILIAN on his accession to the throne. The Solent also carries 84 Austrians, destined to form port of MAXIMILIAN'S body-guard.

abstract: BURGLARY, AND CAPTURE OF THE PERPETRATOR. The residence of Mr. JOHN K. SAMSON, No. III West Warren-street, was feloniously entered at an early hour yesterday morning by boring the lock out of one of the doors, and several articles of clothing and silver-ware were stolen therefrom.
lead_paragraph: BURGLARY, AND CAPTURE OF THE PERPETRATOR. -- The residence of Mr. JOHN K. SAMSON, No. III West Warren-street, was feloniously entered at an early hour yesterday morning by boring the lock out of one of the doors, and several articles of clothing and silver-ware were stolen therefrom. SAMSON called at the Police Inspector's Office, where he was informed that the burglar had been captured and the property, as described by him, recovered. It appears that about 4 o'clock A.M., Officer WILLIAM BROWN, of the Forty-first Precinct Police, observed a man hearing a large bundle walking along Court-street, near the City Hall. He also noticed that he made no noise in walking; in fact, his footsteps could not be heard, so quietly he moved, although going along at a brisk pace, as if in a hurry. The officer at once suspected his real character and conducted him to the Station-house. On searching his person an auger and saw were found secreted under the waist of his coat. His shoes were examined and found to be of cloth, but on over his boots, the object being to make no noise while going about a house. He gave his name as EDWARD FITZGERALD. A number of burglaries have recently been perpetrated by boring and sawing off the locks of doors with tools such as discovered on this individual, and it is supposed that he committed all of them. He was locked up to await examination.

abstract: New-York; Ogden's Lumber-yard; Incendiary
lead_paragraph: About 5 o'clock yesterday morning, a fire was discovered in the large lumber yard of Messrs. OGDEN & Co., situated on Hubert-street, and extending from West to Washington streets. From information which we have obtained from Fire-Marshal BAKER, and from the police of the Fifth Precinct, where the fire occurred, we judge there can be no doubt that this conflagration was the work of an incendiary. The flames were first discovered in the centre of the lumber-yard, and were at the time under such headway that, notwithstanding the firemen were promptly on hand, and used their best exertions to stay them, the property contained therein was nearly all consumed. The loss of Messrs. OGDEN & Co. will exceed the sum of $80,000.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK. SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price Five Cents. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many or which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader: and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Speech at Volunteer Union Club; Speech at Vet Union Club
snippet: Speech at Volunteer Union Club; Speech at Vet Union Club
lead_paragraph: The Veteran Union Soldiers' Club held a ratification meeting at the Academy of Music, last evening. On the stage, was a number of veterans who had been maimed and disabled in the service of the country, but whose brave hearts were left to rejoice over the defeat of all the enemies to the Union and the old flag. Two fine bress field pieces were placed at either end of the stage, for the special reason, we presume, of making these brave boys feel more at home.

abstract: In the Fifth Aldermanic District, the Union candidate for Alderman is ALEXANDER H. KEECH, of the Ninth Ward. He is a practical printer, and an active politician. He has been a member of the Board of Councilmen, and performed the duties of the office with fidelity, ability and integrity. He is an honest, effective and worthy man, and deserves general support. The Democratic party have nominated two Democrats against him, and the Citizens' Association have added a third. We hope he will be elected.

lead_paragraph: There is something really melancholy in the propositions made by such men as Gov. BROWN, of Georgia, and Mr. J.T. LEACH, of North Carolina, for a convention of the States to agree on terms of peace in which the independence and separate sovereignty of each of them should be fully acknowledged; because they reveal an incapacity to comprehend the temper and opinions of the Northern people, and their object in prosecuting the war, which one can hardly help considering incurable.

abstract: Florida, the; Facts Connected with Sinking
snippet: Florida, the; Facts Connected with Sinking
lead_paragraph: OF THE FLORIDA. -- For the credit of the service, an official report of all the facts connected with the sinking of the Florida, cannot be published an hour too soon. It is to the interest of rebels and the abettors of rebellion, that the destruction of the vessel should be made to appear, not a thing of accident, but of design. This surmise, however base may be its origin, must be removed beyond the point of cavil. We might possibly be able, under certain conditions, to afford to make an open quarrel over a disputed question of international right. But we cannot afford to have it advertised that insubordination rules in any branch of the national service.

abstract: Both boards of the Common Council met yes  terday. The Aldermen concurred in the resolution to permit the "Masonic Mission " to erect a temporary building on the square at the Five Points, for the sale of coal and flour at cost prices. The Councilmen transacted nothing but routine business. Both boards adjourned to Monday, the Aldermen at 1, and the Councilmen at 2 P.M.

abstract: Chamber of Commerce on the Florida; Florida; The New-York Chamber of Commerce on
snippet: Chamber of Commerce on the Florida; Florida; The New-York Chamber of Commerce on
lead_paragraph: -- It is important that the discussions of a body, such as the New-York Chamber of Commerce, on such grave questions as the interpretation of international law, should be almost judicial in their temperateness. And we think we may well felicitate that body on its having reached a rational conclusion at its yesterday's session, in the matter of the communication of the merchants of Bahia respecting the capture of the Florida. To have returned that communication, as some ardent speakers recommended, because it came through the hands of the British Consul at Bahia, would not have well comported with the dignity of the chamber. And even the fact that the communication in question contained positive misstatements, could hardly be said to justify its summary rejection. The merchants of Bahia, doubtless, offered their remonstrance, believing that what they stated was true. And their employment of the agency of the British Consul does not appear to have involved anything beyond getting his official certificate for the genuineness of the signatures appended to the letter. It was, therefore, all things considered, a wise and judicious course to refer the letter to a committee, so that its allegations might be calmly considered, and an answer framed which should not discredit the character of the foremost commercial chamber on the continent. Passionate appeals or petulant decisions are but indications of weakness in any deliberative body. They could not emanate from a chamber of eminent merchants without a serious reflection on their discretion.

abstract: The handsome victory won by our forces under Gen. THOMAS, in Tennessee, on Wednesday, was received and announced by the TIMES yesterday morning, several hours ahead of our cotemporaries. The details supplied by our special dispatch from Nashville are full of thrilling interest, and prove it to have been one of the most hotly contested battles of the war.
lead_paragraph: The handsome victory won by our forces under Gen. THOMAS, in Tennessee, on Wednesday, was received and announced by the TIMES yesterday morning, several hours ahead of our cotemporaries. The details supplied by our special dispatch from Nashville are full of thrilling interest, and prove it to have been one of the most hotly contested battles of the war. The attack was made by the rebels under HOOD upon our fortified position at Franklin, and though the action was comparatively-brief, yet it was very sanguinary and bloody. The rebels charged our ranks, and were met with terrible slaughter from our guns. Every attempt failed, and they suffered a loss of six thousand in killed and wounded, beside twelve hundred prisoners, among whom were one Brigadier General and many Field officers. Our loss was less than a thousand, owing to our men being sheltered. During the night our forces retired a short distance, and took up a still stronger position, nearer Nashville, where, at the latest hour, Gen. THOMAS awaited HOOD's renewed onset. Our correspondent, whose account is very graphic, and whose means of information are unsurpassed, assures us that entire confidence in, and satisfaction with, the situation prevails.

abstract: Incendiaries; Military Commission
lead_paragraph: The Military Commission now engaged in an inquest into the rebel plot for burning down the city, have sufficient evidence before them to show that the conspiracy which broke out here this day week is merely an extension of the rebel burglary operations on the Canadian frontier. It is feared that some of the more vicious of the gang have been able to make good their escape across the border.

abstract: Franklin, the scene of the great victory over HOOD on Thursday, is the capital of Williamson County, Tenn., and is situated on the south bank of Big Harpeth River, about 18 miles from Nashville, on the line of the Nashville and Decatur Railroad. Before the war it was a beautiful village, with a population of about 2,000 people. Franklin has changed hands several times during the war. After VAN DORN's success in capturing a Union brigade at Spring Hill, near Franklin, in March, 1863, that rebel Commander moved upon the latter place, which he attacked on the 10th of April. Major-Gen. GORDON GRANGER was in command of the village. His forces comprised two infantry divisions of 1,600 men, 2,000 cavalry under SMITH and STANLEY, and eighteen guns. The only artificial defence was an uncompleted fort, which mounted two siege guns and two three-inch rifled guns. VAN DORN's force was estimated at nine thousand infantry and two regiments of cavalry. The rebels were handsomely repulsed, losing three hundred, while GRANGER's total loss was only thirty-seven.

abstract: The steamer Melville, from Port Royal Nov. 27, brings the report that on the 26th inst. Gen FOSTER had issued orders for all citizens to be enrolled at that place, and report for duty on the 29th. These were to be formed in companies for home protection. The United States forces there were to move immediately, destination unknown. The Melville reports that after leaving port, at about 6 P.M., heard heavy and quick firing at Port Royal, but could not tell its meaning.

abstract: Registration of Southerners Necessary
lead_paragraph: -The order issued by Major-Gen. DIX, in October, among other regulations, laid down this: "All persons from the insurgent States now within the department, or who may come within it on or before the 3d of November, proximo, are hereby required to report themselves for registry on or before that day." The order of last Saturday, requiring all new comers from the insurgent States to report themselves, does not at all exempt the older sojourners from this duty. We are glad to learn that the duty is to be enforced upon the thousands of the latter who have neglected it. Serious consequences will result to them from its further disregard. The public safety requires that the amount of the Southern population in our city should be known, and also what proportion of it recognize loyal obligations. It is certain that the rebel malice which lately attempted to lay the boat portion of our city in ashes, still exists in all its intensity. Nothing short of the utmost precaution can guard against its further work; and, to that end, it is first of all important to learn who these rebel enemies in our city are, and where they keep themselves. Surely loyal Southerners -- and we cheerfully recognize that there are some such -- must be glad of an opportunity thus publicly to attest their real disposition, and to save themselves from being confounded with our public enemies. So far as concerns the latter, they would have no right to complain were the requirement ten-fold more severe. Nothing but extreme magnanimity tolerates them at at all within the loyal lines. Let them take heed.

abstract: The flag-of-truce fleet of steamers, or at least a large part of them, are still at anchor in the Savannah River, above Fort Pulaski, receiving our released men as fast as the rebel authorities choose  to deliver them. The aggregate number transferred to Lieut.-Col. MULFORD during the past ten days will not exceed 5,500, but it is believed that the end of this week will witness the completion of the work.

abstract: A regular meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday afternoon at 1 o'clock, President A.A. Low in the chair. After the minutes of the last meeting were read and approved, Mr. DE WITT C. BLOODGOOD submitted a preliminary report on the Reciprocity Treaty with Canada, which was read by Mr. STEVENS, the Secretary. The committee stated that they had prepared a voluminous report, but they thought it not advisable to present it to the Chamber until alter the President's next message.

abstract: Great March
lead_paragraph: The intensity of the public anxiety to hear from the army of Gen. SHERMAN will be relieved, in great measure, this morning, by the brief but satisfactory dispatch from Lieut.-Gen. GRANT, and by the other telegraphic dispatches in our columns. It is twelve days since SHERMAN'S advance of cavalry reached the Oconee River, and since that time we have had no definite intelligence of the whereabouts of his army, though we have learned of the appearance of small bodies of our troops at various towns east and west of that stream. The enemy have withheld all news from us, and no couriers from SHERMAN have arrived at any point within our lines, either on the seaboard or in Tennessee. The rebel press only made absurd but ineffectual attempts to play upon the fears of the North, by representing that the people of Georgia had risen en masse, and obstructed SHERMAN's advance by felling trees, burning bridges, and destroying supplies; that clouds of their cavalry were hovering around and harrassing his flanks and rear, and heavy bodies of troops were ready to contest the possession of Macon, Augusta and Millen, while a great army was being concentrated in his front upon the lower Savannah, prepared to demolish him utterly when he approached, if he were not utterly demolished long before he got anywhere near the seaboard. The rodomontade of the rebels produced no adverse effect; for the people knew the power and mettle of an army of Western veterans led by an accomplished soldier like SHERMAN.
headline: {'main': 'The Great March.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Great March.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: in Tennessee
lead_paragraph: Gen. HOOD, who is certainly one of the most daring of the rebel Generals, having met with a bloody repulse at Franklin, the question is, what will he do next? We have no idea, that he will undertake to attack Gen. THOMAS, heavily reinforced by SMITH's corps, and posted in one of the strongest Federal fortresses. Neither do we suppose he will attack Murfreesboro,' which is a most thoroughly-defended stronghold. Probably he will move to the south, cut the railroad to Chattanooga, burn the bridges over the Tennessee, raid through that portion of the State, and then, breaking loose from his base at Florence, turn easterly toward Knoxville. He can easily feed 30,000 men in the country at this season of the year, and when he reaches the region beyond Knoxville, he can have a new base in Virginia and unite with BRECKINRIDGE's victorious corps.

abstract: Banquet in Philadelphia
lead_paragraph: At about 4 o'clock yesterday morning, a terrible tragedy took place in one of the prison rooms at the Tombs, whereby two prisoners named WM. KENNEDY and JAMES McDONALD lost their lives, and another prisoner named WM. GEORGE was so badly injured that he cannot recover. These men, while asleep, were suddenly attacked by JOHN DONOVAN, a fellow prisoner, who beat them with a heavy iron bar. on the head and body, until the two first named died, and GEORGE cannot survive. DONOVAN is a returned soldier, who had been drinking to excess for several days, and on Thursday last he was temporarily committed to the city prison, for gross intoxication. It is believed that he was afflicted with delirium tremens when he committed the deed.

abstract: The report published in yesterday's papers of the safety of the steamship North Star, and sent to us by our ship-news collector, he regrets to say, is entirely without foundation. abstract: We are to have another charter election on Tuesday next. The various factions of the various political parties are in the field with their candidates as usual, and the Citizens' Association,...
lead_paragraph: We are to have another charter election on Tuesday next. The various factions of the various political parties are in the field with their candidates as usual, and the Citizens' Association, aiming at the extinction of political differences, has also come forward with a ticket upon which it hopes to concentrate the wealth and respectability of the city. The association embraces in its list of members many very wealthy and influential names. Its objects are such as must commend themselves to general approval, and in certain districts of the city its efforts are likely to be crowned with a reasonable degree of success. Whether that success will suffice to change materially the practical working of the City Government, and to reform the manifold abuses which are so notorious and so damaging, remains of course to be seen. Our own expectations in that respect, we confess, are not very sanguine.
headline: {'main': 'Reform in the City Government.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Reform in the City Government.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: FRANKENSTEIN'S PAINTINGS. -- We mentioned, a few days since, that the distinguished artist, FRANKENSTEIN, had arrived in this city from the West, bringing with him his cabinet of beautiful small paintings; also, a large and remarkable picture of "Niagara." He has also several life-size portraits, some charming figure pictures, and a bust of the celebrated surgeon, Dr. MUSSY, which proves that in sculpture he is equal to his power in paint.

abstract: Muller, the Railway Murderer; Execution of
snippet: Muller, the Railway Murderer; Execution of
lead_paragraph: By the China, which arrived here yesterday, we have news very disgusting in its details of the execution of MULLER, the German tailor. He seems to have kept his secret well up to the last moment for all that went to support his conviction was purely circumstantial evidence. His nature, however, seems to have given way under the tangible influence of the hangman's rope; and a very vulgar and ordinary sort of murderer, who probably hoped to get a name by his crimes, broke down in his last effort (before a sympathetic audience) on the scaffold. A worthy German clergyman of the Lutheran Church attended MULLER in his last hours, and to him the culprit made his confession at the last moment. MULLER, in short, murdered poor old Mr. BRIGGS in a London Railway carriage for the sake of his watch and chain, which he first tried to steal, but, falling in that, robbed and murdered the unfortunate man.

abstract: Campaign Already a Success
lead_paragraph: Savannah, it is supposed, is the terminus of SHERMAN'S campaign, but it is by no means his chief "objective." Therein the public mind, we think, is making a mistake. It suspends its judgment concerning the success of the campaign till it sees whether or not he captures Savannah. The truth is that though SHERMAN may still, for aught we know, be scores of miles from Savannah, his campaign has already secured its most important end. It has again bisected the Confederacy.
headline: {'main': "Sherman's Campaign Already a Success.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Sherman's Campaign Already a Success.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Barbarities; Our Good for Evil
lead_paragraph: -Another instance is on hand of the different treatment we award to the rebels from that which they give to us, They have been cruelly silent respecting the movements of SHERMAN in Georgia, withholding all intelligence of his whereabouts, and only working upon our fears by vaguely and frequently hinting that our invisible army was being rapidly hacked to pieces and ruined, while a wretched remnant of it was floundering through Georgia, and into the arms and pens of "Hog WINDER." They have tantalized us all in their power, by telling us that they possessed news of SHERMAN's fearful disasters, but would not give it to us.

abstract: We have later and important intelligence from Gen. SHERMAN. An official dispatch from Gen. GRANT, to Secretary STANTON, states that Richmond papers of Dec. 1, admits that SHERMAN'S entire army is now east of the Oconee, and ...
lead_paragraph: We have later and important intelligence from Gen. SHERMAN. An official dispatch from Gen. GRANT, to Secretary STANTON, states that Richmond papers of Dec. 1, admits that SHERMAN'S entire army is now east of the Oconee, and progressing toward the seaboard. This is the whole of the definite intelligence. Reports that SHERMAN was within forty miles of Savannah on the 24th, have no foundation beyond the merest rumor. Our special correspondent in the Savannah River had no such news on the 27th. It is said, however, that Gen. GRANT expects SHERMAN to reach the seacoast to-day.

abstract: We are glad to see that the result of the election, or further consideration of the subject, has led quite a number of prominent journalists and other public men to modify their views as to President LINCOLN's position and purposes in regard to terms of peace. It may be remembered that when the letter "to whom it may concern" appeared, we ventured to contest the popular idea that it was intended as an ultimatum to the rebel States. The National intelligencer refuted our views at very great length, and insisted repeatedly, and with rather more than its usual vehemence, that the President could not possibly assent to any peace which did not include the "abandonment of slavery," as well as the restoration of the Union.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. "DON SEBASTIAN" improves rapidly in public estimation. The performance last evening was the warmest in point of applause we have yet attended, and it was decidedly...
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- "DON SEBASTIAN" improves rapidly in public estimation. The performance last evening was the warmest in point of applause we have yet attended, and it was decidedly the best in every artistic sense. Signor MASSIMILIANI was in excellent voice, and sang his romanza -- which it must be remembered ranges up to C, with great great power and sweetness. Segnor BELLINI, too, was in thorough trim. Madame ZUECHI[???] sang -- as she always does -- like a true artist. The entire opera went smoothly and well.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship China at this port and the Bavaria at Cape Race, we have European news to the 19th ult. The ship Great Western was detained at Liverpool on suspicion that her passengers had been recruited by Federal...
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship China at this port and the Bavaria at Cape Race, we have European news to the 19th ult. The ship Great Western was detained at Liverpool on suspicion that her passengers had been recruited by Federal agents for the military service of the United States. The Great Western had four or five hundred men on board, and was on the point of sailing when she was detained. The matter was referred to the authorities in London. The Liverpool Post of Nov. 18 says that SEMMES was recruiting men in that city for a privateer, that he had already sent off a number, and was himself to start for Gibraltar in a few days. The Southern correspondent of the London Times, writing September 23, from Columbia, N.C., admits that the drain of the war on men in the South had been terrible, and was daily augmenting. The news of the Presidential election was awaited with the greatest interest in England. The capture of a British Navy officer in command of a blockade runner, has led to the issue of stringent orders from the Admiralty on the subject. The execution of FRANZ MULLER, which took place Nov. 14, was attended by disgraceful scenes of violence about the jail. At least a hundred thousand of the lowest population of London gathered to witness the death of MULLER, and our correspondent writes that every person worth robbing who entered the crowd was immediately lightened of everything valuable. A large number of persons were severely injured by the rabble. Just as the executioner drew the bolt. MULLER uttered a few words which have been taken as a confession of guilt. His death caused intense excitement throughout Germany, and has led, it is reported, to diplomatic correspondence between the Courts of England and Prussia.

snippet: Gray, David, Poems of; Norton, Hon Mrs; Lady of La Garaye; Rider's Lyra Anglicana; Jamison's, Mrs, Sacred and Legendary Art; Lamb, Charles; Eliana; Anderson's, Dr, Hawaiian Islands; Child's, L M, Looking Toward Sunset; Gentle Life, the
lead_paragraph: GAIL HAMILTON is a lay preacher, who addresses a wide circle of hearers. She has a sharp eye for social weaknesses and follies, and a keen pen for dissecting them. Her range of vision is not extensive, but she possesses good sense enough to confine herself chiefly to the topics with which she is best acquainted -- the phases of society conspicuous in a New-England village or country town. We do not know whether she is popular, or the reverse, in her own, neighborhood, assured ly the picture of it to be deduced from her writings is not inviting. There is a hard stern realism everywhere apparent in her books that gives one the impression of having "kept company" with a highly sensible person whom we are not anxious to see again. The subject of "A New Atmosphere" is the endless one of woman's false position, her grievances, sufferings and wrongs, that arise from the errors growing out of our imperfect civilization. The theme is one that calls out all the writer's energies causing her to be terribly in earnest.

abstract: New-York, Tombs--Murder by Colored Woman in Cell
snippet: New-York, Tombs--Murder by Colored Woman in Cell
lead_paragraph: WM. GEORGE, the third man who was beaten on the head with an iron bar in the hands of JOHN DONOVAN, in one of the rooms of the City Prison, on Friday morning last, died at about 6 o'clock yesterday morning. A full account of this terrible homicide we published in the TIMES of yesterday. GEORGE did not rally after the fearful beating that he received. Upon an examination of his wounds, the surgeons were surprised that he should have survived so long. Coroner NAUMANN held an inquest on his body, and Dr. WOOSTER BEACH, Jr., made a postmortem examination. A verdict similar to that in the case of KENNEDY and MCDONALD was rendered by the jury. Deceased was a native of England, aged 28 years.

abstract: Muller's, in London
lead_paragraph: -- Those who read the account of the horrible scenes at MULLER's execution, published in our yesterday's issue, probably doubt whether there is any parallel to them even in England. They have been paralleled very often. But on this occasion they have suggested to the London press the plain and rational question, whether executions might not as well take place within the walls of the prison. The trouble which arises before the "leading journal" in determining this question is that, "the countries in which private executions have, at different times been adopted, have been those in which the supreme power is vested in a single person."

abstract: M. LOUIS BERTRAND, well known in the French sporting world, has addressed to the France the following particulars respecting the fine dog which is the travelling companion of the Emperor of Russia: "This animal is not of the Newfoundland breed, as stated, but a fine jet black setter of large size and beautiful form, with long silky hair.
lead_paragraph: -- M. LOUIS BERTRAND, well known in the French sporting world, has addressed to the France the following particulars respecting the fine dog which is the travelling companion of the Emperor of Russia: "This animal is not of the Newfoundland breed, as stated, but a fine jet black setter of large size and beautiful form, with long silky hair. His name is Milford, and he is of the same breed as Black Rake, one of the spaniels which I last spring presented to the Egyptian Prince, HALIM PACHA. Milford was at one time an excellent shooting dog, but since his promotion to the rank of favorite he rarely does any work, except it may be occasionally to act as a retriever, and fetch any head of game his roaster may have shot. He is excessively gentle, and the inseparable companion of the Emperor, following him throughout the palace, and even into his cabinet. At night he always lies at the door of his master's chamber. The Emperor generally feeds the dog himself, and never allows any one but his personal aide-de-camp to give him any food whatever."

abstract: The news from Gen. SHERMAN, this morning, is of a very important character. A dispatch from Washington says the Government has information that Gen. SHERMAN occupied Millen, seventy miles north of Savannah, on the 29th ult., and by this time he is believed to be in front of Savannah. The Richmond Enquirer,...
lead_paragraph: The news from Gen. SHERMAN, this morning, is of a very important character. A dispatch from Washington says the Government has information that Gen. SHERMAN occupied Millen, seventy miles north of Savannah, on the 29th ult., and by this time he is believed to be in front of Savannah. The Richmond Enquirer, of Dec. 1, also admits the capture of Millen, and says SHERMAN has thus far met with very little resistance in his march. From our Savannah and Augusta files of the 26th and 28th inst., we also get information, which very plainly indicates that SHERMAN was fully as far advanced as has been previously reported. We also get some details of the effect of his march through the country. It seems he found supplies so plenty that great quantities of corn, wheat, &c., were burned, and horses, mules, sheep, swine, &c., killed on the roadside.

abstract: The trial of the Columbia County (Pa.) conspirators have come to a close. JOHN RANTZ, a ringleader in the disturbances, has been sentenced to pay a line of $1,000, and to be imprisoned in Fort Mifflin for two years. SAMUEL KLINE has been sentenced to two years' imprisonment, and WM. APPLEMAN to pay $500 fine.

abstract: A man who gave his name as GEO. SMITH, about 30 years of age, was arrested yesterday afternoon, on the charge of having stolen about $2,000 worth of diamonds from Messrs. WM.W. CRANE & Co., of No. 10 Maiden-lane. It appears that SMITH entered the store and stated that he wished to purchase some diamonds to match some that he had with him. Two packages of diamonds were accordingly produced, and while SMITH was looking at them, one of the partners of the establishment entered, and took a survey or his customer. SMITH observing that he was closely watched, suddenly turned pale, became greatly agitated, and without saying a word, started for the door, upon reaching which, he ran rapidly down the street. Mr. CRANE followed him, and in Nassau-street with the aid of some citizens, he was taken into custody. Officer CARROLL, of the Twenty-seventh Precinct, took him in charge, and went with him to Mr. CRANE's store. When there, the proposition was made to search SMITH, whereupon the latter drew from one of his pockets a package of unset diamonds, valued at $2,000, which he had stolen from the counter of the establishment.

abstract: A correspondence of the Augusta Chronicle and Sentinel, who left Milledgeville the day the Legislature adjourned, going out by the way of Eaton, gives a very numerous description of the many mishaps of himself and his party on the way, trying to reach Madison. They were out three days, during which time they subsisted on parched corn. The writer then proceeds:

abstract: the Expedition Against
lead_paragraph: The expedition of the combined Powers to open the passage to the Inland Sea, has proved successful. On the 5th of September the fleet appeared off Simonosaki, and immediately commenced an attack on the Prince of NAGATO's forts, two of which were destroyed before evening. Next day, at dawn, the attack was renewed, and a storming party having been landed from the ships, several of the other forts were quickly carried. This so intimidated the Prince that, shortly after the revival of the conflict on the third morning, he dispatched one of the Japanese envoys who had been in England, with a flag of truce to the assailants, tendered his submission, and begged a cessation of hostilities. The request was granted on condition that the Daimio would assent to the terms of the victors, and thus the attack was brought to a close. The loss sustained by the allied fleet did not exceed 100 killed and wounded, but its loss would not have been so trifling, nor its conquest so easy, had NAGATO been supported by his brother Daimio, the Prince of KOKURA, who rules over the country on the southern side of the strait.

abstract: Barbarities; The Lesson of; Rebel Cruelties to; The Lesson of
snippet: Barbarities; The Lesson of; Rebel Cruelties to; The Lesson of
lead_paragraph: It is remarkable that two such terrible instances of the barbarism of the rebels should have been presented at once, as were furnished by our columns of last Monday and the two previous days. The dreary tales of those sufferers in the prison-pens of Georgia, which filled such large portions of our sheet for two days, read like the story of another age and of a savage people. The patient and ingenious malignity which must have devised this slow agony for these unfortunate creatures; the hardness of heart which could allow thousands of human beings, once friends and neighbors, now disarmed and helpless, to die for want of fuel in a country of forests; which could permit such food to be furnished that even the rebel surgeons describe it as "alive with maggots;" the callous indifference and cruelty which could leave the sick for months on the damp ground, and suffer the camps with thousands of prisoners to be filled with excrement, and even the unburied bodies of the dead, decaying in a tropical atmosphere; the meanness which, in a country well supplied, as Georgia is, with corn and bacon, could starve these helpless captives -- all these form such a combination of cruel and savage qualities and brutal actions such as we could hardly believe possible in this age and country.
headline: {'main': 'The Lesson from the Rebel Cruelty.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Lesson from the Rebel Cruelty.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: When a soldier dies, his body is washed, enshrouded in a clean shirt and drawers, and with naked hands and feet, is carried on a stretcher by the nurses to the dead-house and put in a plain, red coffin. The soldier's name, company and regiment are painted on the under side of the coffin lid, to identify the deceased in case of exhuming. At the hour appointed, the escort, drum corps, dead-cart, pall-bearers, and the Chaplain, all being assembled, the funeral begins by placing the encoffined dead in the cart, each one receiving the regular dead salute of a three-fold rapping of the drums and the shouldering and presenting of arms by the escort. We usually take five at a load, all covered over with the glorious old flag they died to honor and defend. All ready, with a slow step, graced with the solemn notes of the "Dead March," of fife and drum, we march to the graveyard, and with solemn silence consign them to the tomb.

abstract: Foreign Lady's Views of the Rebellion
snippet: Foreign Lady's Views of the Rebellion
lead_paragraph: -- We published in last Sunday's TIMES the letter of a Southern lady, intended to give vent to the anguish she was compelled to smother in her domestic circle at witnessing the outrages committed upon her people in the prosecution of the war. We endeavored to show in as generous terms as possible wherein we thought our fair correspondent failed to appreciate the situation. But as we only went over a very limited ground another fair correspondent comes forward this morning to supplement our easy commentary. Being herself a foreigner, the lady who speaks to-day, claims to do so without prejudice. Be this as it may, she certainly speaks out. Her subject is handled most assuredly without gloves. And her masculine English would do no discredit to an experienced political fencer of the other sex.

abstract: Extract from Thanksgiving Sermon
lead_paragraph: STERN LOYALTY IN THE PULPIT. -- The Thanks-giving sermon preached by Rev. SAMUEL J. CORNEILLE Rector of All Saints' Church, has been published. We extract the following eloquent passage: "And yet there is something worse than war: national dishonor, cowardice, and selfishness: the decay of manly enthusiasm; the pusillanimity that shrinks from duty, because it is surrounded by peril. These are worse than war. If we must purchase peace at the price of dishonor: if peace means the cowardly relinquishment of every virtue and every right that makes man God-like; if we seek peace on the grounds that national prosperity and wealth consists in silk and cotton, in that thing men that call capital, rather than in noble, generous, high-souled hearts; if we must pay for peace with national virtue; if, to obtain it, we must surrender our manly spirit of heroic endurance, our conscientious convictions of duty and right; if this is the price at which it must be purchased, then give us war -- "war with a thousand battles, and shaking a hundred thrones." Better that men should die, than that they should degenerate. Better then every foot or our Republic should be stained with blood, than that American freemen should prefer life to duty, national wealth to national principal and integrity."

abstract: Gov. VANCE commences his message by calling upon the present Legislature to unite with him in a cooperation for the public good, as sincere, and tempered with as much forbearance, as existed between the Governor and the last Legislature. The crops of the past season, he says, were fair, and in some places excellent.
lead_paragraph: Gov. VANCE commences his message by calling upon the present Legislature to unite with him in a cooperation for the public good, as sincere, and tempered with as much forbearance, as existed between the Governor and the last Legislature. The crops of the past season, he says, were fair, and in some places excellent. The enemy have made no further encroachments, save in the recapture of Plymouth and the consequent evacuation of Washington. The western border of the State is, however, subject to raids and depredations from bands of lawless men, who swarm in the mountain frontier, and murder, burn and destroy with savage cruelty. Some of the interior counties also, are infested by deserters representing nearly every State in the Confedeeacy, who lurk in the swamps and mountains, stealing, plundering, and in many instances murdering the inhabitants. In some places they muster in such force as almost to amount to the suspension of the civil authority, aided and protected, as they are, by their relatives and friends.

abstract: History of
lead_paragraph: Major-Gen. PATRICK ROMAGNE CLEBURNE, C.S.A., was the second son of Dr. JOSEPH CLEBURNE, of the "Grange" Castle, Bellingham, Ireland. He pursued his studies at Trinity College, Dublin, and before their completion, entered the British army, but not finding a soldier's life congenial to his tastes, he resigned and turned his attention to the law. On the death of his father, CLEBURNE came to the United States and settled at Helena, Ark., where he commenced the practice of law under the auspices of his friend, Judge HANLY, of the Supreme Court of that State, and soon earned for himself quite a reputation at the bar of his adopted State. On the breaking out of the rebellion he volunteered as a private in the First Arkansas Infantry, in which regiment he was soon afterward elected Captain, and subsequently became its Colonel. Col. CLEBURNE commanded the rear guard of the retreating rebel forces at Bowling Green, and was commissioned a Brigadier General at Shiloh. He served with POLK at Perrysville, where he was severely wounded. On his recovery he succeeded to the command of BUCKNER's old division, and after the invasion of Kentucky was made a Major-General. He has held his command in the Army of Tennessee ever since, and was considered by the rebels one of their most accomplished General officers. Gen. CLEBURNE, though an Irishman by birth, was an intense Southerner in feeling, considering the South much oppressed by the North, though, strange to say, his opinions were anti-slavery. A cousin of the General's resides in Philadelphia, and holds a commission as surgeon in the United States Navy. His brother, WM. CLEBURNE, Esq., for some time connected with the Pennsylvania Railroad Company as Civil Engineer, is a man of high moral tone, and of great scientific attainments. He, together with his family, remains true to the flag which his rebel brother had so basely and ungratefully forsaken. It is said that Gen. CLEBURNE has shown great kindness to such of our men as have fallen into his hands.

abstract: Incendiaries Shielded by Opposition Press; Press Shielding Rebel Incendiaries
snippet: Incendiaries Shielded by Opposition Press; Press Shielding Rebel Incendiaries
lead_paragraph: Some of the Opposition prints are pretending that the late attempt to fire our city was no Southern work at all, but an Administration trick. This is carrying impudence into absolute senselessness. The abuse heaped upon Secretary SEWARD and Major-Gen. DIX, previous to the election, for their public notifications that rebel agents wore scheming such attacks upon our cities, had some sort of an excuse in the party excitement of the day. It was possible that even honest men could imagine in the heat of that time, that these statements by public officials were put forth only to play upon the fears of the people, and make party capital. Of course, it was not very reasonable to suppose that public servants of such a personal character, and in such a position, would condescend to so low a game; but unreasonableness is too common at such times to be judged very harshly.

abstract: The steamship North Star. Capt. Jones, from Aspinwall arrived at Port Royal Nov. 28, short of coal, having in tow her convoy, the U.S. steam gunboat Augusta, which broke her piston-rod 400 miles to the eastward of that port. Capt. Jones expected to secure a sufficient quantity of coal on board by noon of the 1st inst., and would then sail for New-York. The North Star has on freight $500,000 in specie, mails and 181 passengers.
lead_paragraph: The steamship North Star. Capt. Jones, from Aspinwall arrived at Port Royal Nov. 28, short of coal, having in tow her convoy, the U.S. steam gunboat Augusta, which broke her piston-rod 400 miles to the eastward of that port. Capt. abstract: -- Some time last Summer a gentleman of Carondefer Township, who lives in near neighbourhood to Mr. DENT, the father-in-law to Gen. GRANT, was arrested by a posse of provost detectives, as he was escorting Mrs. GRANT, in his buggy, to this city. After a short detention at Gra[???] prison, he was released on bond of $5,000, and paroled to the limits of the department, conditions with which he strictly complied. Unluckily his name was drawn in last week's draft in that sub-district, and he was placed between two horns of a dilemma. Either he must obey the draft summons, be sent beyond the department bounds, and forfeit the $5,000 penalty, or stand [???] to the terms of his parole, and be pro[???]ted against as a draft deserter. A question was made up in official from as to his primal duty in the ma[???], and in due course of red tape delays and cir[???] [???], it reached Gen. R[???]CRANS who has occured substantially as follows:

abstract: On Saturday night and Sunday morning, Capt. Jourdan's men arrested and took to the Sixth Preeinct Station-house the usual number of drunken and disorderly persons; eleven of whom were taken in between midnight and 2 o'clock in the morning. Among these were Margaret Peters, of No. 19 Baxter-street; Sarah, E. Williams, of No. 19 Mulberrystreet; Sarah Savocoe, of Baxter-street, corner of ...
lead_paragraph: On Saturday night and Sunday morning, Capt. Jourdan's men arrested and took to the Sixth Preeinct Station-house the usual number of drunken and disorderly persons; eleven of whom were taken in between midnight and 2 o'clock in the morning. Among these were Margaret Peters, of No. 19 Baxter-street; Sarah, E. Williams, of No. 19 Mulberrystreet; Sarah Savocoe, of Baxter-street, corner of Leonard, and Mary Bean, a pauper. The three former are colored, and aged from 18 to 22 years; but the latter was an Irishwoman, aged 92, Neither of the four seemed disposed to be quarrelsome, but all at the time of their examination before Sergeant Kennedy appeared to be grossly intoxicated and harmless; and one by one, as they were taken in by the patrolmen of the precinct, they were sent into a cell for females. Savacoe, however, recovered from her stupor soon after her incarceration, and when, at about 2 o'clock yesterday morning, the aged Irishwoman Bean appeared and became one of her companions, she became enraged, and perceiving that abusive epithets had no effect upon her new cellmate, she resorted to blows, and knocked her to the floor, and bent and kicked her until life had fled. Her companions, meantime, shrieked in vain for aid: but their cries were not heard by the watchman. The officers of the cell were called, and the murderess was removed to another cell and kept until the arrival of Coroner NaUmann and a jury. Testimony was then taken as follows?

abstract: The Duty of Congress
lead_paragraph: One of the most important questions which will come before the next Congress and the new Administration, will be the question of National Retrenchment. For the first three years of the war, the nation has conducted the struggle on the principle of immense outlays of money and men, to accomplish great results speedily. By the pouring forth of life and means in a profusion unknown in history, we have acquired a domain from the rebellion whose importance to us could never be estimated in money, and we have gone far toward crushing an outbreak which, under a different system of attacks, might have lasted a generation.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Fulton, on Saturday evening, we hare intelligence from Port Royal to the 30th ult. We learn that the publication of newspapers at that place has been, for the present, prohibited, and that all citizens had been enrolled, and are now used for the protection of the place, as a movement of some unknown character had taken place, and the troops ordered away. An expedition had sailed from Port Royal previously, but no Information could be gained relative to cither of the above movements from the officers of the Fulton.

abstract: -- The Atlantic Monthly (Boston: TICKNOR & FIELDS) opens its December number with "The Highland L[???]ht," a graphic posthumous paper of THOREAU's, on the Cape Cod region, bringing out its characteristics with the living fidelity that marked all his studies of nature; "English Authors in Florence" by Miss K. FIELD is a curious example how "the whirligig of than brings about its revenges," the purport of the article being mainly, a glorification of the Trollope family, not forgetting Mrs. Trollope herself, that "name of fear" to our fathers of thirty years ago; Mr-GILLMOEE's "Our Last Day in Dixie," is a vainglorious apology for his Quixotic escapade at Richmond; this writer seems out of place in the Atlantic. The most noticeable feature of the number is unquestionably "England and America, "by Prof. GOLDWIN SMITH. It is a powerful and well-reasoned plea for mutual friendship, explaining the cause of the adverse manifestations of feeling that hide and obscure the real interest taken by the great heart of the nation in the success of freedom and right. Every one must admire Prof. SMITH's eloquent earnestness. The form of the paper will be, we think, the only objection to its universal reception. It is written in the first person, and in a tone decidedly didactic. Now, for one man to lecture a great nation is a service of delicacy, that even the consciousness of a good cause is not [???] sufficient to insure success. "Ice and E [???]maux," by D.A. WABSON, commences cheerily an account of a last Summer's amateur excursion to Labrador. Longfellow's Sonnet, on Translating the Divine Commedia" must not be overlooked. The other articles are readable, and, as Miss HOSMER's "Process of Sculpture" contain matter that should not be overlooked. The promise of the "Atlantic Monthly" for the New-Year is brilliant. A story to be continued for twelve months, by DONALD C. MITCHELL, (Ike Marvell) entitled "Dr. Johns." -- some precious fragments from HAWTHOENE's papers -- and contributions from Mrs. S.C. HALL, by A. SALA, and the author of "Ten Acres Enough," being only a portion of the forthcoming novelties.

abstract: The intelligence from Gen. THOMAS' army continues to be favorable. No new developments have taken place since the retirement of Gen. THOMAS to the vicinity of Nashville. Our lines extend around the city in the southeast, its wings resting on the Cumberland River. The enemy's lines are within three miles of the city, in a southeastern direction. Heavy skirmishing occurred yesterday on our
lead_paragraph: The intelligence from Gen. THOMAS' army continues to be favorable. No new developments have taken place since the retirement of Gen. THOMAS to the vicinity of Nashville. Our lines extend around the city in the southeast, its wings resting on the Cumberland River. The enemy's lines are within three miles of the city, in a southeastern direction. Heavy skirmishing occurred yesterday on our left, without serious results to either side. It is supposed that HOOD will not long delay an attack on our lines. The north bank of the river was patrolled by Union cavalry to prevent a crossing by the rebels. A rumor that FORREST has placed a pontoon bridge across the river above the city is contradicted. A block-house, four miles from the city on the Chattanooga road, was surrendered to the rebels yesterday, after a brave but ineffectual resistance against greatly superior numbers.

abstract: Official Vote for Presidential Electors; Presidential Electors; Official Vote for
snippet: Official Vote for Presidential Electors; Presidential Electors; Official Vote for
lead_paragraph: -- The Committee of the Executive Council, to whom was referred the returns of the votes for Electors of President and Vice-President of the United States, report the number of votes to be as follows: At large, EDWARD EVERETT, of Boston, 126,742; WHITING GRISWOLD, of Greenfield, 126,626; ROBERT C. WINTHROP, of Boston, 48,745; ERASMUS D. DEACH, of Springfield, 48, 566. It will be seen that the plurality of the Republican vote for Mr EVERETT, who heads the ticket, over Mr. WINTHROP, who leads the Democratic ticket, is 78,000, lacking three votes. The vote for the District Electors is substantially the same, although in some instances several thousand votes were lost by a transposition of names or the candidates. For instance. ABRAHAM JACKSON, of Boston, the Democratic candidate in the Fourth District, received 13,017 votes as of the Third District; GEORGE L. DAVIS, the Republican candidate in the Sixth District, received 5.295 votes as of the Fifth District; John G. WHITIER the Republican candidate in the Fifth District, received 5.295 votes as of the Sixth District; 11,485 votes were cast for ANDREW PIERCE as of the Fourth District, instead of ANDREW PIERCE, Jr., the Democratic candidate in the Third District; 8,043 votes were cast for WM. D. SWAN as of the Second District, instead of for JOHN WILSON, the regular Democratic candidate, Mr. SWAN having died before the election. These errors were caused by those intrusted with the preparations of the ballots. -- Boston Journal, Nov. 30.

abstract: On Municipal Reform; Municipal Reforms; Evening Post on
snippet: On Municipal Reform; Municipal Reforms; Evening Post on
lead_paragraph: The Evening Post opposes with force and plausibility our suggestion that the scope and powers of the City Commissions, which, alike in their organization and practical workings, have earned public confidence, should be enlarged. It concedes that they have worked well, but thinks this is because they have little to do, and fears that, with more patronage and responsibility, they would lose their virtue. Possibly this might prove true; but the presumption is at least quite as strong the other way. The reason why our new police works better than the old one, is because it is more removed from party politics, more independent in its tenure of office, more directly responsible, and appointed in a way to secure better men at its head. The result of all these advantages is that it preserves better order than the old one. Would not the same reasons render it probable, at least, that it would also clean the streets better? Possibly it might fail there, but the chances are against failure; and the need of reform is so great as to warrant the risk. And so of other departments.

abstract: Pacific Steamers; Piratical Plot to Seize
snippet: Pacific Steamers; Piratical Plot to Seize
lead_paragraph: On the 18th of November, the TIMES contained an exclusive account, derived from authentic sources, of a desperate scheme, matured by a band of rebel pirates, to capture one or more of the Pacific Mail Company's steamships, on the Panama coast. The full history of the plot, and all the particulars bearing upon its detection and frustration at Panama, were published (again exclusively) in our issue of Yesterday, and may be read in our columns of to-day.

abstract: We have received a communication written on "behalf of several ladies who are students in the Medical College for Women," complaining that the twenty or thirty lady students who are permitted to attend the clinical and other lectures...
lead_paragraph: We have received a communication written on "behalf of several ladies who are students in the Medical College for Women," complaining that the twenty or thirty lady students who are permitted to attend the clinical and other lectures in Bellevue Hospital College, are not properly treated by their fellow-students of the other sex. If our correspondent will modify his language and permit the publication of his proper name to his communication, we will give him a hearing on behalf of the ladies; but when he expresses his "burning desire to avenge the studied and deliberate, yet brutal and beastly insults leveled at wives, daughters and sisters, by a large portion of the male students then and there assembled," we must ask him to consider and reconsider the style of his words, and the gravity of his charges; and if he chooses to "inform the miscreants that they are watched," he must adopt some other medium than this for his information. He further asserts that "the Professors have been appealed to, to stop these outrages, but they have declined," which statement we must decline crediting.
