abstract: Mr.HIRAM TIBBETS, residing at No. 203 West Twenty-seventh-street, appeared before Justice LEDWITH yesterday, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, and made complaint against five young men, named John Cannon, Peter Rooney, Robert John-...
lead_paragraph: Mr.HIRAM TIBBETS, residing at No. 203 West Twenty-seventh-street, appeared before Justice LEDWITH yesterday, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, and made complaint against five young men, named John Cannon, Peter Rooney, Robert Johnson, John Darcy and John McGuire. These persons are charged by TIBBETTS with having made a felonious assault on him, and with having robbed him of a gold watch and chain valued at $150. From the testimony it appears that TIBBETTS went into a saloon on Seventh-avenue, between Twenty-seventh and Twenty-eighth streets, kept by the prisoner JOHNSON. He there called for a drink and paid for it. While he was drinking, he was suddenly struck a powerful blow in the face, and another in the left eye, by one of the accused, but which one TIBBETTS does not know. The result of these blows was to fell TIBBETTS to the floor, and rendering him partially insensible. While he was lying thus, he was robbed of his gold watch and chain, which have not been recovered. As soon as he was able, TIBBETS gave the alarm, and Officers MCGOWEN, KENNEDY, TRAINOR, GAMBLING and CONNER, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, were promptly on hand, and arrested all of the persons above named. Justice LEDWITH, after an examination, committed each of the accused, in default of $1,500 bail, for trial.

abstract: The news from Gen. SHERMAN this morning is both meagre and contradictory in its character. The steamer Gen. Lyon, which left the Savannah River on Thursday night last, Dec. 1, and which arrived at Fortress Monroe on Sunday evening, reports that the latest intelligence in Savannah was that SHERMAN's cavalry was scouting within six miles of the city. Much excitement prevailed, and every effort was being made for the defence of the city. Even boys of 13 and women were at work on the fortifications, On the other hand the Richmond papers of Saturday are more boastful than ever, and represent that SHERMAN's forces are being generally used up! The Richmond Examiner predicts that if Gen. SHERMAN now gets through it will be with the loss of half his army. All this must be taken for just what it is worth.

abstract: Barbarities; More Victims of
lead_paragraph: The transport Baltic which arrived Sunday at Annapolis, left Savannah with five hundred and twenty of our released prisoners. Of this number fifty-seven died on the passage. And two-thirds of the remainder, it is said, will never recover. There is something too horrible almost for contemplation in this practical record of Southern savagery. The only mitigating feature is that it is a record which must soon be closed. The strong grip of SHERMAN will be on the conspirators before many more days shall have elapsed, and we shall witness a retribution which will make rebeldom quake to its centre.

abstract: Mr. WM. BAER, a consulting agricultural chemist of Maryland, who has had some thirty years' practical experience, will attend the meeting of the Farmers' Club of the American Institute to-day, at 1 1/2 o'clock, at Room No. 24 Cooper Union Building, and will answer all inquiries in relation to the different climates, soils, society and productions of Maryland. Mr. BAER will be happy to meet, in addition to farmers, munufacturers of acles and salts, glass, cast iron, glue and color makers, &c., as he will be able to communicate much valuable information in relation to those subjects Admission free.

The Chairman of the Finance Committee of the Fair Association has just paid over to the Treasurer of the Sanitary Commission the sum of one hundred and seventy-eight thousand one hundred and fifty-one dollars and sixty-eight cents, the affairs of the whilom "institution" being now finally settled up. abstract: Irving Hall was crowded Sunday evening with a most respectable audience, composed in great part of ladies, brought together to listen to appeals made in behalf of the Mission Sunday-Schools, for poor children in this city. The meeting was presided over by Rev. Dr.FERRIS, President of the American ...
lead_paragraph: Irving Hall was crowded Sunday evening with a most respectable audience, composed in great part of ladies, brought together to listen to appeals made in behalf of the Mission Sunday-Schools, for poor children in this city. The meeting was presided over by Rev. Dr.FERRIS, President of the American Sunday-School Union, and able addresses were denvered by Rev. Mr. BOLTON, Rev. H.D. GANSE, WM.E. DODGE, Esq., and Rev. C.S. ROBINSON, D.D. At 7 1/2 o'clock the exercises were opened with prayer, and the reading of the Scriptures by Rev. Dr. FERRIS, after which a choir of about fifty children selected from the various mission schools sang an appropriate hymn, accompanied by a musical professor on the piano. Rev. Mr. BOLTON was then introduced. He narrated his varied experiences as a missionary whose labors had been mostly devoted to the cause of Sunday schools for poor children throughout the city, and made an urgent appeal on their behalf to the sympathies of the auditory. The inadequacy of proper accommodations for establishing these schools he dwelt on at some length, and alluded with much force to the existing and constantly increasing scarcity of teachers, urging all who professed to be followers of the Divine Master, to come forward and aid in this great work. He directed the attention of the wealthy classes to the necessity devolving on them to forward the pious movement by extending "material aid," and called on professional men and those who had capacities and opportunities for imparting religious instruction, to improve the opportunities now presented them in every quarter of the city, to show by their devotion to the cause of poor children, how this they valued the teachings of that Christianity of which they professed themselves the adherents.

abstract: The late order of Gen. DIX, requiring all persons from the rebel States, resident, or arriving in this city, to register their names at the once of Gen. PECK, is to be carried out to the letter. For a few days subsequent to the issuing of the order there was quite a rush of Southern men and women to Gen. PECK'S...
lead_paragraph: The late order of Gen. DIX, requiring all persons from the rebel States, resident, or arriving in this city, to register their names at the once of Gen. PECK, is to be carried out to the letter. For a few days subsequent to the issuing of the order there was quite a rush of Southern men and women to Gen. PECK's office, but lately the applicants have been few and far between, and it was evident that those for whom the order was more especially intended had kept in the background, under the impression, that no steps would be taken to enforce the order, and that after the excitement attending the discovery of the plot to burn the city had died away they would be left to resume their disloyal schemes unmolested.

abstract: The Crayon Art Gallery, No. 756 Broadway, contains at the present moment an unusually fine collection of Dusseldorf pictures -- the finest, in many respects, that has ever been seen in this country. There are works by Carl Hueoner, F.S. Lachenwitz, Von Wille, Lot, Von Franken, Kels, Becker, Aloys Schmidt, and other well-known names. The exhibition is free, and we know of no better place where an hour can be pleasantly and profitably passed. We shall take an early opportunity of speaking in detail of many of the important pictures.

abstract: Sec of Navy, Report; Abstract of Report; Report
snippet: Sec of Navy, Report; Abstract of Report; Report
lead_paragraph: The report of the Secretary of the Navy opens with a statement of the measures adopted by the present Administration, on first coming into power, to create a navy adequate to the requirements of the blockade of over three thousand miles of coast. Foreign squadrons were recalled, new vessels were built, the merchant service was called upon for steamers available as war vessels, the capacity of our navy yards was increased, the foundries and workshops of the country were put in requisition for supplies of ordnance and machinery, the number of seamen was greatly augmented, and the deficiency of officers supplied by judicious selections of experienced shipmasters from the commercial marine. The Secretary dwells upon the results of these labors, as represented by the stringent blockade of the Southern coast, and the victories achieved by STRINGHAM, DUPONT and FARRAGUT. He also refers in terms of eulogy to the exploits of our navy on the Mississippi and other inland waters, which are now patrolled by a fleet of more than one hundred vessels. The Secretary states that it has always been the policy of the department never to permit the efficiency of the blockade to be impaired. Hence no large squadrons have been maintained on foreign stations. Cruisers have been sent out from time to time, to protect American shipping, and to watch the predatory vessels of the rebels.

abstract: Postmaster-General Dennison's Report; Report
lead_paragraph: -- The report of the Postmaster-General, which we lay before our readers this morning, is, in its most essential features, a satisfactory record of the operations of the department for the year. Its brevity is altogether commendable. The public want the facts, being, usually, able to supply the rhetoric for themselves. Gov. DENNISON has seized manfully on this truth, and the consequence is an admirable compendium of appreciable facts. The department stands well financially. It shows an apparent deficit of only two hundred odd thousand dollars, against seven millions in the times of JAMES BUCHANAN. But even this deficit of two hundred thousand dollars would be wiped out were the department not burdened with the franking system. If Gov. DENNISON took credit for the Congressional vote which is supposed to commute the franks, he would have half a million on hand after paying all his debts. And these financial results have been reached at a crisis when the cost of mail carriage, the price of labor, and all that enters into the outlay of the Department, have enormously increased, -- with no increase whatever in the rates of postage. The extraordinary fact, moreover, is presented in the report, that the department got nearly four millions more money during the year than it had estimated, at the same time that the miles of travel for the year had increased by over eighty thousand.

abstract: The Secretary of the Navy asks credit, and we think it may be given to him, considering how much money he might have spent in his department, for having disbursed in the last three and a half years, for men-of-war, iron-clad and wood rams, monitors, speculative naval abortions, munitions, provisioning, refitting, salaries, and so forth, a sum of only two hundred and thirty-eight odd millions. For this outlay the Secretary shows to-day 671 craft of most promiscuous character and quality, and over 50,000 seamen. The Secretary has a gross tonnage for his money of 510,396 tons, and he has 4,610 guns. Besides this, he has been capturing blockade-runners at a rate exceeding one a day for the last three and a half years -- 1,379 in all -- of a gross value exceeding $14,000,000.

abstract: Sec. Fessenden's Annual Report
lead_paragraph: In presenting to Congress his annual report on the state of the finances, in obedience to the requirements of law, the Secretary of the Treasury feels that, while there is no occasion to distrust the ability of the people of the United States to bear the great and increasing burdens imposed upon them by the arduous and prolonged struggle for national existence in which they are engaged, there is nevertheless much in the financial condition of the Government which requires careful and anxious consideration. Among the serious duties devolved upon him, the Secretary recognizes a full and clear exposition of that condition as first in importance, in order that the wisdom of Congress may provide a remedy for existing evils, and guard against the recurrence of similar evils in the future. The Secretary's assumption of office was so nearly coincident with the commencement of the present fiscal year, that he would be naturally impelled to begin by stating the exact condition of the Treasury upon that day. Before proceeding to do so, however, a brief review of the financial measures adopted since the outbreak of the rebellion, and of their operation and effect, may not be without value in endeavoring to arrive at just conclusions with regard to the future.

abstract: AMERICAN AND FOREIGN BIBLE SOCIETY. The stated meeting of the managers' of this society was held on Thursday, the 1st inst., at the rooms No. 116 Nassau-street. Rev. Dr. HISCOX, President of the Board, in the chair, assisted by LISPENARD STEWART, Esq., one of the Vice-Presidents of the Board.
lead_paragraph: AMERICAN AND FOREIGN BIBLE SOCIETY. -- The stated meeting of the managers' of this society was held on Thursday, the 1st inst., at the rooms No. 116 Nassau-street. Rev. Dr. HISCOX, President of the Board, in the chair, assisted by LISPENARD STEWART, Esq., one of the Vice-Presidents of the Board. The various reports presented as to the state of the treasury, and economy in the transaction of business, and the present condition of the society were most favorable and encouraging. Grants of Scriptures were made in answer to applications from Virginia, Pennsylvania, Missouri, Kansas, Wisconsin, Illinois, Minnesota, New-York, New-Jersey and District of Columbia. The circulation of the Scriptures among our soldiers and sailors, among freedmen at the South, in prisons and hospitals, was reported as largely on the increase. Two hundred dollars was ordered to be sent to Rev. Mr. GOBLE, now in Japan, to aid in publishing Scriptures in the Japanese language, and $1,000 to Rev. Mr. CROSS, for Burmese Scriptures. The board also voted, upon recommendation of a committee previously appointed, to take immediate measures for the establishment of a Bible press in Burmah. India, which shall be the property of the society, and under its exclusive control. In connection with this, it was directed that a special fund of several thousand dollars should be raised without delay for the purchase and equipment of one or more presses for Bible printing in that far-off country. The attendance of members was large, and the meeting deeply interesting.

lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. LANE, of Indiana, introduced a bill, which was ordered to be referred to the Judiciary Committee, to authorize the holding of a special session of the United States District Court of Indiana. The President pro tem, laid before the Senate a communication from Gov. HAHN, of Louisiana, relative to the Senators from that State. Mr. POWELL, of Kentucky, offered a resolution that the Secretary of War be requested, if not incompatible with the public interest, to communicate to the Senate a report of the proceedings of the court-martial appointed to investigate the conduct of Gen. E.A. PAYNE, while commanding at Padu???, Ky. The resolution was ordered to lie upon the table until the announcement of the committees. Mr. MORGAN, of New-York, presented the credentials of the Senators elect from Louisiana proposing to refer the papers to a committee. Mr. WADE moved that all documents relating to the subject be printed. The President pro tem??? presented to the Senate copies of the laws of the Territory of Nebraska. An adjournment then took place.

abstract: Guide in the Southwest; Report of
snippet: Guide in the Southwest; Report of
lead_paragraph: The report of the Chief of the Bureau of Ordnance opens with a statement of the increase in the number of guns for the navy during the year ending Nov. 1, 1864. The work of fabricating cannon has steadily progressed during this period of time, and 1,522 guns of the different calibre were added to the grand total. Few guns have been surrendered or abandoned to the enemy; nearly all the losses have been by the inevitable accidents of battle, as in The case of ??? and Commodore Jones. In the grand total should be added seven 10-inch solid-shot guns and three 13-incn Dahlgren gun. Thers are in process of fabrication a new class of 32-pounders and 8-inch smooth-bore guns, for the broad sides at ???: vessels. In regard to the composition of batteries, the general rule in arming our ships of war has been to place on board of them the very heaviest and most effective guns they can bear with safety. Nine-inch guns are generally used for broadside; 10-inch and 11-inch and the Parrou guns in pivot, the 15-inch for the monitor turrets, and the bronze howitzers and rifles for ???oat and deck service in shore. The efficiency of co???nc heavy pivot guns with broadside guns has been fully established. Whether a battery consisting entirely of heavy pivot guns would be more ???ormidable than one of broadside alone, the aggregate weights being equal, has not yet been tried, the only effort of the kind being that of the Niagara, which has a battery of twelve 150-pounder rifles mounted in pivot, and no regular broadside guns. The decisive power of the heavy gun in pivot was strikingly exemplified in the fight between the Kear??? and the Alabama.

abstract: Message; Correction on Public Debt; Fessenden's Sec Treasury Report
snippet: Message; Correction on Public Debt; Fessenden's Sec Treasury Report
lead_paragraph: Secretary FESSENDEN acquits himself with marked credit in his first formal report to Congress. He has grapsed the financial situation with the ability of a business-like statesman, and the candor and plainness of his statements certainly imply more experience in his new and difficult office than a brief practical administration of its vast figures and complicated and embarassing duties of only five months service imply. He manifests no disposition to over-estimate the resources of the country to supply the sinews of war, ample as they confessedly are, but at the same time does justice to their intrinsic and increasing magnitude, and is not slow to appreciate the readiness of the people to bear the burden of the public debt. If Congress should, as promptly, show an equal confidence, we have reason to hope that the Secretary's estimates of the amount to be raised in the next year and a half, by loan, in place of taxation, will be materially lessened. From the experience of the past three years, on the other hand, and the merchant-like budget of the present report, we have no ground to think that these estimates will be materially, if at all, exceeded.

abstract: The latest news from Nashville still represents the two armies of THOMAS and HOOD confronting each other south of that city. The rebels seem to be vigorously engaged in planting batteries and throwing up earthworks. On Tuesday Gen. HOOD sent in a flag of truce to Gen. THOMAS ...
lead_paragraph: The latest news from Nashville still represents the two armies of THOMAS and HOOD confronting each other south of that city. The rebels seem to be vigorously engaged in planting batteries and throwing up earthworks. On Tuesday Gen. HOOD sent in a flag of truce to Gen. THOMAS conveying a proposition to exchange prisoners. Gen. THOMAS responded that the prisoners he had captured had passed beyond his hands, and he could not, therefore, comply with his request. On the same day a body of rebels attacked block-house six and seven, near Murfreesboro. They were gallantly fought by the garrison, and soon a body of troops was sent by Gen. MILROY, from Murfreesboro, who attacked the rebels with such effect that they were driven off in confusion, losing six pieces of artillery and a number of prisoners. One brigade of white and another of colored troops, which garrisoned Johnsonville prior to its evacuation, and which were cut off from the main army when Gen. SCHOFIELD fell back from Franklin, have reached Clarkesville in safety.

abstract: Chief Justice; Appointment; How Received
lead_paragraph: The appointment of SALMON P. CHASE to the Chief-Justiceship of the Supreme Court gives very general satisfaction. Even his political opponents -- those of course excepted whose judgment is palsied by old prejudice -- cheerfully concede' that the President could have made no better selection. We can recall no Instance of one transferred from the political arena to the Supreme Bench with so little animadversion. It is a remarkable contrast to the storm of wrath raised by Gen. JACKSON's appointment of his immediate predecessor.

abstract: The Enrollment for; Report; Boundary Question, the
snippet: The Enrollment for; Report; Boundary Question, the
lead_paragraph: In the brief note which our space yesterday enabled us to make on the report of the Navy Department, we could only point to the general results in the most summary form. The Secretary, we think, might, without serious loss, have rested his case where we left it. But those who think otherwise may consult the report at length. It will be found, in all its integrity of rhetoric and of logic, to be the most formidable State paper of modern times. We give up some nine columns of our space to its reproduction this morning, not without some misgivings that even herein we fail of doing it complete justice.

abstract: Post, Gerardus, of N Y
lead_paragraph: The bar of New-York has met with a loss in the death of one of its youngest but most promising members, GERARDUS Post, Esq., of this city. Mr. Post graduated at Columbia College in the Class of 1862, and immediately entered the law school of the college, from which he received a diploma as Bachelor of Laws, and the prize medal for superior proficiency in legal acquirements. He was subsequently admitted to the bar, and commenced the practice of his profession in this city. He died on the outset of a career of brilliant promise, in the morning of a life devoted to a profession which would have been honored by his name. His studious nature, his finished scholarship, his high aims and love for his profession, led those who knew him to look upon him as one destined to occupy an eminent position at the bar, and deepen their sorrow for his unexpected loss.

abstract: Trial for Assault
lead_paragraph: The people vs. Luther C. Tibbetts. -- The prisoner in this case was indicted in March last for assaulting the Janitor of the Produce Exchange with a knife, and inflicting upon him a dangerous wound. A. OAKEY HALL, Esq., District Attorney, appeared for the people, and in opening the case stated that this prosecution differed from most of the cases brought in criminal courts, in this, that it was a case actually brought by the people, the Grand Jury having found the indictment of their own volition, without the usual complaint from the individual who had been wronged. The first witness called was Mr. Vanderbilt, the Janitor of the Exchange, who testified that on the 8th of February last, Tibbetts presented himself at the entrance of the room used by the Exchange Board, and attempted to enter. Tibbetts and previously been suspended by the board from membership, and the janitor had been instructed to exclude him from the room. Prisoner had in his hands some paper boxes, containing samples of corn. As prisoner was about to eater, witness stepped up to him, and was about to speak t0 him. raising his hand at the same time. Tibbetts instantly dropped his sample boxes, put his hand into his pocket, drew out some sharp instrument, and stabbed witness in the shoulder and left side. Witness was unable to see what Kind of an instrument Tibbetts had in his hand, but subsequently saw him on a table in the room brandishing what appeared to be a knife. A knife was afterwards picked up on the floor and given to the witness. In his cross-examination ???tness stated that the wound was a slight one that Mr. Tibbetts appeared to be exc??? ??? ??? quick in his mi???fons, Had ne???tner said anything to Mr. Tibbetts before the stab???ing. Had never seen any dough or corn thrown ???t Mr. Tibbetts at the Exchange, before this occ???rence. The members occasionally did such things in lest among themselves.

abstract: Emperor Maximilian; Letter to his Secretary of State
snippet: Emperor Maximilian; Letter to his Secretary of State
lead_paragraph: MY DEAR MINISTER VELASQUEZ DE LEON: On returning from my laborious journey into the departments of the interior, during which I have received, in every city, town and village, the sincerest proofs of sympathy and the most cordial enthusiasm, I have derived two important truths. The first is, that the Empire is a fact firmly based upon the firm will of the immense majority of the nation, and that in it there is depicted a form of Government of real progress, and one that suits best the wants of the people. The second is, mat this immense majority is desirous of peace, tranquility and justice; blessings that it expects and anxiously asks of my Government, and which I, keeping In view my sacred duties to God and the people who have chosen me, am resolved to give them.

abstract: Gold Bill; Speculation and Public Credit; Stevens' bill
snippet: Gold Bill; Speculation and Public Credit; Stevens' bill
lead_paragraph: Mr. THAD, STEVENS' extraordinary bills, prohibiting the exportation of specie, and forcing the public to take Government paper at par value, have been extinguished; but it is very little to the credit of Congress that they should, after the experience of last year, to say nothing of any other consideration, have been referred to a committee, and that they should not have been thrown overboard till the rise in cold in New-York reminded everybody of their folly. "What is, however, more extraordinary than this, is that there should have been fifty-two members found to vote against their rejection. It only proves what a large number of gentlemen persist, in spite of the gravity of the crisis, in sitting, speaking and voting in Congress, without bestowing on the questions before them either study or reflection.

abstract: March; Topography of Georgia; Topography of; Sherman's March; Interior, Secretary of, Report; Report of
snippet: March; Topography of Georgia; Topography of; Sherman's March; Interior, Secretary of, Report; Report of
lead_paragraph: It will be seen that the Richmond Examiner of Tuesday last rather facetiously remarks that "If the Lieutenant-General (GRANT) has already sent to Hon. E. M. STANTON the information which we (the Examiner) communicated to him on yesterday, that SHERMAN had passed by Millen, we hope he will be fair to that statesman, and send another dispatch, stating how the Richmond Examiner now denies that SHERMAN's army had passed by Millen. This it does positively," from information furnished by the Confederate Government. We suppose, therefore, that in this case and on this matter we must credit the Richmond Examiner and the Confederate Government, and believe that Millen, which is 80 miles from Savannah, was not captured by Gen. SHERMAN up to Monday night or Tuesday morning of the current week.

abstract: Lyons, Lord; Retirement of from Washington Embassy
snippet: Lyons, Lord; Retirement of from Washington Embassy
lead_paragraph: We presume that no one outside of the circle of Southern sympathizers in New-York even feigns to believe that Lord LYONS has retired from his mission from any motive arising out of the relations of the two countries. Nearly twelve months ago Lord LYONS, feeling the approach of the disease from which it is feared he is a hopeless sufferer, asked to be relieved. And we learned that he then expressed, informally, the wish that some one who had become familiarized with the existing crisis by a residence here, should be his successor. This suggestion would naturally point to some late or present member of the Legation at Washington as the probable successor. Lord LYONS' personal desire was unquestionably in favor of maintaining the same friendly relations that characterized his own incumbency as British Minister. And it was natural that he should look with special hopefulness on the appointment of some one that had graduated under his own teaching. It has been reported in tolerably well informed circles that the Hon. WILLIAM STUART was indicated in Lord LYONS' suggestions. Mr. STUART is a traveled man. He comes of a good, sound, Scotch stock; and he is neither a snob nor a fool. The appointment -- if it should happen to be made -- would be highly acceptable.
headline: {'main': 'LORD LYONS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'LORD LYONS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. DAVIS, of Kentucky, gave notice that he would introduce a joint resolution for the restoration of the Union and ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. DAVIS, of Kentucky, gave notice that he would introduce a joint resolution for the restoration of the Union and peace, and for the vindication of the Constitution, and the guarantee of the rights of the citizens of the several States. On motion of Mr. ANTHONY, of Rh???de Island, the rules which require the election of standing committees by ballot were suspended. The committees were then reported and agreed to. Mr. POWELL, of Kentucky, then moved the consideration of the resolutions introduced by him, calling for an investigation into the conduct of Gen. PAYNE. After a brief debate, without taking action in the matter, the Senate adjourned until Monday.

abstract: The Richmond papers of the 6th, and Augusta (Ga.) papers of the 2d, furnish us with some important information from Gen. SHERMAN. From their statements, it would seem that SHERMAN'S army, on the 4th inst., was between the Ogeechee and the Savannah Rivers, in the ...
lead_paragraph: The Richmond papers of the 6th, and Augusta (Ga.) papers of the 2d, furnish us with some important information from Gen. SHERMAN. From their statements, it would seem that SHERMAN'S army, on the 4th inst., was between the Ogeechee and the Savannah Rivers, in the neighborhood of Millen, and evidently moving upon Savannah. The rebels report e considerable fight on Sunday, the 4th, between the rebel cavalry under Wheeler and our cavalry under KILPATRICK. The latter officer is reported to be wounded, but that is merely a rebel surmise. The rebels, of course, claim the advrntage, but they have been regularly whipping this same KILPATRICK ever since he left Atlanta, and yet he has pushed the rebels back to the Savannah river. The rebels predict a heavy battle north of Savannah this Week. If it occurs some of the rebel bombast with which we have been regaled for three weeks will be exploded, and we shall have direct news from Sherman.

abstract: The County Volunteer Committee have commenced the great and Important work of revising the enrolment???lists of persons liable to draft in New-York County. They have hired the first and fourth floors of the large building No.73 Duane-st., where nearly four hundred clerks are employed in transcribing the records of the District Provost. Marshals, when this work is done the work of correcting them will begin, and every offort will be made by the committee to make the revised enrollment as near perfect as possible, but their success depends in a great measure upon the hearty cooperation of the citizens of New-York. Whether a draft is impending or not every man, woman and child in the county has a deep interest in this movement, which, when carried through, will give to the authorities a new basis for declaring the quota of the county. Private interests and public justice require that it should be done thoroughly and well, that in case a call is made New-York may furnish her just share of the men required, but no more. The committee desire every person knowing himself to De exempt to go to the Provost-Marshal of his district, state his cause of exemption, prodnce his proofs, and have his name stricken from the list. It will be very little trouble to any man to do this; it can be done much quicker and easier than after a draft, and it is an act of justice to one's neighbors. Any person who knows that any enrolled man is exempt, should hand in the name and the probable cause of exemption to the Provost-Marshal of the district in which the exempt lives, and the committee will then send and obtain the proper proofs required to make the correction. This is not Informing of a friend, but is in reality doing him a kindness.

lead_paragraph: AID FOR THE FREEDMEN. -- A large number of valuable contributions have recently been received from the Society of Friends in England by the National Freedmen's Association that has its office at No.1 and 3 Mercer-street. The following is a list of packages, which came by the steamship Edinburgh, according to the invoice: 1 crate clothing, 1 bale clothing, 1 box clothing, 1 box clothing, 1 box clothing, 1 cask clothing, 1 bale clothing, 1 cask clothing, 1 box clothing, 1 bale clothing, 1 chest books, 1 cask shoes, 1 box new clothing, 2 boxes clothing and ???oys, 8 casks clothing and boots, 1 bale clothing, 1 box clothing, 1 bale 80 yards black cloth, 1 cask clothing and sundries, 1 box clothing and sundries, 1 box clothing and some books, 1 cask boots with laces, 1 cask spoons, pins, fancy buttons, toys, pens, 1 cask netting, pios, buttons, spectacles, beads, worsted, &c., 1 tierce clothing, and new and second-hand material for clothing, 1 box fleecy hosiery, and 7 hats. There are also fifteen boxes, bales, crates and other packages of goods -- all of excellent duality.

lead_paragraph: COMMISSION. -- A committee of responsible citizens, appointed by the United States Sanitary Commission, have made a formal report upon the financial condition of that organization. abstract: We learn from Washington, where Gen. HANCOCK has his headquarters, that enlistments in the new First Veteran Army Corps are progressing favorably. The order of the War Department for the organization of the corps provided that it should consist of twenty thousand men, who had already served honorably not less than two years, and that enlistments should commence on the 1st day of December, and continue until the first day of January next. It will thus be seen that, to be up to time, enlistments should average about six hundred and fifty men per day. We should think that, taking the whole country over, and considering the large number of men there are of the class referred to, and the great inducements offered, and the short term of service required, that this number might easily be reached. There is a liberal bounty of three hundred dollars to the volunteer, payable on being mustered in, and only one year of service.

abstract: Capt. CROPPER, of the steamer Wyoming, which vessel left City Point yesterday morning and arrived here at midnight, reports that when passing Day's Point on the James River, at about 10 P.M., he observed two schooners aground on the shoal, one of which was on fire. After proceeding on his course down the river a short time, he looked back and discovered another vessel, which he took to be the second schooner, ablaze.
lead_paragraph: FORTRESS MONROE, Wednesday, Dec. 7, 1864.

abstract: The hour is coming -- and it is a fearful and solemn hour, even to the wisest and the best -- when we must bid adieu to the scenes which please us, to the families we love, to the friends we esteem. Whether we think, or whether we think not, that body, which is warm and active with life, shall be cold and motionless with death. The countenance must be pale, the eyes must be closed, the voice must be silenced, the senses must be destroyed, the whose appearance must be changed by the remorseless hand of our last enemy. We may banish the remembrance of the weakness of our human nature; but our reluctance to reflect upon it, and our attempts to drive it from our recollections are in vain. We know that we are sentenced to die; and though we sometimes succeed in casting off for a season the conviction of this unwelcome truth, we can never entirely remove it. The reflection haunts us still; it lies down with us at night, it awakes with us in the morning. The irrevocable doom is passed upon us, and too well do we know it. "Dust thou art, and unto dust thou shalt return."

abstract: The rebel papers now keep us pretty well informed of SHERMAN'S movements. According to Richmond papers of the 7th, SHERMAN had rested his army four days in the vicinity of Louisville, thirty miles north of Millen, which is eighty miles north of Savannah. The region where SHERMAN stopped is one of the richest in Georgia.
lead_paragraph: The rebel papers now keep us pretty well informed of SHERMAN'S movements. According to Richmond papers of the 7th, SHERMAN had rested his army four days in the vicinity of Louisville, thirty miles north of Millen, which is eighty miles north of Savannah. The region where SHERMAN stopped is one of the richest in Georgia. Richmond, Glasscock and Jefferson Counties abound in provisions and forage, and the Richmond papers say that SHERMAN was busily engaged in gathering a full supply. On the 2d inst., he had passed Millen, and at the rate he had been moving he would be before Savannah by yesterday or sooner. From the tremulous tone of the rebel reports, it is evident they have no positive faith in their ability to hold the city against such an attack as SHERMAN's invicible army will make.

snippet: Emily Chester; Ward's Letters of Samuel Curwen; Reid, Capt; Ocean Waifs; Gems from European Picture Galleries; Mowry's Arizona and Sonora; Scott, Lieut-Gen; Autobiography; Encyclopedia Britannica; Treatises on Printing, Gas, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: Though the present is nominally the third edition of this work, it appears by the preface that the two former impressions were brought out in California, and probably scarcely a single stray copy has found its way to the shores of the Atlantic. The book is, therefore, in reality, as new as it is authentic. Lieut, MOWRY is, perhaps, the first living authority on the actual condition and mineral resources California, at the time when the Gadsden purchase was made, which would have brought this region into direct communication with California is much regretted, and has retarded more than any other circumstance the settlement of the Territory. A multitude of facts are adduced to show that the popular impression of the barrenness of Arizona and the neighboring districts are entirely unfounded, and that, though mining industry will always be the first interest, the agircultural resources are very great, and sufficient of themselves to attract the notice of emigrants. From this portion of the United States will undoubtedly be derived a great part of the world's future supply of silver and copper, to say nothing of gold. All who are concerned in knowing the "whereabout" of these attractive commodities must read Lieut. MOWRY's book. It is awkwardly put together, and shows no literary skills in its arrangement, but the facts are there, and will easily be discerned by interested eyes.

abstract: Prof. R.L. Hamilton: Having been prostrated by a severe disease of the lungs, called quick consumption, and having suffered for a number of months without any benefit from the best physicians, you will recollect that I was so much reduced as to be unable to sit up or walk a step, when I began your treatment, and after a short trial of your new remedies, I was soon restored to perfect health, and to-day stand as a living witness, perfectly healthy and free from lung or other disease, and there can be but one possible way to account for this great miracle, and that is by the thorough use of your world-renowned remedies, and after seeing hundreds rescued from the very jaws of death, who were similarly diseased, by your treatment, I shall ever raise a warning voice to save poor mortals from death and misery. I hope all that have doubts of this will write me for information. MISS A.M. WOOD.

abstract: Very much sensation pervaded our business community, yesterday, when it began to be noised about that an officer of Maj.-Gen. DIX's staff was in town, with peremptory orders to arrest a number of our most wealthy and highly esteemed business men, and take possession of their counting-rooms, and the books and papers therein. The order was executed at 10 o'clock, yesterday morning, so far as to seize the counting-rooms and to arrest one of the parties, who was sent on to report to Gen. DIX yesterday afternoon. Other parties sought were out of town, and may have been arrested elsewhere. These persons are charged with "furnishing supplies to the enemy," and the case has something to do with the outfitting of the steamer Ella Warley, (which was run down by the North Star, off Sanoy Hook, many months ago,) and other vessels sent into the Gulf about the same time. Gen. DIX has arrested in New-York a number of persons known to be engaged in nefarious trafficing with the rebels. These persons, it is understood, seek to palliate their detected guilt by implicatting parties in this city who have heretofore stood at the head of the business men of Rhode Island, and whose honor and loyalty have never been challenged. The investigation is not completed, and the authorities deem it proper to withhold the names and details of the case for the present. -- Providence Journal, Dec, 9.

abstract: Mr. Geo. W. Vaughan, of Grand Rapids, Wood Co., WIS., writes: "In the Fall of 1852 I was taken with a severe affection of the kidney and bladder. My strength rapidly gave way to the ravages of my disease, until I was literally nothing but a walking shadow. For the first five years of my disease my water was of a cherry red color. At times substances the size of a bean, resembling clotted blood, would pass off, and at others something resembling coarse sand. My sufferings were well high intolerable. I had taken your medicine only two weeks, when I felt a decided change for the better. In four weeks I had so far regained my strength that I was able to engage in light work; and now (only two months since I commenced the use of your wonderful remedies) I consider myself a well man. It seems it credible, after suffering so long, and doctoring with so many physicians, and paying so much money, that I should be entirely cured in so short a time, and at such a trifling expense; yet such is the case, as all my friends and neighbors can testify. Your practice in this vicinity will be unlimited. Many are astonished at such a wonderful cure, and are daily applying to you for relief. Long may you live to bless your race!"

abstract: James Brannegan, who plead guilty to manslaughter in the fourth degree, was sentenced yesterday to imprisonment for life. The trial of Luther C. Tibbetts for felonious assault on the Janitor of the Produce Exchange was resumed. The evidence being all in the counsel for the prisoner summed up for the defence, followed by Mr. Hall for the People. The case was then submitted to the Jury, who brought in a verdict of guilty of an assault with a deadly weapon with intent to do bodily harm. Mr. Tibbetts has not yet been sentenced, and in the meantime will be permitted to go upon bail.

abstract: Mr. Wm.S. Blakeslee, of Windham Centre, Greene County, N.Y., writes, Jan. 10, 1863: "Five weeks ago my friends thought I was in the last stage of consumption. After taking your medicines for a few days, I began to feel much better, and am now able to be around and attend to my business. I anticipate a permanent cure. I owe everything to you for your great wisdom in treating this disease, that has hitherto been considered incurable."

abstract: The funeral of Dr. RANNEY, who died on Wednesday evening last of typhus fever, a disease he contracted while in the discharge of his duties, and after one of his assistants, Dr. A. FALLS MARVIN, had been carried off by it, took place yesterday morning from Cavalry Church, and was largely attended by his friends and brother physicians, among whom were Collector DRAPER, Commissioners BELL, NICHOLSON ...
lead_paragraph: The funeral of Dr. RANNEY, who died on Wednesday evening last of typhus fever, a disease he contracted while in the discharge of his duties, and after one of his assistants, Dr. A. FALLS MARVIN, had been carried off by it, took place yesterday morning from Cavalry Church, and was largely attended by his friends and brother physicians, among whom were Collector DRAPER, Commissioners BELL, NICHOLSON GRINNEIL, and several members of the New-York Academy of Medicine. Crescent Lodge of the Order of Freemasons, of whom deceased was a member, was also in attendance, and after the funeral service, which was conducted by Rev. Messrs. CRAWLEY, WALKER and PETERS, took charge of the body, which they escorted to the Hudson River Railroad depot en route for Stockbridge, Vt., where they will be interred.

abstract: Wm. McStrong, of North Manchester, Conn., writes: "I am in possession of your circular, in which you propose to cure epilepsy or fits. You have certificates of several persons cured. I wrote to Mr. Freeman, of Detroit, N.Y., in reference to the validity of the statement published by you. He at once answered me, stating the case was as reported, and had proved permanent, there having been no return of the fits up to the present time."

The bilious material is thrown upon the delicate membrane that lines the air passages Irritation, with cough; more or less severe Soreness through the throat, breast, sides, back, or shoulders, or pains of various degrees of severity, and unless something is done immediately to relieve Nature, inflammation will supervene, followed by ulceration, night sweats, cold chills, hectic fever, raising of matter, with perhaps a little blood, diarrhea, sore mouth and throat, &c., which are indications of a powerful effort of Nature to relieve the system of poisonous, bilious material which has fastened itself upon the most delicate and sensitive organ in the human system -- the Lungs and air passages.

abstract: Mrs. L.H. Palmer, of Bedford, Hillsboro County, N.H., in a series of letters under different dates, gives a history of her case, which, as she says, "was so remarkable, that strangers went many miles to see her, the same as they would a great curiosity." "I seem (she writes) to have all the complaints a person can have and live. Indeed, I seem to live but to suffer. I have headache, sore throat, with a general disorganization of the system; am touched with a dry, tight cough, short breath, very costive; have night sweats, and at times afflicted with the piles, which are intolerably painful. Now I suffer with the cold, and again feel burning with heat. I have not had a menstrual discharge in fifteen months: have sharp running pains in my hips and kidneys, and my liver is apparently perfectly torpid and inactive." The medicines needed by Mrs. P. were at once forwarded; and the benefits derived from them is apparent from the following extract from one of her subsequent letters: "Although I had begun to be encouraged by the slight improvement, yet I felt that a crisis was coming -- one which I dare not contemplate. You can imagine my agreeeable surprise, when I passed the critical period with less pain than I ever felt in my life. From that time I began to improve rapidly; nature seems to have been aroused under the magical influence of your remedies; my strength returned; my mind appeared to be relieved of all melancholy, and again the pathway of life opened brightly before me. * * * Only last week I returned to my native place, from whence I was taken years ago on my bed, hardly expected by my friends to reach my journey's end alive. When my old acquaintances saw me returning comparatively well, they could hardly believe that such a miracle could be wrought by medicine; they say it seems "like one raised from the dead," to see me moving round again. As long as I live I shall be a walking advertisement of your truly wonderful healing powers. * * * Words cannot speak my gratitude. Once more I find happiness in living. If I ever succeed in accomplishing any good, I shall attribute it all to you.

abstract: CENTRAL PARK CONTRIBUTIONS -- The Commissioners of the Central Park are almost daily in receipt of donations from persons interested in the progress of the great work under their charge. A group of figures representing "Auld Lang Syne," the work of a Scotch artist, has been presented by a number of gentlemen, residents of this city. The following animals have been received: From R.C.M. Hoyt, United States Consul at Minatitlan, Mexico, two animals, male and female, known as the Ant Bear. They are very playful and tame, and in their native country roam along the banks of the rivers in droves. From Mrs. Roosevelt, eight splendid Bantams; from Geo. R. Brooks, three English Rabbits; from D.G. Piper, one Hawk; from Gen. As-both, one Florida Black Bear; from Alex. M.C. Stetson, two Guinea Pigs; from T.F. Trenor, two Blue-jays and one Robin; from Miss Bessie Greenfield, one Grey Squirrel.

abstract: in Southern Georgia
lead_paragraph: We have news of SHERMAN'S army from Richmond papers of as late a date as Wednesday. It confirms the accounts we had yesterday of the march of SHERMAN toward Savannah, along the narrow strip of country that lies between the Ogechee and Savannah Rivers. The formation of this stretch of land is peculiar there being extensive and continuous marshes along the banks of both rivers, with an elevated ridge of land running about equidistant between them. Thus while our troops march along the ridge, both their flanks are protected by the marshes. It was given out, last Saturday, that Lieut.-Gen. GRANT calculated SHERMAN would reach the seaboard by that day; and now the Richmond editors calculate that he will reach Savannah today. GRANT's calculation was not far from accurate, or at least would not have been, had SHERMAN marched without stoppage; but it seems by rebel accounts that he halted his army for four days at Louisville, a little place about 110 miles from the seaboard, in order to gather in such forage and supplies as he required. The rebels still proclaim that he will have a fight before he gets Savannah. We suppose it likely that when, they found he had passed by Augusta without assailing it, they removed the troops which had been hastily gathered there, under Gen. BRAGG, WADE HAMPTON and the local Militia Generals, and hastened them forward by the railroad to Charleston and thence to Savannah, to confront SHERMAN. Beside the officers we have mentioned, there are at Savannah Messrs. HARDEE, DICK TAYLOR and GUSTAVUS W. SMITH. It is not unlikely that the troops under COBB, whom SHERMAN found at MACON, have been running a race to reach Savannah before our forces. They could take railroad from Macon as far as Loyola, and thence march to the Southern Georgia road, which would carry them to Savannah. In the meantime, we have not heard a word lately of BEAUREGARD, who announced to the people of Georgia, twenty-two days ago, that he was hastening to their relief. We should think that with BEAUREGARD, COBB, BRAGG, HARDEE, SMITH, TAYLOR, HAMPTON, WAYNE, WHEELER, and the score of other great Confederate Generals, who are gathered together to stop SHERMAN's march, they would make some strenuous efforts to prevent his getting into Savannah. We hope they will soon let us know what success they meet with.

abstract: A telegram from Shanghai of October 9, says: Prince NAGATO has ageed to open the Straits of Simonosatti, not to rebuild the demolished forts, and to pay the expenses of the allied expedition. The British merchants have addressed Sir R. ALCOCK, calling attention to the violation of the treaty in the stoppage of the silk trade by the Japanese authorities.

abstract: Seward's Rebuke of Lord Wharncliffe; Independence Association; Impertinent Petition of; Impertinence--Seward-Wharncliffe Cor
snippet: Seward's Rebuke of Lord Wharncliffe; Independence Association; Impertinent Petition of; Impertinence--Seward-Wharncliffe Cor
lead_paragraph: Mr. SEWARD'S dispatch, published in our last issue, in reference to the application of Lord WHARNCLIFFE for permission to aid the rebel prisoners in our hands, is pat to the purpose. It hits this new malapertness point blank. Lord WHARNCLIFFE, is told that these prisoners are suffering no privations that need relief that, if it were so, the American Government has the ability to furnish such relief -- that his funds in hand, ostensibly profferred in the name of humanity, came in no small part from profits made by furnishing the rebels with arms and munitions of war to take our lives, and in exchange for the products of the toil of slaves; and it is added that even the rebels themselves probably have yet American spirit enough to rejoice in being saved from the gross insult of this last officious intervention in our domestic affairs.

The general news from the Continent is unimportant.

abstract: Having long and lavorably known Prof. R. Leonidas Hamilton, M.D., (formerly a partner in the practice of medicine with a brothor of mine,) it gives me pleasure to recommend him as a learned and skillful physician. He has, by means of his new theories and remedies, been eminently successful in the treatment of all liver, blood and other chronic diseases of a lingering and obstinate character. Dr. H. is a man perfectly reliable, and of strict integrity. F. JAMES FITCH, County Judge of Greene County.

abstract: Mr. Jacob C. Mateer, of Shellsburgh, Benton County, Iowa, writes: "This is to inform you that I am doing all I can for you in circulating the papers you sent me among the sick, and think it no hardship to spread your fame, and the wonderful cures you have performed, throughout the land, for I was at your mercy and you saved my life; and, therefore, if there is anything I can do for you, it will be done with the greatest pleasure. I want you to send me all the circulars and papers you can to distribute among the sick about here, May God give you a long life on earth."

abstract: Mrs. Caroline M. Romney, of Mantua, Portage County, Ohio, writes: "I placed great confidence in your medicines, and am not disappointed, for their effects are more than satisfactory. I have taken one-half the package you sent me, and am better in every respect. I think another small package will cure me. It seems almost incredible that your medicines should affect me so beneficially in such a short time. Would that I could sound your praise through the length and breadth of the land. May God bless you!"

abstract: Guildenfuss Extradition Case
lead_paragraph: Yesterday the Consul-General of Prussia, JOHN WILLIAN SCHMIDT, and the representatives in this country of the institutions in Prussia which have sustained losses by the alleged forgeries of ERNST GULDENFUSS, alias GIRARD, appeared before United States Commissioner WHITE as witnesses in the action for the extradition of GUELDENFUSS. The prisoner since his arrest in Troy a few days since has been kept in confinement in this city, awaiting an examination of his case. It would seem, from his own confession, there is but little doubt of his guilt, and the question of his rendition to the Prussian authorities turns only upon technicalities of law.

abstract: Caleb B. Heath, a well-known citizen of Glen's Falls, N.Y., writes; "I was afflicted with a very severe cough, which was rapidly undermining my health and weakening my lungs, and was so failing that my friends began to think my recovery doubtful, having tried several kinds of remedies without relief. By the recommendation of a friend I was induced to try your treatment. I did so, and with pleasure can inform you that one course completed the cure. I consider your remedies invaluable, and do not feel disposed to be without a supply on hand."

abstract: It affords us pleasure to place before the public the following statement of Mrs. Jennie Duncan, a highly respectable lady residing at Bargettstown, Washington County, Penn. Such a testimonial, emanating from a source so worthy; is deserving of a careful perusal: "I not only claim it a privilege, but consider it a duty I owe my fellow-mortals, to tell them what the valuable remedies of Dr. HAMILTON have done for me. It is hoped that some doubting, suffering mortal will, through the perusal of this, be led to apply to those who deservedly rank "honorable as men and scientific as physicians." For some eight or ten years previous to April, 1862, I suffered severely from a pain in my back, underneath the right shoulder-blade, sometimes extending into the right side. When my side thus ached I could not bear an article of clothing fastened around me. I had headache constantly, palpitation of heart, and was so very nervous that a strange footstep, or an unusual noise, would startle me, and cause me to tremble like a leaf, my heart beating audibly. But the most horrible of all my sufferings was a smothering sensation -- I could not get my breath. Oftentimes I have started from my bed and ran to an open window for relief. Indeed I was often afraid to lay my head upon the pillow lest I should smother. All the temporary relief I could get from this feeling was in being bled, and my blood was so thick and black that it would not run a drop unless placed in hot water. These, with many other allments, rendered me truly a miserable being. During this time I was running up heavy bils with eminent physicians. I had swallowed enough medicine to fill one corner of a drug-store, (at least so it seemed to me.) My back was blistered, plastered, cupped, and cold water applied, until I was heartily tired of it. Yet the pain was there, and there it would stay. About this time I was handed a paper containing the theory of Professor Hamilton's new mode of treatment. It seemed reasonable, and was corroborated by so many "Testimonials" that, although discouraged, I was induced to try it. I sent them a statement of my case, and in due time received their terms and diagnosis of my case. I inclosed the requisite fee, and received a course of their treatment. Before I had been under it two weeks I was relieved. No palpitation of heart, no smothering sensation, no headache. Improved appetite, sweet and refreshing sleep. I advise, day entreat, all those afflicted, especially those whose symptoms are similar to those enumerated in my case, to at once apply to Dr. Hamilton and ???e relief."

abstract: A telegram from Berlin, of Nov. 21, says: Lord NAPIER had an audience of the King to-day, and presented his credentials as British Ambassador to the Prussian Court. His Excellency afterwards visited HERR VON BISMARK. Count KAROLYI has also been received by the King. The official Staatsanzeiger contradicts a leading article respecting the Federal execution in Holstein, published by the Nord Deutsche Allgemeine Zeitung.
lead_paragraph: A telegram from Berlin, of Nov. 21, says: Lord NAPIER had an audience of the King to-day, and presented his credentials as British Ambassador to the Prussian Court. abstract: London Herald on President Lincoln's Reelection; Florida Case; French Press on
snippet: London Herald on President Lincoln's Reelection; Florida Case; French Press on
lead_paragraph: We hail the result mainly because it is a triumph of the anti-slavery principles which the English people have long professed, and which have now been proclaimed by a popular vote to be the only principles upon which the Government of the United States can be conducted. Slavery in that great country dies hard.***Mr. LINCOLN has been elected by a party, which declares that slavery shall be extirpated, and they have returned to Congress the requisite two-thirds majority to carry the proposed amendment of the Constitution prohibiting slavery forever on the soil of the United Slates. The war must now continue, as it would have done under the Presidency of MCCLELLAN, but for higher and nobler purposes. It is for no more perpetuation or restoration of the Union, with all the enormities of slave-breeding, Slave-trading, and slave labor which formerly shocked humanity. The rebellion will doubtless be subdued, and in place of the fire and sword which usually follow in the track of conquest, the South will gain the blessings of tree labor, the crack of the slavedrivers whip will cease throughout the land, and under the benign influence of completed emancipation the Southern people will reap a prosperity of which they had scarcely dared to dream. Even, for results so conspicuously great as these the Northern western would not have been justified in ??? the ??? an aggressive war, but since the South chase the weapon and the combat, and sought to trample under foot alike the constitutional lights and to destroy the most cherished privileges of the people of the North, they would have been false to themselves and humanity had they not resolved to smite slavery -- that master spirit of civil discord and social wrong -- to the earth, so that the Republic might never more be subject to its malignant influence. Mr. LINCOLN has undoubtedly deserved well of his country. Few men could have grasped the helm with so firm a grasp during a civil conflict so appalling as that which now rates. He is, it is true, neither distinguished by hereditary descent nor by personal accomplishments; he was a bargeman and a day-laborer, and slowly rose to be a provincial lawyer by dint of those qualities of perseverance and clearness of intellect which have been conspicuously displayed during the last four years. He has been caricatured in this country by pen and pencil in a style reflecting disgrace upon the caricaturists, but which has failed to shake the popular belled in the thorough honesty of his character, the sincerity of his love of freedom, and the humanity of his disposition. His policy toward this country has been characterized by the utmost frankness and the strongest desire for peace, and no statesman worthy of conducting the affairs of this country but must be convinced that our best allies on the American continent are men professing the principles which ABRAHAM LINCOLN avows, and in consonance with which he has auther to directed the foreign policy of the Republic.

abstract: Maximilian and the Mexicans
lead_paragraph: MAXIMILIAN has completed his tour through the provinces of his Empire, and has once more established himself in its Capital. The reception which he met with during his travels, has inspired him with confidence and audacity. While away, his Majesty became cognizant of two important facts, of which, we presume, he would have remained ignorant had he not gone. The first is, that "the Empire is firmly based on the firm will of the immense majority of the nation:" the second, that "that immense majority is desirous of peace, tranquillity and justice. "These discoveries have convinced MAXIMILIAN not only that he is securely seated on his throne, but that it is his duty to confer on the Mexicans those blessings which they so ardently yearn for. Yet how can "peace, tranquillity and justice" be reestablished in his dominions, if those wretched incendiaries who still persist in standing up for republicanism, liberty and autonomy, are not put down? Hitherto the Emperor has shown that forbearance toward them that honorable adversaries are entitled, to, but now the Emperor declares that he will keep terms with them no longer, and that henceforward all bands of armed men infesting the country shall be regarded and treated as banitti; which means that they are to be tried by court-martial and shot, or hung, within twenty-four hours after sentence. This mode of dealing with gangs of robbers is, of course, well enough; but it seems rather premature for: a sovereign that owes his throne to violence and intervention, to doom to the gallows all men found in arms against his authority.
headline: {'main': 'Maximilian and the Mexicans.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Maximilian and the Mexicans.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: London Saturday Review on Loss of American Liberty; London Times; Liberty, Loss of, in America
snippet: London Saturday Review on Loss of American Liberty; London Times; Liberty, Loss of, in America
lead_paragraph: One of the bugbears which continually haunt the English mind in regard to this country, is the dreadful oppression to which personal liberty, and especially the liberty of the press, has been exposed since the beginning of our war. According to the British idea, free citizens are daily snatched away from their peaceful avocations and consigned to the "American Bastille" in Fort Lafayette, without trial or accusation, while any journal that should breathe a word against Mr. SEWARD or Mr. LINCOLN would be at once suppressed at the point of the bayonet!

abstract: Child Killed by at Gloucester, New-Jersey
snippet: Child Killed by at Gloucester, New-Jersey
lead_paragraph: HENRY CAREY, ten years old, who resided at Gloucester. N.J., was attacked by a bloodhound, about a fortnight ago. and was so terribly injured that he died soon after. Accompanying the boy was a small dog, which attacked the savage animal and fought him desperately in defense of the child, but was terribly torn himself. The child was tossed about in the field for some time, spectators supposing it to be a dead animal till they discovered that it was a human being, when they went to the child's rescue. Both ears were torn off. and the scalp entirely taken ??? his head. The flesh was torn from his face, beside inflicting other injuries. -- Trenton Gaz???.

abstract: La Marmoras' Speech on Franco-Italian Convention
snippet: La Marmoras' Speech on Franco-Italian Convention
lead_paragraph: The most important and interesting speech made in the Italian Parliament during the debate on the Franco-Italian Convention, was that of Gen. LA MARMORA, the chief of the new Government. The candid, honest tone of the Premier's address, has inspired the nation with confidence in himself, and in the treaty under consideration. The terms of that treaty were not originally approved by the Minister; he was conscientiously opposed to them from an apprehension that they might tend to mar the work of Italian unity; but when he assumed office, and found the obnoxious instrument already completed and signed, he determined, after mature deliberation, and weighing of the arguments for and against it, to give the provisions thereof his cordial support. However repugnant the said convention may be to ardent patriots, there can be no doubt, argues the General, that it will prove, on the whole, beneficial to Italy. It will remove the French garrison from the Subalpine peninsula, and ultimately leave the solution of the Roman question to the inhabitants of the "Eternal City." The Italian Government and people will faithfully abide by the terms of the convention, and, in the opinion of the Premier, the party in the chamber who suspected that the Emperor NAPOLEON would not do likewise, did his French Majesty great injustice. LA MARMORA assured the House that the Emperor was at heart well disposed toward Italy. True, that personage once entertained doubt, touching the possibility of Italian unity, but now he is convinced that that unity is irrevocable, and accepts it as a virtually accomplished fact. Nor does it become Italians to be unmindful of the important services which NAPOLEON has rendered to their cause. Let it not be forgotten that it was he who promoted the discussion of the Italian question at the Congress of Paris -- that it was he who drove the Austrians out of Lombardy -- that it was he who initiated that great movement which resulted in the expulsion of those petty despots that formerly oppressed them. And, after such evidences of his friendship, is it generous, is it prudent, asks the Premier, to harbor undue distrust of his Majesty's designs? If Italians honestly discharge the obligations which the treaty imposes on them, the French Emperor, continues the Minister, will withdraw his troops from Rome within the period specified, and not only do so, but aid Italy, perhaps with all his moral and diplomatic influence, to recover Venice.
headline: {'main': 'The Italian Premier on the Recent Convention.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Italian Premier on the Recent Convention.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The indications are, that there will be a culmination this week of more than one of the three great campaigns which are now in progress that of SHERMAN in Georgia, that of THOMAS in Tennessee, and that of GRANT in Virginia. Whatever may be the exact point...
lead_paragraph: The indications are, that there will be a culmination this week of more than one of the three great campaigns which are now in progress that of SHERMAN in Georgia, that of THOMAS in Tennessee, and that of GRANT in Virginia. Whatever may be the exact point at which SHERMAN is aiming, there is no doubt that by this time his army is very near to the seaboard, and if it is going to have a serious action with the enemy at all, the event must be close at hand. In Middle Tennessee, again, it would seem as if matters could not remain long in their present state. HOOD is closely menacing the defences of Nashville, while he has planted batteries on the Cumberland River, northwest of the city, and his forces have also been found to the eastward. If he proposes to assault, his opportunity has come, and if he proposes to march into Kentucky, he could not find a better moment, though events may prove he could not have chosen a worse one. Beside the assault on the city, and a movement north of it, there is but one other operation in which he can have any hope -- a march into East Tennessee. If he accomplish neither of these, the rebel campaign will stand confessed a terrible failure and no hope for HOOD in the future. In Virginia, as well as in the far South and Southwest, our columns, this morning, bear witness that activity is again to be the order. The object of the movement begun by Gen. WARREN on our left rear on Wednesday last, has not yet been fully developed, but we shall presently learn its magnitude, bearings and issue.

abstract: On the morning of the 7th, at daylight, the Fifth Corps, with the Third Division of the Second, and the brigades of cavalry, broke camp in the Army of the Potomac, and started south. During the same afternoon they crossed the Notroway River on pontoons, and then took...
lead_paragraph: On the morning of the 7th, at daylight, the Fifth Corps, with the Third Division of the Second, and the brigades of cavalry, broke camp in the Army of the Potomac, and started south. During the same afternoon they crossed the Notroway River on pontoons, and then took them up and moved on. On the afternoon of the 8th heavy firing was heard in the direction of Stony Creek Station, on the Weldon Railroad, and deserters who came in that day stated that MAHONE's rebel division had been sent our to meet our forces. The exact destination of our troops was unknown. Gen. WARREN commanded the force. A cavalry reconnaissance was made on Thursday afternoon, which drove the rebels to their breastworks on Hatchen's Run, where they were developed in force. Reports were current that the evacuation of Petersburgh might be looked for at an early day.

abstract: T.C. Clark vs. Henry Dean. -- This action was brought to recover a balance of account on a grocer's bill, the last item in which accrued in November, 1857. The defendant plead the statute of limitations as a bar to the action. Plaintiff put in evidence a note from defendant, dated in 1861, and claimed, to have been received in that year, which acknowledged the debt, and promised payment. Defendant denies that the note was sent in 1861, and alleged that it was sent in reply to a dunning letter from plaintiff, in December, 1857. His Honor charged Jury that if they found that this note was sent in 1861, it amounted to a renewal of the obligation and took the case out of the statute. Verdict for the plaintiff for $770 84 and interest.

abstract: The Society for Promoting the Gospel among the Seamen in the Port of New-York, known as the Port Society, seized upon the opportunity afforded by the presence among us of that brave and noble sailor, the Commander of the Kearsarge, at once to...
lead_paragraph: The Society for Promoting the Gospel among the Seamen in the Port of New-York, known as the Port Society, seized upon the opportunity afforded by the presence among us of that brave and noble sailor, the Commander of the Kearsarge, at once to enable our citizens to give him a hearty welcome, and at the same time to make his appearance sub-serve the objects of a society whose work must commend itself especially to one who takes so deep an interest in the welfare of seamen as Capt. WINSLOW. Doubtless the severe storm alone prevented as large an attendance as might have been anticipated from the claims of the society, combined with the promised attraction of seeing the hero of the Kearsurge, but still there was a very respectable assemblage, many of them ladies, whose enthusiasm, both for the cause and the man, enabled them to brave the weather.

abstract: Joliet. Illinois was excited on Nov. 30, by the discovery of a determined and skillful effort to plunder the Joliet City bank. The officers of the institution on opening the bank found that the burglars had been vigorously at work in the vault at LILLIE's chilled non-safe but that they had failed in effecting an entrance. Upon the premises was found as complete and formidable set of tools as perhaps was ever used by burglars, consisting of two pointed heavy steel bars, about three feet long, a steel "Jimmy," a ratchet drill, a hand brace, with several peculiar shaped drills, which had been unsuccessfully used, a heavy blacksmith's sledge, chisels, &c.; also a quantity of powder and a coil of use. The powder had been used, but with no effect whatever upon the safe. The appearance of the safe, as well as the tools, showed they had been severely used.

abstract: Detroit Council on
lead_paragraph: -- The Common Council of Detroit are in favor of allowing the Reciprocity Treaty between the United States and the neighboring Provinces to stand as it is, until commissioners are appointed to make a formal report upon the subject. There is a fair share of sound sense in this. The treaty needs revision; but hasty action on a question with which the interests of the great Northwest are so intimately bound up, is strongly to be deprecated. Detroit, in this matter, we have no doubt, speaks for Chicago and Milwaukee as well.

abstract: Appointed Chief Justice and Consol-Union Party; Consolidation of; Chase's Appointment
snippet: Appointed Chief Justice and Consol-Union Party; Consolidation of; Chase's Appointment
lead_paragraph: President LINCOLN's appointment of Secretary CHASE to the office next to his own in responsibility and dignity, will, we trust, make an end forever of the invidious distinctions in the Union party, between the so-called conservatives and the so-called radicals. Mr. LINCOLN has been somewhat complained of, by one portion of the party, for supposed conservative tendencies; Mr. CHASE, by another portion, for supposed radical tendencies. It is useless now to dispute whether there was any just ground on either side for these complaints.

abstract: By the arrival of the Canada at Halifax, yesterday, we have four days later European news. The Canada left Liverpool on the 26th and Queenstown on the 27th ult. The steamship Glasgow also arrived at Halifax yesterday, having put into that port short of coal. The Glasgow left Liverpool on the 23d ult. The news by the Canada is not of political importance. The London Globe expresses the opinion that Lord LYONS will be absent from his post for six months, having, as it alleges, obtained leave of absence for that term on account of his health. There are reports abroad in London that important papers were found on board the Florida., implicating certain persons of eminence. The Great Western grant-ship had been detained in the Mersey by order of the Government, on a charge of having recruits on board. The vessel, however, was stress of released, but was still detained by stress of weather. There had been numerous shipwrecks on the east coast of England, attended with serious loss of life.

abstract: Necessity for Action on
lead_paragraph: The general Bankrupt Bill will be up before Congress to-morrow. And we desire at the earliest moment to express an earnest hope, that it will receive thorough and prompt consideration. From one cause or another the bill which was brought before the House last session by Mr. SPAULDING Of Ohio, had, apparently, no chance from the moment of its introduction. It was, however, a carefully prepared measure, and had the assent, unquestionably, of a large portion of the mercantile community of the land. But, what with the absorption of the time of Congress in settling the questions of taxation, conscription, the currency, and debating an endless variety of speculative measures, from the amendment of the Constitution to the girdling of the globe with telegraphic wires, the loud and all but universal demand for a bankrupt law was left practically unanswered when the dog-days had arrived. It was into June before the Select Committee had made their report. And, then, the measure, except by a small minority of practical men, was taken up in a half-hearted manner. The very opening debate was disgraced by personal altercations, which were renewed on other occasions when the subject was before the House, and which showed that the majority were disposed to let the thing go by default.

abstract: Aphrodite, Men Missing from Wreck
lead_paragraph: The return of Assistannt BAILEY HASCALL enbles us to furnish a list of the missing from the Chartered steamer Aphrodite, which was lost on the coast of North Carolina, some weeks since. Of the draft of men, numbering some 500, only six or eight were drowned, and only one of this number was washed ashore so that he could be identified. There were supposed to be some twenty who deserted to the North Carolina shore, but it is impossible to give their names or to separate them from the lost. The following, however, are missing: Seamen -- John McClean, Thos. Parson, James Devine. Andrew McLean, Richard Smith, Charles Worrell. John Woods, James O'Donnell, Chas. Story. Thos. Wilson, Geo. Frye. Ordinary Seamen -- Samuel Beasley. John Cullen, John Lantry. Landsmen -- James Murray, E.L Davis, Charles Benjamin, John Myer, Alfred Stuart, J.A. Farrell, Jas. Johnston. First-class boy -- Jas. Baker. Second-class fireman -- M. Courtney. Coal-heavers -- Wm. Commington. Henry L. Cox. Drowned -- landsman John Rolf. In addition to these, the Navy Department has information that landsmen Jas. F. Rudd and Wm. Belcher were drowned, and that the fate of John F. Taylor still remains in doubt. This list of names will no doubt serve to put at rest the many anxious minds who have been sorely troubled lest their loved-ones should be among the list of missing. The balance of the 500 men are now distributed in the various Atlantic and Gulf Squadrons.
