abstract: Brooklyn Gas Works; Coal; $50,000
lead_paragraph: EXTENSIVE FIRE AT THE BROOKLYN GAS WORKS IMMENSE DESTRUCTION OF COAL DAMAGE $50,000, About 12 O'Clock Friday, a fire broke out in the coal shed attached to the works of the Brooklyn Gas-Light Company, at the foot of Hudson-avenue, resulting in the destruction of a large amount of property. The fire, it is supposed, originated by spontaneous combustion on Tuesday last, and efforts have since been made to suppress it. There being no more evidence of fire yesterday, all was thought to be safe, but last night it burst forth anew in different places, proving that the entire pile was ablaze. The firemen have been engaged upon it from the time it broke out until noon to-day (Saturday.) The works were saved, but the supply of gas was cut off for three hours. Operations have since been resumed, and the supply will no more be suspended. The quantity of coal inclosed in the shed -- which covers three-fourths of an acre -- was 20,000 tons. It was imported from Glace Bay, Nova Scotia, being peculiarly adapted for gas making. It is bituminous, soft, and highly inflammable. Much of the coal will be saved. The actual loss is estimated at $50,000. The supply on hand was expected to last for five months. The insurances are as follows:

abstract: Rents in New-York
lead_paragraph: Social economists are very far from agreeing upon the proportion which the householder's income should bear to the rent he pays his landlord. In some parts of Europe oneeighth of the income is supposed to represent a reasonable rental. Mr. WILLIAM CHAMBERS, if we remember rightly, puts the proportion about this figure. But we are accustomed in this country -- strange as it seems -- even in healthy times, to much higher rentals, having regard to income. There are various reasons for the difference. But we may sum them up under two heads. In almost every city of Continental Europe and the British Islands, the landlord is content to get a smaller return for his capital than would satisfy him here. And, again, the respectable trader on the other side of the Atlantic is content with a far less pretentious domestic establishment (looking to his income) than the same class of citizen is here.

abstract: COUNTERFEIT TENS ON THE STATE BANK AT NEWARK. -- An Irish laborer, named THOMAS CAMPBELL, aged 52 years, living at No. 44 Clarkson street, was arraigned yesterday, before Justice LEDWITH, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, charged with passing spurious $10 bills on the State Bank at Newark. N.J. Mr. ANTOINE BAUER, a butcher, doing business at No. 300 Hudson-street, the complainant in the case, testified that a day or two since, CAMPBELL came to his stop, and purchased 68 cents worm of corned beef, in payment for which he gave complainant a $10 bill on the above-named bank, and the latter gave him $9 32 in change. Soon after the butcher learned that the bill was worthless. On Saturday, CAMPBELL went to BAUER's shop again, bought some more corned beef, and tendered another counterfeit $10 bill of the same bank. BAUER then detained CAMPBELL until the arrival of Officer GIBBONS, of the Twenty-eighth Precinct, who took him into custody. After an examination he was committed for trial in default of $1,000 bail. In answer to the question as to his guilt, he stated that he found the money in the street.

abstract: Mr. MARETZEK's second season is drawing rapidly to a close. It will end, so far as the subscribers are concerned, with the present week, but it is Mr. MARETZEK's intention to give a few extra performances in order that he may produce AUBER's celebrated opera of "Fra Diavolo." We anticipate for the work an unmistakeable success. It has always been a favorite in its clumsy English dress, and certainly must gain in popularity by the caste, scenery and costumes that will be bestowed upon it at the Academy. The past week was not a good one for amusements. The weather has been too much unsettled. Nevertheless the Fourteenth-street house has been well attended, and the performances have given very general satisfaction. On Saturday the "Daughter of Regiment" was repeated at the Matinee, and attracted a good audience, notwithstanding the snow-storm. Miss KELLOGG sang admirably, so much so that the Herald has taken back all that it said against her in a recent editorial. Nothing can exceed the variety of that journal's opinions, except their wildness. Signor SUSINI's Sergeant Sulpics is a very amusing and somewhat vociferous performance. Signor LOTTI was in good voice, and prudently avoided those upper regions, where disaster not unfrequently is encountered. Tonight "H Trovatore" will be repeated for the last time. The distribution is remarkably good. There will be no opera tomorrow night, the Academy being required for a full rehearsal of "Fra Diavolo." On Wednesday, "Don Sebastian" will be given for the last time this season, and on the following night, (Brooklyn Academy) "Don Giovanni."

abstract: Gen, New Army Corps
lead_paragraph: -- It will not be creditable to the spirit of the veterans of New-York, who have completed their military term, if Gen. HANCOCK's magnificent offer to organize a corps exclusively of honorably discharged soldiers, fails to meet a prompt and hearty response. The inducements, we desire to point out once more, are of no common kind. The Commanding General is himself one of the most popular leaders in the service. The subordinate officers are to be commissioned from such as have honorably served not less than two years. Recruits will be credited to the districts in which they or their families are domiciled, and immediately on being mustered into service, will receive, in addition to the regular Government bounty, a special bounty of three hundred dollars. The term of service is for one year.

abstract: Labor Question in Kentucky; The Labor Question in
snippet: Labor Question in Kentucky; The Labor Question in
lead_paragraph: -The question of slavery is beginning to demand decisive action at the hands of the people of Kentucky, as it must in every slave State sooner or later. The Louisville Journal is pressing the slaveholders of the State to give it their attention. Under the existing state of things labor is rapidly leaving the Slate and will continue to do so as long as slavery exists by law. The State Constitution prohibits the emancipation of slaves without the consent of their owners, or without paying their value in money and removing them from the State. The Journal therefore urges the owners to consent to their emancipation, and to their retention in the State until labor shall become more abundant. Kentucky will speedily be compelled, by her industrial necessities, to follow the example of Maryland, and so will every other slave-holding State, even if slavery should not be abolished by an amendment of the National Constitution.

abstract: Highway; Frankfort-street, at Midday; Price Crossed Above Fort Smith; Mutiny in Fagan's Division
snippet: Highway; Frankfort-street, at Midday; Price Crossed Above Fort Smith; Mutiny in Fagan's Division
lead_paragraph: A daring assault and robbery was perpetrated upon an elderly gentleman, about 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, in Frankfort street. A man, who subsequently gave his name as THOS. ROBERTS, met the victim on the walk, suddenly threw one arm round his neck, and choked him so seriously that the old gentleman nearly fell to the ground. While he had him in that position, the robber slipped his hand into the pocket of the other took his pocketbook and ran down the street, shouting the familiar words of "Stop thief! stop thief!" Several persons witnessed the whole proceeding, but it was so startling in its nature, and so speedy in its execution, that for the moment every one seemed unable to render the gentleman any assistance. Senator BRADLEY and others, who were eye-witnesses, pursued the outlaw, had him arrested, taken to the Tombs and locked up for examination. When inquiry was made for the victim of the outrage he could not be found. He is earnestly requested to appear and give his testimony before Justice HOGAN, this morning, at the Tombs Police Court.

abstract: Operations in progress
lead_paragraph: -- There are a number of military and naval movements in progress at present -- of some of which the public are partially informed, and of others they are in ignorance -- which seem greatly involved and totally disconnected; but which, we think, will soon be found to be parts of one great and comprehensive plan. Four extensive operations, ranging across four great rebel States of the Atlantic slope, each operation having a bearing upon the others, and all looking to results of magnitude, are pretty sure to meet their consummation before Christmas. Of the object of Gen. WARREN's movement in Virginia, the public are as ignorant as they are of the whereabouts of Gen. SHERMAN in Georgia; but WARREN's movement is as assuredly connected with other great operations, which will in due time be developed, as FOSTER's movement on the Charleston and Savannah Railroad was connected with the great march of Gen. SHERMAN. By the way, we may remark that it now appears that FOSTER's late movement was not as entire a failure as it seemed at first sight. He was repulsed at Grahamville, but he destroyed the bridge ouer the Pocotaligo, which was one of the main objects he had in view. We learn but little additional of SHERMAN, but the public will almost certainly be gratified this week by good news from him.

abstract: The building hired on Duane-street by the County Committee on Volunteering, has proved to be too small for the accommodation of the clerical force engaged in correcting the enrollment lists of this city and county. The committee are about erecting a wooden structure in the City Hall Park, fronting on Broadway, which will contain every convenience and ample accommodations for all the clerks employed. This building is to be over 300 feet in length. It is thought that the whole work of correcting the lists can be completed in ninety days.

abstract: Governor of Virginia; Message on; Message
snippet: Governor of Virginia; Message on; Message
lead_paragraph: There is after all no such trustworthy information concerning the actual state of Dixie as is afforded by its official documents. The newspapers aim chiefly to keep up the public spirit by clap-trap and buncomb. The few private individuals who escape have only had a very narrow field of observation, and their report concerning that narrow field is apt to be more or less incorrectly colored by their personal feeling. But the public officials, of the higher class, have a complete view of all affairs as they actually are, and they have the strongest motives to represent them truly. Official responsibilities and necessities weigh upon them which cannot be satisfied by any sort of humbug. The war against them is a terrible reality. They cannot stand up against it for a day, except with solid means. These means can be had only from the people, and the representatives of the people. Therefore they must publicly declare, under the penalty of ruin, just what their dangers and their wants are.

abstract: -- A fair for the benefit of the families of volunteers and the relief of sick and wounded soldiers, will be held at the City Hall, in Jersey City, commencing this evening at 7 o'clock. The fair is held under the auspices of the Ladies' Relief Society of Jersey City, an organization that has already performed a vast amount of good work for soldiers and their families. Under their skillful direction the hall has been fitted up in elegant style, and the display of articles for sale is very extensive and tempting. The object is one that commends itself to the good wishes of every one, and we trust that the fair will prove a decided success.

abstract: The Union party, it seems, is to be treated to its annual display of "dirty linen." Now that the election is over, and votes are, therefore, not to be immediately affected by it, parties who deem themselves aggrieved come before the public in hot pursuit of "satisfaction." As a general thing, these performances are old friends with new faces, --old quarrels under new pretexts.
lead_paragraph: The Union party, it seems, is to be treated to its annual display of "dirty linen." Now that the election is over, and votes are, therefore, not to be immediately affected by it, parties who deem themselves aggrieved come before the public in hot pursuit of "satisfaction." As a general thing, these performances are old friends with new faces, -- old quarrels under new pretexts. Ex-Surveyor ANDREWS resents his wrongs by printing two columns of vehement vituperation on that venerable offender THURLOW WEED, upon whom he charges the "deep damnation" of his removal from office. Ex-Mayor OPDYKE has sued the same political marplot for libel, and the courts commence to-day an inquest into the alleged offence.

abstract: Cobden, Richard, on Non-intervention; on Non-intervention
snippet: Cobden, Richard, on Non-intervention; on Non-intervention
lead_paragraph: No one doubts the perfect good faith with which Mr. COBDEN argues the question of nonintervention in presence of his countrymen. And as little can any one doubt the consummate ability which marks his public utterances on international questions generally.-- No one doubts the perfect good faith with which Mr. COBDEN argues the question of non-intervention in presence of his countrymen. And as little can any one doubt the consummate ability which marks his public utterances on international questions generally. Mr. COBDEN has been addressing his constituents at Rochdale, on American as well as other affairs; and we shall all gather instruction from his arguments. But the mere intimation of the delivery of such a speech clearly suggests one pertinent fact as to non-intervention here. It is this -- and many of our friends abroad are apt to overlook it -- that the loyal people of the American Republic would as cordially resent an intervention in their favor, as they would an open or a secret alliance of the rebellious States against the Union. The strong and stout arm of the North can be upheld only by the brave hearts which cling with true faith and unshaken courage to the cause of a free Republican Government. When the freemen of these States begin even to whisper a desire for intervention in their own behalf, the cause of the Republic is gone hopelessly. The sentiment was well put in Mr. SEWARD's note on the Wharncliffe charity fund. Americans North and South, be they loyalists or rebels, the Secretary hoped, had too much self-respect to invite the commiseration of Europe. If this was giving too much credit to the rebel leaders, it was certainly no incorrect interpretation of the universal feeling among the masses of the population of this Continent, from Labrador to the Southern Cape, to be let alone by Europe, no matter under what guise intervention is proffered.

abstract: In the senate, yesterday, Mr. SHERMAN, of Ohio, presented a petition from the members of the Western Associated Press, asking for a reduction of the duty on imported paper, which was referred to the Committee on Finance, Mr. FOOTE, of Vermont, offered the House resolution, which was passed, authorizing the Secretary of the Navy to expend money out of the contingent fund of the Army Department, to enlarge the Navy Department building.
lead_paragraph: In the senate, yesterday, Mr. SHERMAN, of Ohio, presented a petition from the members of the Western Associated Press, asking for a reduction of the duty on imported paper, which was referred to the Committee on Finance, Mr. FOOTE, of Vermont, offered the House resolution, which was passed, authorizing the Secretary of the Navy to expend money out of the contingent fund of the Army Department, to enlarge the Navy Department building. The petition of Maj.-Gen. WEITZEL and four hundred and seventy other officers of the Eighteenth Army Corps, praying for increate of pay, was presented by Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts. It was referred to the Military Committee, A resolution that the Committee on Finance be instructed to inquire into the propriety of the immediate passage of an act to increase the revenue by an additional tax on sales of real estate, &c., was referred to that Committee. Mr. DAVIS, of Kentucky, according to previous notice, introduced a series of resolutions for the restoration of peace, union, &c. Mr. FARWELL introduced a bill to regulate the admeasurement of the tonnage of ships, and to prescribe the charges to the same, which was referred to the Committee on Commerce. After an executive session the Senate adjourned.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--"Il Trovatore"--the most permanently popular opera, with the single exception of "Don Giovanni," that has ever been produced in New-York--was repeated here last evening to more than an average house, ZUCCHI, MORENSI and BELLINI were excellent. The same--with the reservation of a solitary moment, when the weather had its way--may be said of Signor MASSIMILIANI, who, in the latter portion of the opera, was in fact admirable. The performance generally gave complete satisfaction.

Officer PIKE, of the Seventh Precinct, yesterday arrested a man named PATRICK MALONE, who was identified by Mr. WITHERELL as one of the men who assaulted and robbed him. abstract: Brooklyn Art Association Reception
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn Art Association gave their first reception of the season last evening at the Academy of Music. The attendance from an early hour became overwhelming, and by nine o'clock the majority of those present gave up the hope of examining the pictures, and resorted to the congenial occupation of flirting with the pretty girls -- for which timely diversion the body of the house seemed to be providentially reserved, and a band of music especially engaged. Nearly all the best artists of this City and Brooklyn were represented on the walls, the number of pictures exhibited being 162. Many of these were of large size and of true artistic importance. Indeed, from the largest to the smallest, we have rarely seen a collection that possessed such an average of merit. Landscapes and marines were in abundance -- for it is in these branches that our artists most excel. There were also many genre pieces -- most of them betraying a leaning to the French school -- of which, by the way, there was a superb specimen in the room by MERLE. In addition to the pictures, an extremely interesting series of designs for illustrations to LONGFELLOW's poem of "Miles Standish" was exhibited. They were executed by pupils (male and female) of the Graham Art School -- an institution which, judged by its results, is certainly fulfilling its mission in an exceedingly satisfactory way. The exhibition will remain open until Saturday.

abstract: -For two full years after the war commenced, New-York was almost as peaceable and well-behaved as a rural village. The contrast at this time is fearful. Our columns, day after day, show that we are either getting a terrible influx of population from among the dangerous classes of other communities, or that we are breeding among ourselves a criminal population unprecedented, as to its numbers and daring, in the annals of the city. Garroting has become an established made of assault, and mid-day robbery on the public streets is one of the latest phases of the outbreak. We can probably explain to ourselves how citizens may be waylaid at night in out-of-the-way streets, and robbed of their personal effects. But we are daily reporting robberies of a different kind, which show that crime is stalking abroad in a more dangerous form than we have heretofore known it. On Monday, at an hour when the streets were thronged almost to their utmost, a respectable person was knocked down and robbed in Frankfort-street, within sight of Broadway, and but for the promptitude and courage with which a private citizen, who witnessed the assault and robbery, acted on the occasion, the robber would have escaped. Passers-by have not always the nerve to do this sort of work. Indeed, it may as well be said bluntly, that people pay liberally to have it done for them. We know not who is to blame, or if any one, supposed to be responsible, is to blame for the almost total impunity with which these outrages are perpetrated. But surely it is high time that some one were held responsible.

lead_paragraph: The Live Stock Markets are very favorable to owners and speculators this week, and drovers have generally made money, cold weather making a brisk demand for butcher's meats. The total receipts for the week are, 6,245 beeves, 1,393 calves, 18,165 sheep and lambs, and 24,267 swine. This is a good supply, but all kinds show a marked advance in price, and more stock could readily be sold. The recent snow-storm doubtless reminds butchers that the supply is liable to be cut off by a blockade of the railroad, while the severe cold creates a greater consumption of meat. Under this stimulus the demand is such that holders easily obtain much higher rates. Beef has advanced a full cent. lb. on all but the fancy, which were at the topmost before, and on inferior grades the rise was still greater. Whole droves are reported sold at 17c.@18c. lb., estimated net weight, and one lot of 25 at 20c., with single bullocks in several droves at the same figures. Sheep and lambs are selling quickly at an advance of more than $1 head. Fat lots are worth 10c.@10 1/2c. lb., live weight, with a scant supply. Live Hogs are going off finely for owners, prime lots selling readily at 13 1/2c.@14c., and more are wanted.

abstract: The United States flag-ship Hartford, Rear-Admiral DAVID G. FARRAGUT, from Mobile Bay, via Pensacola, Nov. 30, and Key West Dec, 5, arrived yesterday afternoon and anchored in the North River. She had moderate weather and light winds to Key West: from thence had fine weather until the 8th, when she encountered a gale from the northeast, which lasted two days, the sea being so high that she rolled her waist-boats under and lost one of them. On the 12th anchored outside the Hook. Annexed is a list of officers:
lead_paragraph: The United States flag-ship Hartford, Rear-Admiral DAVID G. FARRAGUT, from Mobile Bay, via Pensacola, Nov. 30, and Key West Dec, 5, arrived yesterday afternoon and anchored in the North River. She had moderate weather and light winds to Key West: from thence had fine weather until the 8th, when she encountered a gale from the northeast, which lasted two days, the sea being so high that she rolled her waist-boats under and lost one of them. On the 12th anchored outside the Hook. Annexed is a list of officers:

abstract: Opdyke-Weed Libel Suit; Weed-Opdyke Libel; Suit Commenced
snippet: Opdyke-Weed Libel Suit; Weed-Opdyke Libel; Suit Commenced
lead_paragraph: George Opdyke vs. Thurlow Weed. -- The trial of this somewhat notorious case was commenced yesterday morning in Part 3 of the Supreme Court. Beside the parties themselves and their respective counsel, quite a number of individuals, more or less distinguished in political life, were in attendance as spectators or witnesses. The amount of damages claimed by the plaintiff is $50,000 for injury to his character by alleged libelous publications. A long list of witnesses having been called over, counsel proceeded to the examination of jurymen.

abstract: A meeting of congratulation over Mr. LINCOLN's reelection was held in New-Orleans, Dec. 1, Gov. HAHN spoke, and, in conclusion, he alluded to the proposed amendment of the Constitution respecting slavery. This amendment would certainly be passed. It was better that slavery should forever disappear. He would say to all men who were not prepared to sacrifice pecuniary interests that were invested in slavery, let 'em slide. He alluded to the proposed proclamation of general amnesty. Pardon the rebels in ranks, of course; but SLIDELL, WIGFALL and that ilk -- well, the people would settle them. He knew that thousands of rebels in arms were praying to be restored to the United States Government; let us welcome them back. We were willing to fight out this contest. He believed this to be the sentiment of the people. The people were willing to give more money -- enough to carry on the war for seventy-five years more. He believed the North to be undivided. The conspirators were so insignificant as to be unworthy of consideration. The North proclaims to the whole world their adherence to the principles of liberty and equality of man. Hereafter, the man who raises his voice against this principle, a heavy hand will be laid on him.

abstract: The action of the House on the Bankruptcy Bill deserves emphatic commendation. The measure was brought over from last session for action on Monday. The members, or, at least, a most respectable majority, had discernment to see that the country would no longer be trifled with on a question of such vital moment, and, with no needless discussion, the bill of last session, which had been thoroughly sifted by a select committee, was passed by the respectable vote of 76  to 56. The yeas and nays were recorded in our last issue, and may be scanned with profit. The action of the Senate hereupon will be watched with no common interest. That body is naturally, to a degree, removed beyond merely popular influences; but we venture to hope that a measure, which has been so thoroughly weighed, not only as to its principle, but as to its minutest details, as the bill which has passed the House will not meet at least with an unreasoning opposition in the higher legislative body. The Senate will do well to consider that its revisory powers on a question of such immediate practical account to a vast number of loyal and honest citizens, should be limited by the simple consideration of whether positive injustice is done by the measure to any opposing class in the community. We venture to think that, on this point New-York may speak with some degree of authority. And we have yet to hear that any large body of those who come under the class of creditors here, seek to throw obstacles in the way of such a measure of relief as the House bill provides for.

abstract: United States House Vote to Terminate
snippet: United States House Vote to Terminate
lead_paragraph: -By our Washington news report, it will be seen that the House, by a vote of eighty-five to fifty-seven, have adopted a resolution giving notice of an intention to terminate the Reciprocity Treaty. It is, of course, competent for the House to pass such a resolution; but, if we mistake not, the time and mode of giving the notice indicated in the House resolution are matters of purely Executive action, in which -- as in relation to the invasion of Mexico, and kindred questions -- the House may properly suggest, but does not necessarily assume to dictate, a policy for the guidance of the Executive. The character, moreover, of the vote taken on this question, will show it to have been a vote of an almost entirely sectional character. These, we take it, are hardly the times to create new geographical parties in the National Legislature. The Treaty in question most assuredly needs revision in the interest of the manufacturers of the Northeast. But its abrogation at this time would simply be a new sectional triumph among ourselves. Is this wanted?

abstract: The news from Gen. SHERMAN this morning is highly important. An official telegram from Secretary STANTON to Gen. DIX gives the contents of a dispatch from Gen. GRANT, which announces ...
lead_paragraph: The news from Gen. SHERMAN this morning is highly important. An official telegram from Secretary STANTON to Gen. DIX gives the contents of a dispatch from Gen. GRANT, which announces that Richmond papers of Monday and Tuesday, state that Gen. SHERMAN's army was drawn up in line of battle only five miles north of Savannah. No engagement had occurred up to Monday, so far as was known; but telegraphic communication with Savannah was interrupted, and the rebels, therefore, could scarcely know what was going on there.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. To-night DONIZETTI'S opera of "Don Sebastian" will be played for the last time this season. The announcement is rendered necessary by the forthcoming production of AUBER'S "Fra Diavolo," and not by any lack of interest in the work first named.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- To-night DONIZETTI's opera of "Don Sebastian" will be played for the last time this season. The announcement is rendered necessary by the forthcoming production of AUBER's "Fra Diavolo," and not by any lack of interest in the work first named. Of the many productions that have taken place in New-York -- and nearly all have been at the expense and under the direction of Mr. MARETZEK -- few have been more creditable than this. Considering the uncertain duration of our operatic seasons, and the fact that there is no kind of reliable support extended to the impressario, it is really remarkable to find that one can be found who is willing to incur the risk of bringing out first-class artists from Europe -- who may fail, and yet have to be engaged for a stated period -- and of expending many thousands of dollars in the mise-in-scene of a single opera, which, after all, may not be acceptable. No man has done so much in this way as Mr. MARETZEK, and rarely with better tact taste than this season. The scenery, costumes and appointments of "Don Sebastian" are of unparalleled splendor. This fact alone will cause the opera to take a prominent place in the repertoire; and the music will not quickly be forgotten by those who have other tastes to gratify than that of mere spectacle. "Don Sebastian" is not likely to be again played for many months, for, after next week, Mr. MARETZEK goes to Boston. To-night, then, is, for a large class of people, the last chance. "Fra Diavalo" has undergone the tedious process of rehearsal for many weeks, and will probably be produced on Monday.

abstract: By the arrival of the barkentine Teresa, Caps. AVERY, from Maracaibo, we have intelligence from that place to the 20th ult. Gen. POULGA, the revolutionary exile, visited that place on the 14th of November, in a British schooner, having a crew of only twelve men, and while off the bar, she was boarded by a boat from a Government schooner lying in the mouth of the harbor. The officers and boat's crew were immediately made prisoners. Gen. POULGA then sent word to the Government schooner, purporting to be from the Captain of the vessel that he was in, informing them that Gen. POULGA was a prisoner on board, when a second boat was sent, and they also made prisoners. Gen. POULGA having thus weakened the force of the Government vessel, easily forced them to surrender, and took charge of her. He then went ashore to a battery, drove away the garrison, and spiked the guns; after which, he proceeded on board the vessel he had taken, fired into a Government steamer near by, killing one man and wounding the Captain, and then proceeded to sea, taking with him his prisoners. He lay off the port until the 18th, when he disappeared. The vessel that Gen. POULGA came in had no armament, the crew being simply armed with revolvers and side-arms. The town of Maracaibo was in the greatest state of alarm, fearing that the place would be bombarded, and, as a result, would be surrendered. The Teresa was detained three days in consequence. No pilot could be found who would venture to take her to sea until all fears were allayed.

abstract: Address to and Reply
lead_paragraph: A large number of our most prominent and honorable citizens engaged in commercial, financial and public life, have united in an address of congratulation to Hon. REUBEN E. FENTON, upon his election as Governor of the State of New-York. They refer to his patriotic career in Congress -- to the rare intelligence and unflinching fidelity which he displayed in the nation's great emergency -- to his faithful devotion to the industrial and commercial interests of the country -- to the moral effect of his influence in maintaining the public credit, and in promoting the welfare of all engaged in the patriotic work of preserving the national honor. In order that they may have an opportunity for expressing more fully their sense of the many claims to public regard of the Governor-elect, they invite him to meet them at a public dinner. To this invitation and to these graceful, just, and well-merited compliments, Gov. FENTON has replied. His public duties place it beyond his power to comply with the invitation. He warmly, though modestly, alludes to the expressions of confidence and respect uttered by his distinguished correspondents, briefly refers to his past public conduct, and promises that in the honorable position to which he has been chosen, of Chief Magistrate of the great State of New-York, he will bring to the discharge of his duties an earnest purpose to subserve the public weal, and maintain and perpetuate the institutions that have come down to us from our patriotic ancestors. Gov. FENTON truly says -- what the people of this city cannot have too frequently called to their attea-tion -- that:

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. SUMNER reported a bill authorizing the President of the United States to transfer a gunboat to the Republic of Liberia. Mr. SHERMAN, of Ohio, reported a bill, which was passed, authorizing the construction ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. SUMNER reported a bill authorizing the President of the United States to transfer a gunboat to the Republic of Liberia. Mr. SHERMAN, of Ohio, reported a bill, which was passed, authorizing the construction of six revenue cutters, for service on the lakes, and appropriating one million of dollars, or so much as is necessary for the purpose. Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, introduced a joint resolution, which was referred to the Military Committee, to encourage enlistments in the army by making free the wives and children of colored soldiers, now held as slaves in the South. A message was received from the House, announcing the passage by that body of a bill to establish a uniform system of bankruptcy. On motion of Mr. FOSTER, of Connecticut, the bill was referred to the Judiciary Committee and ordered to be printed. The credentials of Mr. ANTHONY, as Senator from Rhode Island, for six years from March 4, 1865, were presented by Mr. SPRAGUE, of that State. The Senate then went into Executive session, and on the openeng of the doors adjourned.

abstract: We have very important news from Gen. SHERMAN'S army this morning. The first direct communication from that army since it left Atlanta is received through Gen. FOSTER, in a dispatch to Gen. HALLECK, from Hilton Head, Dec. 12, in which he announces the arrival there of Capt. DUNCAN, one of Gen. HOWARD'S scouts, ...
lead_paragraph: We have very important news from Gen. SHERMAN's army this morning. The first direct communication from that army since it left Atlanta is received through Gen. FOSTER, in a dispatch to Gen. HALLECK, from Hilton Head, Dec. 12, in which he announces the arrival there of Capt. DUNCAN, one of Gen. HOWARD's scouts, who left the army on the 9th inst., and, descending the Ogeeche in a small boat, communicated with the fleet. A dispatch from Gen. HOWARD to the Commander of the fleet, reports the army within ten miles of Savannah on the 9th, and advancing to attack that city. The troops were in fine spirits and excellent condition. No opposition of any moment had been enconntered in the march through Georgia. The army had lived on the country, and, in addition had accumulated supplies of horses and cattle. Gen. FOSTER adds that the first line of works, five miles from Savannah, were probably attacked on the 11th, as heavy firing was heard in that direction.

lead_paragraph: George Opdyke vs. Thurlow Weed. -- The trial of this noted cause was resumed yesterday morning, and the court-room was again crowded with spectators. The plaintiff having closed his case on the first day, Judge Pierpont opened for the defence, saying that he felt, like Hamlet, that there was a special providence even in the fall of a sparrow. He had never struggled before to avoid the trial of a cause. He had sought to avoid the public scandal, the disgraceful exhibition of the immorality of public men which this trial must show. Mr. Weed had said that it was his duty, and he shrank not from it. There came a time in the history of all nations when the misdeeds of men in high offices had to be exhibited to the world. It would have been impossible to prevent the trial of this cause. It was one of those things that must come to pass. We had reached a degree of vileness and corruption in public offices, which made it necessary that something must come to pass to bring it to the light, and this trial was to be the means of uncovering the corruption of public men. He should exhibit there to-day a state of corruption in our public officers in this city that would be the beginning of a revolution here. God grant that it might be bloodless; but they would see there such a state of public morals that the necessity of a change would be apparent. Judge Pierrepont then read the libels, and stated that Mr. Weed had not made these statements without carefully considering the matter; that if he did not this day substantiate the statements, his witnesses would fail far short of their written testimony, sworn to before the trial.

abstract: Coursol, Judge, Decision on; Gen Dix's Order
snippet: Coursol, Judge, Decision on; Gen Dix's Order
lead_paragraph: It concerns the people of the neighboring Provinces more than us, whether the Colonies shall become a base of operations for organized bands of burglars, to rob and murder at will in the border towns. Gen. DIX's order, which appears in another column, is the first formal intimation of the purpose of the United States Government to stop this business. It is hardly possible to over-estimate the significance of this document. Gen. DIX speaks at once by direct authority of the War Department and with the perfect cognizance of the National Executive. His words imply no threat, but they convey, in explicit language, the purpose of the Government of this country to perform -- if need be -- police duty beyond the frontiers of these States.

abstract: Power of the Government Developed; Power of; the Constitution; Newly-developed Powers of the
snippet: Power of the Government Developed; Power of; the Constitution; Newly-developed Powers of the
lead_paragraph: One of the great works of this struggle for national life is its bringing out the undeveloped powers of the Constitution. All of the national history before the rebellion was comparatively a halcyon period. The ship of State floated along about as carelessly as CLEOPATRA's barge -- all rejoicing in the golden streamers and the purple sails, but few knowing or caring where were the ribs, or what the keel. Now that the hurricane is upon us in the high seas, we, for the first time, begin fully to comprehend the solid oak and the matchless build.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. NESMITH, of Oregon, presented the memorial of the Legislature of Oregon praying for the establishment of a manufactory of arms in that State. Joint resolutions of thanks to Capt. WINSLOW and Lieut. CUSHING were reported and passed. A petition from several line officers in the army, asking for additional compensation, was presented and referred to the Military Committee.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. NESMITH, of Oregon, presented the memorial of the Legislature of Oregon praying for the establishment of a manufactory of arms in that State. Joint resolutions of thanks to Capt. WINSLOW and Lieut. CUSHING were reported and passed. A petition from several line officers in the army, asking for additional compensation, was presented and referred to the Military Committee. Mr. WILSON reported back the joint resolution offered by him on Tuesday, declaring free the wives and children of colored soldiers, with the recommendation that it pass. It was read lor the first time. Mr. CHANDLER, of Michigan, offered a resolution that the Military Committee be directed to inquire into the expediency of organizing an army corps to watch and defend our territory bordering on the lakes and the Canadian line, from all hostile demonstrations and incursions. Objection being made, the resolution lies over. Mr. CHANDLER then offered a resolution asserting the complicity of Great Britain with acts of rebel privateers and instructing the Secretary of State to make out a list of each ship and cargo thus destroyed, and to demand from the British Government payment in full for them all. The resolution of Mr. DOOLITTLE, of Wisconsin, in relation to taxation, offered last Monday, was taken up, and after some debate, referred to the Committee on Finance. A joint resolution from the House, giving notice to Great Britain of the termination of the Reciprocity Treaty, was referred to the Committee on Foreign Relations.

abstract: Salaries of Government Clerks; The Pay of
snippet: Salaries of Government Clerks; The Pay of
lead_paragraph: We trust favorable consideration will be given to the application of certain classes of persons in the employ of the Government for an increase of their salaries. As a general thing, these salaries are now precisely what they were three years ago, while house-rent, clothing, food, and all other necessaries of life, have doubled in price. Either their salaries were too high originally, or they are too low now; as nobody has ever held the first of these positions, the second must be true. Thesalaries of our Government functionaries have always been small, not only compared with the scale adopted in other countries, but in view of the labor performed and the qualifications required. But, under the present exceptional and temporary state of things, it is absolute injustice to require them to live on what barely sufficed to support them three years ago. It is an injustice, moreover, which neither governments nor individuals permit themselves to commit in other cases. The wages of labor have increased, mechanics in all departments receive higher pay, officers and soldiers in the army have had their pay enhanced, and in every department of active labor prices have been advanced to meet the increased cost of living. Why should a special exception be made in the case of Government clerks?
headline: {'main': 'Pay of Government Clerks.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Pay of Government Clerks.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- A ladies' fair in behalf of the Church of the Restoration, (Protestant Episcopal,) is now in progress at No. 932 Broadway, corner of Twenty-second-street. As a special attraction, the Seventh Regiment Band has been engaged to furnisn music every evening, and a promenade concert is the inevitable consequence. The object is so praiseworthy, that extrordinary inducements of the kind ought not to be necessary to secure a full attendance and generous receipts.

abstract: The discharge of the St. Alban's raiders surprised the members of the Government, and the ground of the discharge is pronounced ridiculous. The magistrate is likely to be severely dealt with. New warrants have been issued by a Superior Court Judge for the rearrest of the raiders, and constables are in pursuit. An efficient military force is to be sent to the border towns immediately, to prevent further depredations.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. SUMNER offered a resolution, which was adopted, requesting the President to [???]y before the Senate any information on the files of the Department of State, in regard to the treaty with Great Britain, relating to the navaL force on the lakes. Mr. LANE, of Kansas, offered a resolution instructing the Committee on the Conduct or War to inquire into the truth of certain charges, that large numbers of disloyal persons are in the employment of the Government in the navy-yards, Quartermaster's and Ordnance Departments, etc., Of the country, to the exclusion of loyal men, with power to send for persons and papers. After a briet debate the resolution was adopted. Mr. CHANDLER culled up the resolutions offered by him on Wednesday, relating to the Northern Frontier. They were referred to the Committee on Foreign Relations. A resolution looking to the reorganization of the militia system, offered by Mr. BROWN, of Missouri, was adopted. On motion of Mr. CHANDLER, the House bill to regulate commerce among the several States, was made the special order for the first Wednesday in January. The bill to transfer a gunboat to Siberia was taken up and passed. Mr ANTHONY, of Rhode Island, offered a resolution which was adopted, instructing the Committee on the Conduct of the War to inquire into the facts connected with the assault on Petersburgh, on the 30th of July, 1864. The Senate then adjourned until Monday.

abstract: -- The new invention, known as the " Weed Lock-stitch Sewing Machine," is rapidly growing in public favor. Since its introduction, no other machine has increased in popularity more steadily. A very wealthy corporation have it in charge, and with their numerous and well-established agencies in every quarter, at home and abroad, it would seem that this machine will soon have, and deservedly so, a world-wide reputation. Wherever it has been introduced, it has never failed, in a single instance, so far as we know, to give entire satisfaction.

abstract: Our Supplies for
lead_paragraph: -- We are quite sure that the order yesterday promulgated by the War Department, under which special supplies for our loyal and longenduring soldiers still incaptivity at the South, must have carried joy to many a Northern fireside. Let us here repeat in a word or two,the essential points of the order as given in our Washington dispatches. Col. MULFORD, who has been acting as the Union agent for the exchange of prisoners, and whose address is Fortress Monroe, is named for the special duty of forwarding supplies. And the list of articles which the agent is authorized to forward the loyal sufferers, include almost everything that can be supposed to minister to their material comforts. We are sure that we need not urge the importance of seeing to the immediate performance of the duty which this order makes at once practicable. There are thousands of households among us to respond with alacrity at the bare suggestion of an opportunity of communicating with the absent loved ones. And it is unnecessary for us, we feel assured, to do more than indicate the agency through which supplies can be sent to the military prisons and camps of the South.

abstract: "DON GIOVANNI IN BROOKLYN." -- Despite the inclemency of the weather, an immense audience -- one of the largest ever gathered in Brooklyn -- attended at the production of "Don Giovanni," last night. The occasion seemed a fit one for the admirers of Miss KELLOGG to indulge in most extravagant demonstrations of regard and appreciation, her role being made a triumphal scene from the opening to the close. BELLINI, Mme. ZUCCHI and Mile. MORENSI were in admirable voice, and  the opera passed off with enture success. On Thursday next, "Don Sebastian."
lead_paragraph: "DON GIOVANNI IN BROOKLYN." -- Despite the inclemency of the weather, an immense audience -- one of the largest ever gathered in Brooklyn -- attended at the production of "Don Giovanni," last night. The occasion seemed a fit one for the admirers of Miss KELLOGG to indulge in most extravagant demonstrations of regard and appreciation, her role being made a triumphal scene from the opening to the close. BELLINI, Mme. ZUCCHI and Mile. MORENSI were in admirable voice, and the opera passed off with enture success. On Thursday next, "Don Sebastian."

abstract: Nashville, the Battle of
lead_paragraph: We have an official dispatch recounting briefly the facts of a heavy battle which opened at Nashville at 9 o'clock yesterday morning, and continued up to last evening, with great success on our part; but even at night the battle was undecided. Gen. THOMAS, who has been quietly waiting his opportunity in Nashville for a fortnight past, began the attack on HOOD's forces lying around the city, and before nightfall our line had advanced five miles on the right, and the enemy had been driven from the Cumberland River, from their intrenchments, from the range of hills on which their left rested, and in general had been forced back one to three miles, with heavy loss. HOOD's whole army was engaged in the action.
headline: {'main': 'The Battle of Yesterday at Nashville.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Battle of Yesterday at Nashville.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Retirement from Rochester Union
lead_paragraph: We see it announced that ISAAC BUTTS, Esq., has retired from the Rochester Union & Advertiser, of which he has been the editor and part proprietor for many years. We are glad to know that he retires upon a handsome fortune, the result of the energy, enterprise and ability by which his conduct of the Union has been marked. The paper has been intense and not always over-scrupulous in its partisan hostility to the Administration and its friends, though neither have suffered very materially, as results show, from its vigorous and vehement warfare.

abstract: Hostility of, to United States
lead_paragraph: Judge COURSOL, as we learn from an official source, not content with simply discharging the rebel raiders, returned to them the moneys stolen from the St. Alban's banks; and Montreal brokers have converted the funds into gold. This crowns the rascality. There is a report that the Canadian authorities have ordered the re-arrest of the gang. It matters little whether this is true or not. There is little probability that such an order even if issued, would be executed, for the raiders would not stay to be caught. There is less probability that even if executed, it would lead to either extradition to our Government, in accordance with the Ashburton Treaty, or to punishment by the Canadian Government for a violation of the laws of neutrality. The display of Canadian honor and justice already given in this case, is proof that they are mere snares.

abstract: at Savannah
lead_paragraph: The news which we were enabled to give yesterday direct from the army of Gen. SHERMAN, was very refreshing and exhilarating after the rubbish, rhodomontade and lies which the rebels have been sending us about him daily for the last thirty days. We have placed no credence upon the reports which they gave us so plentifully as to the fearful punishment they were inflicting upon him, and the terrible disasters that were befalling him. We had no means of detecting the falsehood in each particular case, or in any of the cases; but still, amid the dense cloud of rebel lies, we could see that SHERMAN's two great columns were steadily advancing from one point to another, were passing across one county and another, over one river after another, along one and another railroad, onward, ever onward and forward, to his destination on the Atlantic seaboard. Even the whinings and screamings and complainings in the rebel newspapers led us to believe that SHERMAN was doing very effective work in destroying the rebel resources, and was finding good stock of supplies and forage for the use of his army.

abstract: -- This edifice was opened for Divine service and the celebration of the Lord's Supper[???] on Sunday last. Notwithstanding the exceedingly inclement weather, a very large congregation occupied the spacious and beautiful sanctuary. There were present in the cha[???]ol, besides Rev. Dr. MONTGOMERY, the Rector. Rev. Dr. FORBES, Rev. Mr. PETERS, Rev. Mr. STOCKING and Rev. J.H. HOPKINS, Jr., who all took part in the services. A beautiful hymn, composed for the occasion b. Dr. LITTELL, of Philadelphia, was sung by the choir and congregation. Rev. Dr. MONTGOMERY took for his text the 16th verse of eighth chapter of the Second Book of Chronicles, from which he preached an excellent discourse. It is a fact worthy of[???]m[???]on that this is the first and only Protestant Episcopal Church ever built in this city, by its congregation, without asking or receiving assistance from the ve[???]rable corporation of Trinity Church. The arrangements of this large and beautiful edifice are very complete. The light is so admitted that not a ray falls into the eyes of the people. At night the church is illuminated by gas-jets around the polls of the columns, and by a superb corona in the channel. The vestiou[???]e, and [???]oad alley, the doors and the chancel, are all admirably fitted for the convenient use of a crowded congregation. The society and Sunday-school rooms are in the chapel building, at the rear of the church itself. There will be a public sale of pews in this church on this (Friday) evening, the 16th inst., at7 1/2 o'clock.

abstract: The news from Nashville this morning is of thrilling interest. An official dispatch from the Secretary of War announces that Gen. THOMAS attacked HOOD at 9 o'clock yesterday morning, and an action resulted which lasted all day, and though not concluded, was splendidly successful, the left wing of the enemy having been driven back five miles, and his centre from one to three miles, with a loss to the rebels of seventeen guns and 1,500 prisoners. They were driven from their [???]ments, from the river, and from the crest of hills which they had occupied. The news is cheering, indeed.

abstract: Press on Presidential Election
lead_paragraph: -- We are entertained by reading in the French organ, La France, that our late Presidential election, having been illegally conducted, is not binding -- that if it cannot be annulled, it can at least be resisted, and that the Western States are actively organizing for a formidable resistance to it. We will not, of course, dispute the accuracy of the information given by the Paris Imperialist journal; in fact, we give it this prominence only to show our appreciation of its intelligence in American affairs.

abstract: Winter Campaign, the
lead_paragraph: Though we are now far advanced into Winter, and the snows and frosts are on the earth and in the heavens, still all our forces and fleets are engaged in active campaigning from the James River to the Mississippi, from the Cumberland to the seaboard. Gen-THOMAS, with one of our three great armies, is demolishing HOOD's army before Nashville; Gen. SHERMAN is thundering at the defences of Savannah, and has just captured Fort McAllister; and GRANT is busy with LEE, and has just, through WARREN, brought to completion an extensive expedition. As regards our lesser military bodies, we read of brisk movements on the seaboard of North Carolina; Gen. FOSTER is distracting the rebels on the coast of the other Carolina, and aiding SHERMAN; while the vast sweep and gigantic scale of our military operations is seen in the fact that we have this morning an official dispatch from Gen. CANBY, at New-Orleans, mentioning that he had sent out two expeditions, cooperative with Gen. SHERMAN, from Vicksburgh and Baton Rouge -- these points being over six hundred miles distant from the point at which FOSTER's small column is also cooperating. Beside all these movements, the official bulletin quotes from Thursday's Richmond papers an account of a very elegant operation undertaken by our troops in East Tennessee, in the rear of BRECKINRIDGE, in which movement, it seems, we have cut through Tennessee into Southwestern Virginia, and have penetrated beyond Abingdon, which the rebels "presume" has fallen into our hands. Another land expedition has moved out from Newbern up the Neuse River, and at last accounts had reached Kinston, half-way to Goldsborough, at which point it would no doubt strike the Wilmington Railroad.

abstract: St. Francis Xavier's College Corporation Gift to; Taxes have been Squandered
snippet: St. Francis Xavier's College Corporation Gift to; Taxes have been Squandered
lead_paragraph: The donation of five thousand dollars which the Aldermen and Common Council have just made to the College of St. Francis Xavier, accompanied by smaller gifts to certain charitable institutions, suggests one point more for the consideration of those who are about to make an effort this Winter to limit these bodies in their powers of mischief. It is agreed on all hands that they are unfit to deal even with the funds which they are authorized to vote for the maintenance of the city government, and are still more unfit to be made the almoners of the public charity, even in cases in which charity is a public duty.

abstract: Your readers will remember, as I have stated the fact in previous letters, the mortality among the thirty thousand prisoners confined at Andersonville, Geo, became so frightful -- averaging one hundred a day during the month of August -- that the rebel authorities were compelled, in their efforts to defend the neighborhood from a pestilence, to break up that dreadful prison. Part of the captives were temporarily transferred to Savannah, where they were treated with comparative kindness by the women or the city, who are spoken of as having contributed generously to the comfort of the sick. From Savannah, after a sojourn at that place of about a month, these prisoners were transferred to a pen at Millen, which had been stockaded for their reception. The other portion of the Andersonville prisoners -- about 15,000 -- were sent to Florence, S.C., where their sufferings were only alleviated so far as this, that the prison-grounds were healthier, and there was more room to move about. The deaths at Florence from scurvy and diarrhoea, during the three months since the camp was established at that place, are estimated to have reached the aggregate of sixteen hundred. Here, as at Andersonville, there appears to have been no pretence on the part of the prison authorities of keeping a correct list of the deceased, and probably hundreds have been buried in unknown graves. Indeed corpses are said to have sometimes remained for as long a period as two days in the stockade before the small detail of negroes appointed for the purpose by the rebels found time to remove them for burial, uncoffined, in the pits they had carelessly prepared. An appeal was then made by Sergt. M. HILEMAN, Company H, Ninety-sixth Illinois Regiment, to Col. IVERSON, of Georgia, who had charge of the prison, for permission to superintend the interment of the dead. This was granted, and from that time the burials were conducted with some decency. Instead of the bodies being thrown as higgledy-piggledy in the pits, they were placed regularly, side by side, and covered with pine boughs before the earth was thrown over them, and, as far as possible, the prison numbers of the deceased was plainly marked on a piece of wood, and placed at the head of the grave, Sergt. HILEMAN also made efforts to obtain the names of the dead, which he preserved to the extent of his ability, and has handed the list to me for publication. As paper was almost impossible to procure, these names are written on scraps -- fragments of newspapers, and diaries, and pieces of envelopes and book-covers. They are inscribed with pencil, and some are now almost illegible. I have copied them as accurately as possible, marking as unknown thirty-three which I failed to decipher. Of the entire correctness of some that I have given I cannot certainly vouch.

abstract: -- The prize steamer Hendry, Acting Ensign John SMALL, Jr., Fortress Monroe, twenty-four hours, arrived here yesterday. The Hendry was Captured the 8th inst., lat. 34° 15' long. 76° 43', by the United States gunboat Cherokee. She was from Wilmington, N.C., bound to Bermuda, with a cargo of naval stores and cotton, she is a new iron side-wheel steamer, and had made one trip between Wilmington and Bermuda.

abstract: Description of
lead_paragraph: Fort McAllister, which was captured on the 14th inst. by Gen. SHERMAN, is a very strong earthwork situated on the Ogeechee River, about sixteen. miles south of the mouth of the Savannah River, and about six miles from the mouth of Ossabaw Sound. This part of the coast of Georgia is of that amphibious character which marks so much of the Southern coastin general -- the raveled and unfinished ends of nature's web, where sea and land keep up a mutual warfare. The ocean breaks in between Great Wassaw and Ossabaw Islands, forming Ossabaw Sound, and into this estuary flow the Great and Little Ogeechee and the Vernon Rivers. The land or rather the march on each side of the Ogeechee, is almost a fleur d' eau, certainly hardly rising a foot above the level of the river, while at times it is entirely submerged. For miles and miles on every hand there is nothing to be seen but these low and level islands and islets, covered with reeds and rank grasses, save where a lustier vegetation has pushed up in occasional clumps of trees called "hummocks."

abstract: To Maj.-Gen. Dix:  Richmoud papers of to-day state that on Wednedsay Gen. Sherman carried Fort McAllister, commanding the entrance to the Ogeechee River, by storm, and that the capture of this position puts Sherman in communication with the Yankee fleet, and necessitates the reinforcement of Savannah.

abstract: -- The anniversary of this institution was to have been observed on Thursday evening at the Academy of Music, but owing to the inclemency of the weather, the number in attendance was small; and in consequence, Mr. RUSSELL, the President, announced that the celebration would be postponed, except as to the exercises of the children, which were given in full, and executed very creditably. Bishop COXE, alter a few remarks to the audience, addressed the children, about two hundred in number, after which the proceedings closed.

abstract: Wampanoag, Swift Screw, Launch of
lead_paragraph: The screw corvette Wampanoag was successfully launched from the Brooklyn Nary-vard Thursday morning. At precisely ll 1/4 o'clock, everything being in readiness, she moved from her ways in the presence of hundreds of spectators, among whom were a large number of ladies. She entered her destined element in the most graceful and brilliant style, amid cheers and waving of handkerchiefs. MISS CASE, daughter of Commander CASE, stood et her bow, and christened her as she went ofl". She gilded through the water about two hundred yards, when she was towed back by tug-boats on hand for the purpose.

abstract: Appeal
lead_paragraph: The Mercantile Library Association, whose local habitation, as most of our city readers are aware, is Clinton Hall, makes another appeal to the intelligence of the commercial community, which should meet a prompt response. The facts, as we discover from a circular issued by the directory, are these: There is an outstanding mortgage on Clinton Hall of $60,000. To meet the interest on this, a large sum is annually swallowed up, which it is desirable should be appropriated to the enlargement of the intellectual treasures of the Association. The library, which is open, at the smallest conceivable charge, to business people, from the humblest salaried clerk up to the leading merchant, is one of the most valuable in the city, alike for general reading and for special reference. It has conferred no common benefits on the so ber and thoughtful class of our young men, whether of the commercial or professional class. And it is not creditable to the wealth and enterprise of New-York that the Mercantile Library should be indebted for one penny to-day. Along with the many scores which the closing year will wipe out, let this Clinton Hall debt be among the foremost. It is but a bagatelle for the class of citizens to which the institution owes its foundation.

abstract: The Company are now ready to grant leases on liberal terms to parties who wish to sink wells. abstract: The Secretary of War furnishes this morning a volume of official dispatches, all of them of the most gratifying character. Success is reported in every quarter of the military field, and much of the information coming through rebel sources, the news may be set down as undoubtedly true.
lead_paragraph: The Secretary of War furnishes this morning a volume of official dispatches, all of them of the most gratifying character. Success is reported in every quarter of the military field, and much of the information coming through rebel sources, the news may be set down as undoubtedly true. The news from Gen. SHERMAN continues highly encouraging. From Richmond papers of yesterday we learn that on Wednesday, 14th, Gen. SHEEMAN carried Fort McAllister by storm, and thus completely opened up his communications with the sea coast via the Ogeechee River, by which he can now receive supplies and reinforcements, if necessary for further operations. His army is thus planted directly in the rear of Savannah, and that city must fall, no matter what may be its defences. We have a report brought by the steamer Varuna, from Charleston Harbor, to annapolis, yesterday, to the effect that Savannah had already been captured, with 1,100 prisoners, after eight hours' fighting, but this is not confirmed from any other source. Richmond papers report the capture of Fort McAllister on Wednesday, and if Savannah had then been taken, as it must have been in order for the news to reach Charleston so soon, it would also have been known in Richmond.

abstract: Enchantress, Capt De Groot's New Steamer
snippet: Enchantress, Capt De Groot's New Steamer
lead_paragraph: A most interesting event to nautical men took place on Friday morning, on the occasion of the trial trip of Capt. DE GROOT'S new steamer Enchantress. A small company of gentlemen, comprising engineers and shipbuilders, among them Messrs. JOHN CHEIGHTON, A.T. EDWARDS, the engineer, Dr. HER IOTT, of this city, and others, assembled on the ship lying at the foot of Twentieth-street, North River. At 11:45 o'clock the steamer left the dock, first under easy steam, not more than 22 pounds, but when once freed from moorings, gradually gaining speed until under 28 pounds of steam, it reached the very high speed of 60 revolutions the minute against a heavy current. Riverdale, sixteen miles distant from the city, was passed in fifty minutes -- a very fine performance for a new vessel with new boilers, likely to foam, and journals very apt to become heated.

abstract: and Peru
lead_paragraph: The Hispano-Peruvian question will hardly be solved by the ingenuity of diplomats. The obstinacy and arrogance of Spain have at length exhausted the patience and aroused the spirit of her quondam colony; and preparations for war are now the order of the day at Lima. A bill providing for the immediate declaration of hostilities against the aggressor was under consideration of the National Congress at last advices, and had actually received a first reading. All this looks martial, and indicates that the Peruvians mean to fight if their imperious old mother won't relinquish her hold on the Chinchas.

abstract: On Friday evening, at Cooper Institute, the first of a series of lectures in aid of the above society was delivered by Rev. E.H. CHAPIN, D.D. Owing to the inclemency of the weather, the hall was but moderately filled. The lecturer chose as his subject, "The Old and the New." He compared the fashions, politics, manner of living, &c., of the present day with those of centuries past, and made many interesting and instructive comparisons, showing the follies and the good points of each. His lecture was a very entertaining one, and was listened to attentively by those present.

abstract: Municipal Privileges
lead_paragraph: The municipal liberty which every American village enjoys, which every considerable English town possesses, is forbidden, under the empire, to the greatest cities of France. From Belgium to the Pyrenees, from the ocean to the Rhine, there does not exist, in the dominion of LOUIS NAPOLEON, a single community that has the right of local self-government. In all, the Mayors and provincial magistrates, instead of being chosen by the people, are the mere nominees and tools of the central Administration. Even Paris, the metropolis of the State, is no exception, for her councillors and civic dignitaries are appointed by the Emperor, just in the same way as those of the pettiest hamlet. This arbitrary mode of installing their corporators in office is of course quite unsatisfactory to the Parisians, who are in the habit of getting up a periodical growl about the grievance as often as it recurs. Their condemnation of the scheme, however, does not seem to have made much impression on the mind of His Majesty thus far, since he has recently sanctioned the appointment of no fewer than sixty of these municipal functionaries to bear rule over the metropolitans.

abstract: From a gentleman who has had opportunities of becoming well informed as to the present state of feeling and opinion in the Southern Confederacy, that there is great dissatisfaction among the people of the South at the prospect of the Richmond leaders arming and freeing the slaves. The ordinary rebels say that they went into the war to fight for the existence of slavery, which was threatened by the North; but that now JEFF. DAVIS himself has proposed a measure which not only secures the abolition of slavery, but endangers the entire social condition of the South by raising within it an army of negroes.

abstract: United States vs 3,792 Hydes; Undervaluation
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. 3,792 Dry Ox and Cow Hides. -- This cause has been on trial for several days past. It is an action on the part of the United States to forfeit the goods for an alleged undervaluation of them in their entry at the Custom-house. The hides were imported from Buenos Ayres by the claimants, Messrs. J.L. Phipps & Co., and the case is one of great interest, not only on account of the value of the goods -- being now some $30,000 -- but also on account of its relation to other litigations, and to the whole trade with Buenos Ayres. It is difficult to state with clearness and accuracy the point involved in the case, as it arises out of the complicated state of the currency in Buenos Ayres.

abstract: The steamship Hibernian arrived at Portland last evening with five days' later intelligence from Europe. Earl RUSSELL had replied to the manifesto of the rebel Congress, and expressed equal friendship for the North and the South. The London Times believes that President LINCOLN will open negotiations with the rebel States. A meeting of English Northern sympathizers at Bristol, convened in honor of President LINCOLN's reelection, was broken up by a mob. The Federal troops have been withdrawn from Holstein on the demand of Prussia.

abstract: Hon. James A. Seddon, Secretary of War:  The expedition to Bellfield, under Gen. WARREN, returned within the enemy's lines yesterday. abstract: Thomas' Victory in Tennessee
lead_paragraph: The dispatch from Gen. THOMAS will be perused with profound satisfaction. The victory of Thursday was followed up on Friday, and HOOD again received terrible punishment, suffering great loss in guns, material and men. This victory in Middle Tennessee reminds us of the victory achieved by Gen. ROSECRANS over BRAGG in the same region (or at Murfreesboro') at the opening of last year. But when BRAGG was defeated, he had a splendid position to retreat to. He could, and soon after did, retire to the great and then considered impregnable stronghold at Chattanooga. HOOD now has no such commanding position to which to fly. The question remains to be solved what he will do.
headline: {'main': 'The Victory in Tennessee.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Victory in Tennessee.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Newbern, Supply Steamer, Officers of
lead_paragraph: The United States supply steamer Newbern, Acting Volunteer Lieut.-Commanding S.B. WASHBURNE, arrived at this port yesterday morning, from the North Atlantic Blockading Squadron, and last from Fortress Monroe, towing from thence to this port the prize steamer Vixen. She was captured on the 2d inst., about seventy miles off Wilmington, by the United States steamer Rhode Island. She is an iron side wheel steamer, of 305 tons, built in England, and is about two months old. Has a cargo of arms, uniforms, drugs, &c.

abstract: Dix, Gen.; Order Revoking Order on Pursuit over Border
snippet: Dix, Gen.; Order Revoking Order on Pursuit over Border
lead_paragraph: Secretary STANTON telegraphs to Gen. DIX that dispatches were received yesterday from Gen. FOSTER, announcing that on the 14th inst. he had a personal interview with Gen. SHERMAN, at Fort McAllister, which had been taken by assault on the preceding day. Savannah was closely besieged, and its capture, with the rebel forces there, confidently expected. Gen. SHERMAN was to make a summons for the surrender of the city within two days; and if not surrendered at the end of that time, our batteries would be opened upon it.

abstract: A gentleman who reached this city last night from Atlanta, reports that the scene of devastation in that city is too awful to contemplate. All the hotels  and the stores from Wesley Chapel on Peachtreestreet to Roark's corner on Whitehall-street have been destroyed. The City Hall and the churches around it are not destroyed.

abstract: The price of Gold fell ten per cent. on Saturday, and closed weak at 223 3/8 per cent. The Railways closed dull and lower.

lead_paragraph: Official dispatches are not usually supposed to be a very fascinating or exhilarating kind of literature; but we venture to say that the people of this country never had a more agreeable chapter of history presented to them than will be found in to-day's bulletin from the War Department. SHERMAN, by his own hand, sends news of conquest; THOMAS sends news of triumph. Every line is luminous with victory. The sententious, swelling sentences are every one rich with such spoils as the great soldier loves to lay at the feet of his country.

abstract: -- M. BOUCICAULT's comedietta called "How She Loves Him," has been received with unquestionable favor at this house, and will be repeated several times during the present week. Its success is due, not merely to the merit of the dialogue, but to the excellent distribution which the piece enjoys. In other respects there is not, critically considered, much to speak about. The plot is too slight to lead the spectator to a strong denouement, and it speedily becomes from mere thinness hopelessly knotted and tangled, so that midway one has already lost all concern for it. The interest thereafter depends entirely on the characters. These are pleasantly sketched, and more original than we are apt to expect in Mr. BOUCICAULT's jater productions. Not a jot of their freshness is wasted on the members of WALLACK's excellent company. Had the parts been tailored for the separate artists, they could not have fitted more exactly. Mr. JOHN WALLACK is perfectly excellent as the stuttering hero, who loves his wife, and yet is divorced from her. The character requires tact and good taste. Miss MADELINE HENRIQUES, as the young and pouing wife, was equally admirable. It is one of her very best Impersonations, and the merit is more particularly due to her as the part itself is embarrassing. Mr. GILBERT's Sir Richard, Mr. NORTON's Diogenes, Mr. FLOYD's Yawley, Miss MARY GANNON's Atalanta, and Miss FANNY MORANT's Lady Selina Raffleticket, were all equally good. Nothing indeed can be better played than this little piece, which we may here add has been placed on the stage with the usual elegance of the establishment.

abstract: We need not epitomise in this place the War Department bulletin of this morning, for it is in itself an epitome of victorious results that could not be condensed, and will assuredly be read in full by every man, woman and ...
lead_paragraph: We need not epitomise in this place the War Department bulletin of this morning, for it is in itself an epitome of victorious results that could not be condensed, and will assuredly be read in full by every man, woman and eligible child in the country. The bulletin comprises dispatches from both SHERMAN and THOMAS; and in both cases and in every detail, they are all that the most sanguine and hopeful patriot could desire. The fact that SHERMAN himself announces his trip to have been an "agreeable" one, unmolested by guerrillas, that he found abundant supplies and that his army was in splendid condition, disposes of the whole of the abominable rebel trash about him which we have been compelled to lay before our readers for the last four weeks. While the fact that he announces the capture of Fort McAllister and its garrison, and the complete investment of Savannah with its garrison of 15,000 men, and its population of 25,000 gives ground for his assurance that it is already as good as captured. It is impossible for the rebels to feed this population of 40,000 for any length of time. Gen. THOMAS dispatch is also itself an epitome. His victory of Thursday at Nashville he followed up on Friday, continued to follow op on Saturday, and probably kept on following up yesterday. He has now got the rebels below Franklin; and from all the dispatches we calculate he has taken full ten thousand prisoners. If this be so, he cannot have destroyed, in the three days, less than half of HOOD's invading army. Gen. THOMAS gives the outlines of several of the actions. The most important action, apart from those of the main army, is that of Gen. ROUSSEAU at Murfreesboro, in which the rebel Gen. FORREST is reported killed, and 1,500 of his men captured.

abstract: In our special Washington dispatches this morning may be found the pith of a singular article from the Richmond Enquirer on the subject of arming and emancipating the ...
lead_paragraph: In our special Washington dispatches this morning may be found the pith of a singular article from the Richmond Enquirer on the subject of arming and emancipating the slaves. There is internal evidence in the article that the writer has been more or less officially inspired. The argument is, that when the South has already come down so far from its independent stand-point as to supplicate foreign nations for help, it must be prepared to receive such help on the conditions on which alone it will be given, viz.; the abolition of slavery. If the Confederacy, moreover, agree to abolish slavery, the writer contends, it will not be necessary to go to European nations for protection; they will at once accord recognition to the South, and follow it up, if necessary, with forcible intervention. Minor arguments, based on the special military exigencies of the crisis, are advanced to show that arming and emancipating the slaves are not only measures of possible expediency, but that they are measures absolutely necessary to the continued existence of the Southern conspiracy. Gen. LEE's opinion is cited by the Enquirer to sustain the policy it urges. And we have no doubt that the editor, by this time, might draw a considerable number of additional arguments on the same side, from the progress of affairs around Nashville, Wilmington and Savannah.
