abstract: -If we have not  referred to Signor Victor (educated in Italy) in a preliminary way, it has been from motives of prudence. With every disposition to be valiant, there ...
lead_paragraph: -If we have not referred to Signor Victor (educated in Italy) in a preliminary way, it has been from motives of prudence. With every disposition to be valiant, there seemed, in this instance, a chance of becoming foolhardy. Since the advent of Signor Victor, the newspapers, the brick piles, the fences, the vacant lots, have bristled with fierce annunciations of his undaunted spirit; with galloptious rhapsodies on his own genius; with withering expressions of contempt for other people's infirmities, and with rather disturbing allusions to his skill in the use of small arms. Not having been educated in Italy ourselves, we have -- as a mere matter of honest pride -- longed for an opportunity of calling Signor Victor a humbug. What, indeed, could be more conclusive on the subject than the fact of his being educated in a country whose chief industry is organ-grinding, and principal export maccaroni. But we would have fallen into a grave error if we had given way to our patriotic feelings. Signor Victor is no humbug. He is an artist of rare parts, and is the civilest creature we have ever met. It does pot detract from the Signor's merits [that] he possesses a tall. As a tall, it is remarkably well proportioned, and curls gracefully at the end. In a word, Signor Victor is a monkey, and having been educated in Italy, is a credit to the Mother of Arts. He possesses all the natural graces of his kind, and many of the accomplishments of the two-legged animal. He is never tedious, however. Go and see him by all means.

abstract: The matinee on Saturday was brilliantly attended, fully sixteen hundred ladies without counting the other sex being present on the occasion. The condition of the weather did not promise such a flattering result. It proves, however, that "Don ...
lead_paragraph: The matinee on Saturday was brilliantly attended, fully sixteen hundred ladies without counting the other sex being present on the occasion. The condition of the weather did not promise such a flattering result. It proves, however, that "Don Sebastian" has taken a firm hold of the public fancy. The applications at the Box office for a repetition have been so numerous that Mr. MARETZEK has concluded to give the opera once more to-night. There will be no performance at the Academy tomorrow evening, the house being required for a final rehearsal of "Fra Diavolo," which will be produced positively on the following (Wednesday) evening, The season ends with the present week.

abstract: The summary of events and opinions bearing on the release of the St. Alban's robbers which we publish in other columns to-day, presents a variety of more startling features in the case than we had previously ...
lead_paragraph: The summary of events and opinions bearing on the release of the St. Alban's robbers which we publish in other columns to-day, presents a variety of more startling features in the case than we had previously even suspected. It will be seen from the publication of the Queen's formal assent to the Extradition law of the Province, what measure of impudence entered into COURSOL's decision. The alleged absence of the Queen's assent was all that this Dogberry attempted to rest his case upon, in releasing the prisoners. And yet the act had been formally consummated by the Queen in council on the 11th of October, 1861 -- more than three years ago. Nay, the order announcing the final passage of this act was made public at the time through the Provincial Official Gazette. And it is simply trifling with the intelligence of the community to say, that COURSOL, did not know of the royal assent having been given.

abstract: The steamship Hibernian, from Liverpool on the 1st, via Londonderry, on the 2d, arrived at Portland on Saturday evening. The news by the Hibernian is five days' later than that previously reported. A brief summary of the Hibernian's report was published in our yesterday's issue. Additional details appear in other ...
lead_paragraph: The steamship Hibernian, from Liverpool on the 1st, via Londonderry, on the 2d, arrived at Portland on Saturday evening. The news by the Hibernian is five days' later than that previously reported. A brief summary of the Hibernian's report was published in our yesterday's issue. Additional details appear in other columns this morning. The passage is reported to have been exceedingly stormy. Earl RUSSEL's reply to the manifesto of the Richmond Congress, which had been communicated to him in a dispatch from the rebel commissioners, is published at length. The sum of it is that the British Government think they best consult the interests of peace, and respect the rights of all parties by observing a strict neutrality. Such neutrality Lord RUSSELL declares has been, and will continue to be maintained. There are some new outcroppings of difficulty in the Dano-German matter, Prussia demanding that the troops of Hanover and Saxony shall be withdrawn from Holstein, leaving the protection of that recently-alienated State to the Prussian army alone. The Franco-Italian Convention for the evacuation of Rome was under discussion in the Senate, and Gen DE LA MARMORA is reported to have said that the Venetian question was merely one of vanity so far as Austria was concerned. He also protested against the supposition that France coveted any portion of Italian territory. A riot had occurred at a meeting at Bristol, England, on the occasion of an intended celebration of President LINCOLN's reelection. A crowd of rebel sympathizers attempted to break up the meeting, but they were ultimately over powered by the aid of the police, and expelled from the room. The ship Great Western, with a large number of supposed recruits for the United States army, has finally sailed from Liverpool. The law officers of the Crown did not see sufficient reason for adopting legal proceedings. The death of DAVID ROBERTS, the artist, is announced. The destruction of a great Liverpool warehouse, valued with its contents at 200,000 sterling, is announced. The British export returns for October show a great falling off. The French press (of opposite politics) are discussing the possibility of President JUAREZ commissioning Mexican privateers to attack the commerce of France on the high seas. Dr. WINSLOW, the American missionary, is reported to have died at the Cape of Good Hope. The case of the Rappahannock had been fixed for the 5th of December, to come before the Court of Queen's Bench. The Inman steamer City of Cork, from Liverpool Nov. 30, arrived at this port at a late hour last night Her news is mainly anticipated by the Hibernian.

abstract: An order has been promulgated by the Secretary of State which makes it incumbent that all persons, excepting those who come under ...
lead_paragraph: An order has been promulgated by the Secretary of State which makes it incumbent that all persons, excepting those who come under the class of emigrants, hereafter arriving in the United States, shall show a passport from the Consul or Minister of the State to which they belong. This is, of course, mainly intended to apply to incomers from the neighboring Canadian Provinces. The people of the Colonies have their own judicial and executive officers to thank for this disagreeable change in the terms of intercourse between the two countries. The passport is a very great nuisance we all admit. But it must be borne with until a different sort of neutrality comes to be practiced over the border.

abstract: Neglect of Soldiers Arriving in
lead_paragraph: -- There were forty or fifty soldiers, many of them sick and wounded, left yesterday afternoon, for two or three hours, on the pavement round the station at Twenty-seventh-street, previous to the departure of the Boston train. Why men should be brought to the station in ambulances, and then dumped on the sidewalk, to sit on door-steps or stand in slush, we do not know; but we do know that such things ought not to happen, and it is a disgrace to the city that they should happen. A large number of sick and disabled men pass through New-York nearly every day, on their way East, and either the station ought to be open and warmed for their reception on Sundays, at whatever hour they may arrive, or else there ought to be a waiting-room provided in the neighborhood for their accommodation.

abstract: Unemployed Generals; Generals Unemployed to be Dropped
snippet: Unemployed Generals; Generals Unemployed to be Dropped
lead_paragraph: The House of Representatives has passed a bill providing that all Generals who shall not, on a fixed day in February, have been in actual service, shall cease to be connected with the army. We hope the Senate will consider with some care the scope and effect of this bill before they give it their sanction. Unquestionably many of the Generals now on the roll may and should be dropped for the good of the service; but we doubt whether the way proposed in this bill for determining who those Generals are, is the best that can be devised. Commanders in the field are not always above the ordinary weaknesses, prejudices, errors, and resentments of mortality; and they may, from very inadequate motives, keep subordinates out of active employment long enough to bring them under the operation of this proposed law, and thus inflict on them from neglect or wantonness a penalty which should only follow conviction for some offence recognized by the military law.

abstract: Winslow, Dr Myron
lead_paragraph: This distinguished Missionary and Oriental scholar, as we learn of the last arrival from Europe, died at the Cape of Good Hope, while on his way from India to England. He was seventy-six years of age, and had been forty-five years in the service of the American Board. No just conception of his valuable and eventful life can be given in this place, and we merely give a few facts of his career.

abstract: Rev. JOHN W. CHADWICK, late graduate of the Divinity School at Harvard College, who has been preaching for two months for the Second Unitarian Church of Brooklyn, has received and accepted a unanimous call to the pastorship of the church. He is to be both ordained and installed on the 21st of the month, in which services several of the most distinguished ministers of the Unitarian sect are to officiate, including Rev. Drs. Bellows, Osgood and Prothingham, of this city; Rev. Messrs. Putnam and Bianchard, of Brooklyn; Rev. Samuel Longfellow, of Cambridge, (former pastor of this church, and brother of the poet Longfellow;) Rev. Mr. May, of Syracuse, and Rev. Mr. Collyer, of Chicago -- the latter to preach the sermon on the occasion. That Mr. CHADWICK should be asked to succeed Messrs. LONGFELLOW and STAPLES (the two former pastors) is exceedingly complimentary.

abstract: Col. CHARLES T. abstract: Mexico; Mr. Davis' House Resolution on; Resolutions on Mexico
snippet: Mexico; Mr. Davis' House Resolution on; Resolutions on Mexico
lead_paragraph: We hope Hon. WINTER DAVIS feels better. The House of Representatives has passed his resolution censuring the intermeddling of the State Department with Foreign Affairs. If that body would now indorse his vehement denunciation of President LINCOLN for disapproving a bill which he had favored, we might reasonably hope for Mr. DAVIS' temporary acquiescence in the action of the Administration. As it is, we can only hope that he will not overthrow it before the short remainder of his Congressional term expires.

abstract: Christmas and Holiday Literature
lead_paragraph: Did we not, each of us, possess in our own instincts inward monitors of the course of the changing seasons and the waning year, the booksellers' shops alone, would, in their present dazzling aspect, be sufficient to remind us of the near approaching festival of Christendom the holy season when the reconciliation of heaven and earth is symbolized by the extension of kindly sympathies and the increased glow of family affections. These emotions naturally seek expression through the interchange of gifts of whatever is rare, curious, and valuable in itself, or precious from its association with the giver, and to the gratification of tastes so laudable our storekeepers are only too happy to minister. The gauzy flutter of light Summer reading that marked the traveling season of the year at our book depots, has given place to the solid Morocco or Russia covered volumes, "rich with burnished gold," that, ranged in tempting array, appeal mutely to those who love the best literature in the best possible garb, and can imagine no present of more sterling value for the one beloved object than the book over which they have hung enamored. There is something so consonant to the physical aspect of nature and the current of human feelings in the Calendar of the Church, that it is not surprising that its holidays and festivals should be gradually working their way into the general sense of communities but partially loyal to its doctrines and ritual. Thus, "Christmas Day" -- treated fifty years ago with comparative indifference and small respect -- now stands between the Puritan "Thanksgiving" and the Knickerbocker "New-Year's Day," not detracting from their special observance, but tacitly felt by all to be the chief festive season of the year, and as such, the cynosure of the booksellers, jewelers and fancy goods' dealers -- the subject of their cherished plans and enterprises for months past, now culminating to the light of day. Our business at present is with the book trade, and, not to be deterred from our purpose of giving a few serviceable hints to the purchasing public, we must turn an unappreciative eye to the less intellectual splendor of Broadway, that require the poet's pen and the painter's colors to do them the justice they require.

abstract: The; The Last Aspect of
lead_paragraph: Upon the close of the year we can congratulate ourselves on certain novel conditions which appear in our military struggle. The Union and rebel armies have confronted each other for three years and eight months, and during that time the intervals have been brief when the Confederates have not had in hand, immediately or prospectively, some scheme for invading the loyal States, for removing the war from their own homes to those of the North. With more or less of force to back it, this threat has always taken a shape sufficiently definite and formidable to compel us to regard it in our offensive operations. Moving against Richmond we have had to look out for Washington, and in one instance the field of battle was suddenly transferred from the banks of the Chickahominy to the Potomac. After the captures of Fort Donelson and Nashville on the Cumberland, and while we were meditating a further advance Southward, we had to retrace our steps in order to cover the line of the Ohio against BRAGG. We defeated armies in the field, we captured armies in their strongholds, but new armies took their places. We flanked them out of their cities, and then they took their turn and flanked us, and we were forced to fight new battles on old fields. The vast extent of territory open to maneuver, facilitated this sort of military operations, which were repeated so frequently, that it soon appeared inevitable that an advance into the enemy's territory must be followed by a retreat. This led near-sighted military critics here and in Europe to pronounce the war hopeless. Where was to be the end of this alternation perpetually going on, of advance and retrogression? Evidently, cried they, in the exhaustion of both parties.

abstract: Died in Southern Prisons; Necrology of Southern Prison Pens
snippet: Died in Southern Prisons; Necrology of Southern Prison Pens
lead_paragraph: In our supplement, this morning, we print another long list of Union soldiers who have perished miserably in the Southern prisons. The record is a dismal one, but thousands today will refer to it eagerly, yet timidly, in the hope of assuring themselves beyond a peradventure, of the fate of those dear to them, and as to whom their minds have been harassed by conflicting hopes and fears. Alas! to many of our readers this list will bring the confirmation of their worst surmises, and others will turn from its perusal with a sense of relief on finding that the single name for which they have been searching in the long, black roll of the martyrs, is unrecorded. But for this class, although there is yet room for hope, there must still be torturing suspense. Our list is but partial, being transcribed, in the main, from the dingy scraps, uncertain notes and fragmentary records of the comrades of the dead, whose humane desire to keep the roster of the victims was frustrated for lack of the means. It seems to be a part of the rebel policy in the treatment of our captured soldiers, that the dead shall rot in unmarked graves -- that their names shall be blotted out with their lives. As far as we can learn, the rebels kept no record themselves of the deaths in the prison-pens, and supplied no writing materials to the hospital attendants, selected from our own men, thus putting it beyond their power to pay this poor tribute of respect to the memories of their comrades. Such meanness as this is characteristic of the Southern "chivalry." It could only be practiced by men who are utterly lost to decency -- by men who are so far oblivious of the instincts of gentlemen as to rob their newly-captured prisoners of hats, shoes or meerschaum pipes, or to steal the likeness of a wife and destroy it before the eyes of her husband, accompanying the ruthless act with the indignity of ribald remarks. Quem Deus vult perdere prius dementat. Certainly in the light of the facts before us the rebels are already mad, and it requires no oracle to tell that the signs of their destruction are now gathering thick and fast.

abstract: The Secretary of War has published an order which commends itself to the judgment of every patriotic citizen, whether soldier or civilian. Mr. STANTON announces that every officer and soldier is now wanted at the front, and those who are not to-day on duty are ordered immediately to join their respective organizations. Those who neglect to conform with this mandate will find themselves -- unless they are detained at home by illness -- in the condition of deserters. We should hope that the order will be promptly and cheerfully obeyed by every soldier, whether officer or private, who deserves to wear the Union uniform. The hour of final and glorious success for the national cause hastens with rapid pace. Soldiers, to the front!

abstract: German Picture Gallery
lead_paragraph: A GERMAN PICTURE GALLERY. -- As the holidays approach it is natural that our picture galleries and art emporiums should display unusual signs of animation. Paintings have long since taken their place as a favorite means of exchange between friends who desire to be remembered with the season. And in truth there is something both practical and poetic in this giving of genuine works of art instead of a trumpery exchange of mere articles of vertu. Almost any one would prefer to have a specimen of a painter who tinges the imagination with a sense of truth obtained in the contemplation of nature, rather than possess a thing of patchwork and mere mechanical skill, tawdry to-day and useless to-morrow. The desire for pictures, owing to this or some other cause, is undoubtedly on the increase. At the present moment, three extensive galleries are open to the public, and in each instance without the exaction of an admission fee. The first is GOUPIL's well-known establishment, at the corner of Ninth-street and Broadway. The collection is both varied and extensive. Without being limited to the French school, it is yet a better exponent of it than any other, and, in fact, contains many charming specimens by its ablest masters. A recent addition is from the easel of GEROME -- one of the few paintings from his brush in this country. It is of small size, and the subject does not appeal to the popular fancy, but it is a marvelous specimen of minute work. Every line is essential to the truth, and not a superfluous speck is inserted for mere effect. The drawing is faultless, and the harmony of colors perfect. Mr. KNOEDLER selected the picture while he was in Europe last year; also many others, by well-known names, notably by FICHEL, ED. FRERE, WILLEMS, MERLE, LAMDINET, and others. They are mostly of small size, and eminently suitable for presents. A few doors below GOUPIL's is another picture gallery, owned by Mr. SNEDECOR, and recently redecorated in handsome style. Mr. SNEDECOR possesses a good collection of paintings, many of them by American artists, but the majority belong, like those at GOUPIL's, to the modern French school. There is a slight admixture of German pictures -- none of them of any particular importance.

abstract: One of the striking literary signs of the times is the extraordinary sudden passion now exhibited by book buyers and collectors for choice editions, of limited quantity and tasteful execution, which reproduce rare historical tracts or manuscripts illustrative of American history, especially of the Revolutionary era.
lead_paragraph: -- One of the striking literary signs of the times is the extraordinary sudden passion now exhibited by book buyers and collectors for choice editions, of limited quantity and tasteful execution, which reproduce rare historical tracts or manuscripts illustrative of American history, especially of the Revolutionary era. The number of these now and recently executed for printing??? and??? gentlemen is very great. The press of Mr. JOEL MUNSELL, of Albany, is a favorite medium for this class of books; but most printers, with any pretensions to the execution of fine work, have been more or less employed in this manner. A "Franklin Club" at Philadelphia, formed on the model of "The Bradford Club"of New-York, is the latest established of the printing societies. It has already issued its first volume. Among the private enterprises of the kind may be mentioned a report of a very scarce little book, exceedingly curious from its connexion with the life of AARON BURR and New-York society of the past Revolutionary times. "Memoirs of Mrs. COGHLAN, (daughter of the late Major MONCRIEFFE,) written by herself, and dedicated to the British nation, being interspersed with anecdotes of the late American and French wars, with remarks moral and political." It is undertaken by Mr. T.H. MORRELL, of Fulton-street. The edition, got up in superior style, is limited to one hundred copies, in octavo, and twenty on large paper, in quarto, at the prices respectively of five and ten dollars. Only a few remain uncontracted for.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. TEN EYCK presented a petition from citizens who had lost United States certificates, asking for indemnity. It was referred to the Judiciary Committee. Mr. SUMNER presented a petition from HENRY WARD BEECHER and three thousand citizens of New York, praying for the abolition of slavery.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. TEN EYCK presented a petition from citizens who had lost United States certificates, asking for indemnity. It was referred to the Judiciary Committee. Mr. SUMNER presented a petition from HENRY WARD BEECHER and three thousand citizens of New York, praying for the abolition of slavery. It was referred to the Committee on Slavery. Mr. WILSON presented a petition from the officers of colored troops asking for increase of pay, &c., which was referred to the Military Committee. Mr. WILSON, from the Military Committee, reported the House bill to enable aliens who have served in the army or navy to become citizens of the United States. The bill was read a first time. Mr. GRIMES asked leave to introduce a bill to create the rank of Vice-Admiral in the navy. The leave was granted and the bill referred to the Naval Committee. Mr. DOOLIITLE introduced a resolution authorizing the President to expend $10,000,000, or so much thereof as may be necessary to build fortifications and floating-batteries for the protection of the lakes and frontiers against attacks of piratical expeditions organized in the British Provinces by enemies of the United States.

abstract: The; Pennsylvania Oil-Digging
lead_paragraph: We devote some space in this issue to a special report of the progress and prospects of oil-digging in Pennsylvania. Among other points, we have a description of the route to the oil regions, the oil creek railroad, the investments which have proved profitable, and those which have proved unprofitable, the industrial picture which the oil regions of Pennsylvania at this moment present, the chances of success for those whose enterprise may tempt them to invest in oil springs, the advancing cost of production, and the increasing cost of the article produced. All these points will be found illustrated without unnecessary detail, and yet with perfect clearness.

abstract: Gen. THOMAS reports his operations of Sunday briefly, by saying that the pursuit was kept up, and several hundred more prisoners captured, among them the rebel Brig.-Gen. QUARLES, who was wounded at the battle of Franklin, and left on the roadside. In regard to the battle of Friday, Gen. THOMAS says that the entire division of the rebel Maj.-Gen. EDWARD JOHNSTON, with all its brigade commanders, was captured. The rear guard of HOOD's army was yesterday at Spring Hill, Tenn.

abstract: ??? give below the concluding portion of a long list of names (furnished recently by our correspondent who accompanied the exchange fleet to Savannah and Charleston,) of Union soldiers who have died under the terrible hardships of their treatment in the Southern prison pens. It is a dismal record. For its entire correctness our correspondent makes no claim, as it was mainly copied from small detached slips and fragments of dingy paper, each containing a single name -- the writing upon which was often nearly illegible, requiring in its slow deciphering a great expenditure of patience. Many of the names therefore are doubtless misspelled. Long as the lists of the dead have been which we have published from time to time, it is sad to reflect that they comprise but a tithe of the victims, and thousands upon thousands of our brave soldiers have been buried like dogs in unmarked graves. As nearly as can be ascertained the rebel prison authorities, generally speaking, were not themselves humane enough to have the deaths among our prisoners recorded, neither were they liberal enough to supply the cheap favor of a sufficient quantity of writing paper to the hospital attendants selected from our own men, that this last simple duty toward the dead might be properly performed. Imperfect, however, as this list is, we are sure that it will be eagerly scanned by thousands of our readers, to many of whom it will probably convey the first information of the fate of a dear relative or friend.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- AUBER's celebrated opera of "Fra Diavolo" will be produced here to-night, for the first time, in Italian. The work is known -- in an impoverished condition -- to the American stage. It has been played frequently in English; and, even in that wretched form, has been successful. The present version is new to our public. AUBER, after nearly forty years' experence of distinct triumphs reserved a very remarkable degree of strength for a revision of this work. Changing it from the French colloquial to the Italian declamatory form, he achieved a new success only four or five years ago. Instead of being a comic opera, (or work where dialogue is permissible,) it is now grand opera (where recitative is the only medium of conversation.) Five numbers are entirely new, and the connecting links are also written for the present version -- which, in fact, is a new opera.

abstract: The new call for troops has made the business at the County Volunteer Office exceedingly brisk. The determination of Mr. BLUNT to avoid a draft in this city is being fully sustained by the people. The demand for substitutes, yesterday, was greater than on any former day since the last call. The supply was equal to the demand, and quite a number paid the necessary $650.

abstract: The Paris correspondent of the London Globe says that the United States frigate Niagara has been loitering so long in the Scholdt that a wholesale desertion of her crew is seriously apprehended. A batch of 25 able-bodied men having got ashore at Antwerp from the frigate, had to be pursued to the Dutch frontier, most of them escaping into Holland.
lead_paragraph: The Paris correspondent of the London Globe says that the United States frigate Niagara has been loitering so long in the Scholdt that a wholesale desertion of her crew is seriously apprehended. abstract: The new Cunard steamer Cuba arrived here at an early hour yesterday morning, with advices via Queenstown to Dec. 4. The most important intelligence in her news is the death of Mr. DAYTON, the United States Minister at Paris. He died of apoplexy, on the 1st inst. The Union and Emancipation Society of Manchester adopted an address to President LINCOLN on the 28th ult., congratulating him upon his reelection. On the 1st, Mr. LAYARD, Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs, made a speech to his constituents on the 1st, in which he said, in reference to American affairs, that no Liberal Government would now eugage in foreign intervention. It is stated that a large number of sailors have deserted from the Niagara. GARIBALDI has accepted the yacht presented to him by a number of English ladies and gentlemen. German and Danish affairs are still unsettled, There is thought to be some danger of a rupture between Austria and Prussia. Martial law in Venetia has been abolished.

abstract: The ship Mercury, Capt. STETSON, sailed to-day for Havre, and when outside of Sandy Hook, the crew mutinied, and refused to go to sea in the vessel. The pilot, upon giving orders, was disobeyed and threatened, and upon the Captain remonstrating, he was attacked, badly beaten, and stabbed. The ship was put back, and anchored at Quarantine, where the revenue cutter at that station sent on board a boat's crew, and put the offenders in irons.
lead_paragraph: The ship Mercury, Capt. STETSON, sailed to-day for Havre, and when outside of Sandy Hook, the crew mutinied, and refused to go to sea in the vessel. abstract: Blessed in the memory of all true housewives will ever be the inventor of the sewing-machine. He is a universal benefactor, who has made easy, pleasant, and a hundred-fold profitable, one of the most important duties of woman -- to sew. He also has added lustre to the dignity of labor. Once ladies "gave out" their sewing to the seamstress and dressmaker, and few, since the days of our grandmothers, were seen with the needle in hand, either mending or making up a garment. But now, the handsomest ornament of a room is the rosewood or walnut-cased sewing-machine, and the prettiest ornament of it is the charming face and snowy fingers of the lady of the house, or her daughter, busy at the weeel, braiding, embroidering and "running the breadths" on a new dress. The choice of a machine in this day of new patents and multiplied improvements is a question of great importance, and, to many, very difficult of settlement. Every patent has its excellencies, and each well-established firm puts in claim for advantages in their peculiar machine, possessed over all competitors, and indeed it must be admitted that some of the more prominent are worthy the patronage they receive, and well adapted to the purposes of the invention.

abstract: THOMAS is pursuing the enemy to Duck River. We have nearly all HOOD'S artillery, and his army is really fearfully demoralized. All the rivers are high, and all the bridges in HOOD'S front destroyed. Our pontoons are up. We captured three thousand of the enemy's wounded at Franklin, Tenn. Since Thursday, we have captured and brought in just six thousand prisoners, making nine thousand, counting the wounded taken at Franklin.
lead_paragraph: Special Dispatch to the New-York Times.
headline: {'main': "The Fruits of General Thomas' Splendid Victory.; Nine Thousand Prisoners Captured. Sixty-one Pieces of Artillery Taken. abstract: -- The City Mission, with the official sanction of the Board of Commissioners of the Metropolitan Police, proposes to place in the Station house in each Ward, an eclectic, unsectarian collection of good books, for the intellectual entertainment and improvement of the policemen when off duty. The City Missionaries will call upon the people for donations for this purpose, and the books will be selected by a judicious committee. In a few of the wards, a beginning has already been made in this direction, and the foundation of a good library has been laid, to which additions will be welcome. But a small amount, comparatively, will be required to commence this desirable work, and we trust that a prompt and cheerful response will be given to those who have very properly taken the matter in hand.

abstract: Canadian Denunciations of
lead_paragraph: We hear from the Canadian journals of a very commendable activity on the part of the authorities, in disclaiming any complicity with the raiders, and in condemning such hostile and plundering incursions as that of St. Alban's, from their neutral territory. The Mayor of Windsor, (Canada,) writes to the Mayor of Detroit, regretting these violations of neutrality, and hoping for peaceful relations in future between the two peoples. The municipality of Hamilton condemns in the strongest terms such robbing expeditions as those of the St. Alban's thieves, and urges the strictest precautions on the part of their own officials to put a stop to them. Other towns and other public meetings of Canadian citizens assert their regard for neutrality and their desire to do their duty in this matter, in equally strong terms. The Provincial press is full of denunciations of COURSOL, bought with stolen money, and the Montreal Chief-of-Police, whom they assert to have been bribed with the funds deposited with him. The provincial militia in one district is called out, to protect the frontier, and especial magistrates are empowered to watch the border towns, and prevent by energetic means any future attempts at murder and robbery, such as shocked the security of the peaceful Vermont villages.

abstract: March, and Rebellion Discouraged
lead_paragraph: The rebellion, from the beginning, has lived only on delusions. The delusion that the Northern people had not the courage to fight the delusion that the Government would be fettered by the Democratic party so that it could not fight, if it would the delusion that even if there were fighting, foreign Powers, constrained by their necessities for cotton, would speedily interfere to put a stop to it -- the delusion that the spirit of volunteering would quickly die out in the North, and that there would be no other practicable means of keeping up the National armies -- the delusion that the accumulating debt of the Government must soon break down its financial system, and plunge the North into helpless ruin -- the delusion that the North could be successfully invaded and frightened into peace -- were what sustained the rebellion all through its first period of existence. These delusions were gradually dispelled, one after another.

abstract: New; Reasons for Enforcement
lead_paragraph: The journals that are disposed to question the judgment of the Government in ordering a new draft, present various reasons of some weight to support their argument. They show how unproductive previous drafts have been. They make a strong point of it, that volunteering, after all, must be the prime resource of the War Department; and that populous districts, like New-York, have done their duty without any stimulus beyond that which the liberality of the corporation and of private citizens has supplied.

abstract: The President has issued a proclamation, calling for 300,000 men for the military and naval service, to serve for one, two, or three years. The quotas for the different States will be immediately assigned by the War Department. If they are not made up by volunteering by the 15th of February, 1865, a draft will be ordered to take place.

abstract: Cuba, Cunard S S, Description of
snippet: Cuba, Cunard S S, Description of
lead_paragraph: The new Cunard steamship Cuba, Capt. STONE, left Liverpool, on the 3d inst., about noon, and arrived at this port yesterday morning. The following is a description of the vessel: Her model combines fine proportions and great speed. The dimensions of her hull are: Length of keel and foretake, 327 feet; length over all, 350 feet; breadth of beam, moulded, 42 feet 6 inches; depth, moulded, to spar deck, 29 feet. She has a tonnage of 2,832, by builder's measurement. In accordance with the most approved of marine construction, the Cuba is built in nine watertight compartments, four of which come to the upper deck. She has accommodations for 300 first-class passengers, and is capable of transporting 1,500 troops. The propelling power is provided by oscillating-geared engines of 650-horse power each, nominal, fitted with surface condensers and all the recent improvements. The steam for the engines is provided by four boilers, heated by twenty-four furnaces. The cylinders have a diameter of eigty-two inches, and the piston a stroke of six feet. The rig of the Cuba is similar to that of the other screw mail steamers of the Cunard service.

abstract: Death of
lead_paragraph: The Gold Room reacted, yesterday, from the rapid decline of Monday. The range of sales Were 227@220 @221 cent., the last figure quoted at 3 o'clock. Government stocks were less firm on the disappointed expectation that notice of the early withdrawal of the 10-40 Loan would be announced from Washington after the heavy subscriptions of yesterday. The Railways generally better in the morning, but left off dull. Money active at 7 cent.

abstract: News to the 9th ult. from Rio Janeiro, received per steamship Cuba, indicate that the Florida affair will undoubtedly be amicably settled with the Brazilian Government. The Correio Mercantil, of Oct. 15, says that the intimate and friendly relations existing between the United States and Brazil will not be ruptured in consequence of the seizure of the privateer.
lead_paragraph: News to the 9th ult. from Rio Janeiro, received per steamship Cuba, indicate that the Florida affair will undoubtedly be amicably settled with the Brazilian Government. The Correio Mercantil, of Oct. 15, says that the intimate and friendly relations existing between the United States and Brazil will not be ruptured in consequence of the seizure of the privateer. It has no doubt but that this Government will grant the reparation required, and regards Mr. WEBB's letter as entirely satisfactory. It also regrets that the people of Bahia should have so far forgotten their dignity as to make an uncalled-for attack upon the honor and dignity of the United States, as represented in the person of its Consul and his office at Bahia.

abstract: What shall it be? For the child, something suited to the sex, useful and diverting -- not for the moment only, then to be cast aside -- but that will link year with year, and mark and improve the character. For an adult of either sex the variety is endless, suiting the infinity of circumstances. The mother and head of a family has learned to prize most what lightens the household burden and betokens affectionate sympathy: a Baby-Tender, Washer, Wringer, or a Wheeler & Wilson Sewing-Machine. The first are winning their way to public favor; the last is old and well fried. There is no question of its utility and suitableness as a present of affection and charity. Its low-toned voice will prove a sweet reminder of friendship and effective sympathy, and mingle with the hymn of thankfulness. Try it for your own or Pastor's wife, or the widow tolling for the support of her children. -- Commercial Advertiser.

abstract: Layard, A. H., on the American War
snippet: Layard, A. H., on the American War
lead_paragraph: Mr. A.H. LAYARD, M.P., Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs, made a speech to his constituents on Dec. 1, in the course of which he referred to American topics as follows: He did not believe it possible that any liberal government would now engage in foreign intervention or enter into another Holy Alliance. But to abstain altogether from foreign politics was quite another matter. We could not hold aloof from Europe -- remaining apart from all that occurred on the continent -- refusing to mediate when our mediation might lead to peace. If that was what was intended by the advocates of non-intervention, then it was that intervention would be most dangerous to this country. We must, hovever, always exercise that intervention with caution, and due consideration for others as well as ourselves. We should not interfere unless agreeable to the parties concerned. The United States had been quoted as an example of non intervention, but a more unfortunate example could not be produced. The United States did not interfere with European politics, because they were not part of the European family, but on their own continent they carried the principle further than we did, and claimed the right to prevent any combination of other States that might possibly interfere with their form of Government or liberties. He denied that the debate of last session had changed the foreign policy of this country. That debate was a great party struggle. The opposition had began to think that there was a great conservative reaction, but in the division they found out their mistake, and that there was an enormous majority of the constituencies of England and Wales in favor of the Government.
headline: {'main': 'MR. A.H. LAYARD ON THE WAR.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'MR. A.H. LAYARD ON THE WAR.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The last arrival from Europe brings the painful intelligence that Hon. WILLIAM LEWIS DAYTON. United States Minister at the French Court, died on the 1st instant of apoplexy. Mr. DAYTON was born at Baskingridge, in New-Jersey, Feb. 17, 1807. He graduated at the College of New-Jersey in September, 1825, and was admitted to the practice of law in 1830. In 1837 he was elected member of the State Senate, and in the following year was chosen by the Legislature one of the Associate Judges of the Supreme Court of New-Jersey. He held this position till 1841. Upon the decease of S.L. SOUTHARD, United States Senator in 1842, he was appointed to fill the vacancy. In March, 1845, he was elected by the Legislature for the full term of six years, and served in the Senate to March 4, 1851. He was superseded by Mr. R.F. STOCKTON, and began again the practice of the law at Trenton. In 1856 he was nominated for the Vice-Presidency upon the Fremont ticket. In March, 1857, he was appointed Attorney-General of New-Jersey. Upon the election of Mr. LINCOLN, Mr. DAYTON was appointed Minister to France, and discharged the difficult and responsible duties of his office with credit to himself and the country which he represented.

abstract: GILL, of the New-York, Philadelphia and Liverpool Steamship Company's line, was unladen and made ready for sea with a celerity highly creditable to all concerned. The Glasgow arrived on Friday morning, more than a week overdue, and after discharging the passengers, came to her pier at 2 o'clock P.M. Her entire cargo of nearly one thousand tons was unladen, and seven hundred tons of coal and a full return cargo loaded by 12 o'clock on Saturday night. The Glasgow sailed at an early hour on Sunday morning, only fifteen hours behind time. Such evidences of energy speak highly of the admirable manner in which this line is conducted.

abstract: Lee's Letter on Arming Slaves; Gen. Lee and Richmond Enquirer on; Last Resort; Arming Slaves
snippet: Lee's Letter on Arming Slaves; Gen. Lee and Richmond Enquirer on; Last Resort; Arming Slaves
lead_paragraph: The statement of the Richmond Enquirer that Gen. LEE has written a letter to the Committee on Military Affairs in the rebel House, in favor of arming the slaves, virtually settles that this experiment will soon be tried. The military judgment of that General is authority not to be appealed from in the Confederacy on any military question. It is in its military bearing alone that this subject is now discussed. The universal feeling of the rebels is that military success alone can save them. Their only hesitation about arming the slaves has been the doubt whether the slaves will do effective military service, and whether there was yet an actual military necessity for that resort. Gen. LEE's demand that the experiment shall be at once tried, settles the matter, and we may expect soon to see the measure in practical operation.

abstract: Since the call by President LINCOLN for 300,000 more men, with an order for a draft on the 15th of February if they are not raised by volunteering before that time, the people have anxiously turned to the County Volunteer Committee to know how far New-York is prepared to meet the call, and what is the prospect of escaping the draft. The committee can answer these questions very readily.
lead_paragraph: Since the call by President LINCOLN for 300,000 more men, with an order for a draft on the 15th of February if they are not raised by volunteering before that time, the people have anxiously turned to the County Volunteer Committee to know how far New-York is prepared to meet the call, and what is the prospect of escaping the draft. The committee can answer these questions very readily. They have three times filled the quota without much outside assistance, and they can fill it again; but they must have help from a cooperative movement of every man and woman in the city who is interested in the effort to avoid a draft to fill up our armies and to see justice done the city in the matter of the enrollment. It is idle to indulge hopes that the quota will be again filled by some providential discovery of neglected credits, or by allowing the three year men enlisted as so many one-year men, multiplying the number of that class by three in crediting them; it is useless to hope that the seven thousand naval recruits credited to Brooklyn will be transferred to New-York. All expedients of this kind have been exhausted, and New-York will have to raise her quota by furnishing the men asked for in able bodied recruits for the army or navy. There is no cause for despair in this. On the contrary, it needs only a combined and determined effort on the part of all our citizens, to assist the committee, and the men will be raised within the fifty days. Our account with the Government stands thus:

abstract: Where to Get them
lead_paragraph: If we may judge from the appearance of Broadway and other business streets, the approaching holidays promise to be among the most gay and widely enjoyed of any that have come upon us for several years past. The dark phantom of rebellion seems to be rapidly vanishing away under the fatal blasts that it has lately received from SHERMAN, SHERIDAN and THOMAS, and the loyal people of the North at last begin to discover the end of their troubles, and are thus just in a mood to enjoy the festivities of Christmas and New-Year with a zest unknown since the breaking out of the war. The exchange of presents and tokens of affection -- always among the most pleasing incidents of the festive season -- will certainly not be loss liberal this year, than heretofore, and a brief notice of the ample preparations made by our shopkeepers for supplying the public wants in this respect, may not be uninteresting to our readers.

abstract: Second Capture of
lead_paragraph: in his dispatch, mentions that in the operations of Friday last, below Nashville, "Major-General EDWARD JOHNSTON's entire division, with all the brigade commanders, was captured on the works which were carried by assault." It will be remembered that this rebel Major-Gen. EDWARD JOHNSTON, who is again in our hands, was the genius who was captured with his entire division at Spottsylvania Court-house, by Gen. BARLOW, in May last, during the advance of Gen. GRANT upon Richmond. Thus he has been twice captured in a short period, and each time the division of rebels which he commanded has been captured with him. In other days, JOHNSTON belonged to the Sixth Regular Regiment of United States Infantry, was in the same brigade with GRANT, and was an old friend of Gen. MEADE, Gen. HUNT, Chief of Artillery, and many other of our best known officers. When captured in May last, he was described by an army correspondent of the TIMES as a "stout-built fellow, with a strong, rough face, his dress in bad condition, and his slouched hat, with his brownish gray hair sticking through an aperture at the top, such as even a New-York dead rabbit would scorn to sport." JOHNSTON has been a very unlucky General for the rebels.

abstract: Coursol, Police Justice, Antecedents
lead_paragraph: We publish, in another column, a communication from a responsible citizen of Montreal, on the antecedents of Police Justice COURSOL, and the incidents of the trial at which he has gained his present notoriety. It seems that COURSOL earned his judgeship by doing heavy political duty, for many years, at election times, as a Plug-Ugly or Dead Rabbit. The title, in the Provinces, we understand, is "Short Boy." Our readers, probably, don't care to know much more about COURSOL, after this. The influences which secured him his appointment may possibly keep him there; although, judging from the decisive action taken by the Provincial Government since COURSOL's judgment was rendered, there is a fair probability that the stipendiary will be required to resign -- if, indeed, it should not turn out that he is liable to a criminal indictment for receiving bribes.

abstract: Attention Called to Customs Abases; Abuses; Custom-house Abuses. (Ed.)
snippet: Attention Called to Customs Abases; Abuses; Custom-house Abuses. (Ed.)
lead_paragraph: We have heretofore had occasion to notice, approvingly, certain Custom-house reforms initiated by Collector DRAPER since his installation to office. The effect of his vigorous action in reference to bonded warehouse extortions has been to reduce the exactions for storage, in some cases that have come to our knowledge, seventy-five per cent.; so that where merchants were, a few months ago, compelled to pay twenty dollars, they are now called upon to pay only five. This certainly is an auspicious beginning, and leads us to hope that a great deal more in the same direction will be accomplished before the work closes.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC PRODUCTION OF FRA DIAVOLO. In the matter of weather Mr. MARETSEK is certainly an unfortunate manager. His best pecuniary intentions are frequently frustrated by the unkindliness of the elements. Whenever, in fact, it...
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC -- PRODUCTION OF FRA DIAVOLO. -- In the matter of weather Mr. MARETSEK is certainly an unfortunate manager. His best pecuniary intentions are frequently frustrated by the unkindliness of the elements. Whenever, in fact, it seems certain that the "house" will be of a sort to cheer the heart of the Treasurer, the unpitying heavens unbosom themselves, and slush prevails. Such a day as yesterday, was, indeed, calculated to try men's soles. The ancient Egyptians, it is well known, were in the habit, on all festive occasions, of passing round a small coffin containing a perfect representation of a dead body. The attendant who performed this cheerful office, exclaimed, "Cast your eyes on this figure; after death you will be like it; drink then and be happy." Mr. MARETZEK, we are informed, preserves the custom, adapting it to the necessities of the time. In the roseate moments of managerial exaltation, an official approaches him with the effigies of an umbrella and a pair of over-thoes. "Cast your eyes," he exclaims, "upon these terrors; after rehearsal you will want them." The remainder of the exhortation is the same as in the original Egyptian.

abstract: Measures to Unite
lead_paragraph: -We are glad to see that measures are in progress which promise to bring about a termination of the dissensions in the ranks of the Union party in this city. The State Committee recently appointed Messrs. W.R. STEWART and R.F. ANDREWS to devise some plan for superseding both the existing organizations by one which should represent the feelings and sentiments of the Union party. These gentlemen have discharged that duty in a manner which enlists the assent of both parties: the details of their proposition will be found set forth in our advertising columns. Both the Darling and Draper Committees, and all the local committees connected with them, are to be dissolved: and a new Central Committee is to be elected, consisting of seven members from each Assembly District. At the election, those persons only will be allowed to vote who shall have previously been enrolled in their respective districts: and all who may desire it will be enrolled upon their affirmation that they voted for LINCOLN and JOHNSON at the late election. Inspectors to superintend this enrollment have been appointed in each district. This evening is the last evening for the enrollment. We trust this arrangement will put an end to differences and dissensions which have injured and discredited the Union party in this city for some years past.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, petitions were presented, and referred to the proper committees, in relation to the transportation of periodicals in the overland mail; to the increase of pay of army officers, and to the extension of an India-rubber pa-...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, petitions were presented, and referred to the proper committees, in relation to the transportation of periodicals in the overland mail; to the increase of pay of army officers, and to the extension of an India-rubber patent. The House bill in reference to the tax on whisky, was passed after some debate. Mr. CARLAN's resolution in reference to the oath of allegiance for the District of Columbia was debated at some length and passed. The Senate then took up the resolution to repeal the Reciprocity Treaty with Great Britain. After some debate further consideration of the resolution was deferred until the 6th of January.

abstract: The steamship Fulton, from Port Royal Dee, 18, arrived at this port yesterday. The Fulton touched at Foriress Monroe to land Lieut.-Col. O. E. BABCOCK, bearer of dispatches from Gen. SHERMAN to the War Department; also, Col. A....
lead_paragraph: The steamship Fulton, from Port Royal Dee, 18, arrived at this port yesterday. The Fulton touched at Foriress Monroe to land Lieut.-Col. O. E. BABCOCK, bearer of dispatches from Gen. SHERMAN to the War Department; also, Col. A.H. MARKLAND, Gen. SHEREAN's mail agent, who had delivered the great mail to the army on the 16th. Savannah was still in the hands of the Confederates. Its surrender had not been demanded by Gen. SHERMAN up to the time of the sailing of the Fulton. From Richmond papers of the 19th, and Charleston papers of the 16th, we learn that some fighting had occurred on the 14th. The Ogeeche River Bridge had been burned, and a large body of rebel troops coming from Florida and the Southwest thereby cut off. HARDEE, with 12,000 to 15,000 troops, was inside the city, and could nor get away. The Savannah papers were whistling to keep their courage up.

abstract: Exchange, the Special, Finished
lead_paragraph: -- We are advised by our correspondent at Port Royal of the conclusion of the special exchange business at Charleston. The last boat-load of the miserable victims of rebel cruelty was brought down and delivered on the 16th inst., making an aggregate of upward of eleven thousand who have been released. On the 17th inst. the siege of Charleton was resumed, and hostilities are probably now in fiercer progress, after the brief respite during the continuance of the truce. The exchange just concluded was brought about solely through the efforts of Lieut.-Col. JOHN E. MULFORD, the Assistant Agent for Exchange, who has conducted the whole delicate business with singular ability and prudence. Col. MULFORD has long been known as an accomplished officer, and a noble-souled gentleman. His name, which, from his long connection with the matter of exchanges, has been a household word in thousands of families, will hereafter be doubly endeared to the soldiers just released, on account of his unflagging and active personal interest in all that could add to their comfort and welfare.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- AUBER's charming comic opera of "Fra Dlavolo" will be given here to-night for the second time in America. The work, on its production, Wednesday night, achieved an unmistakable success -- a result which was merited, both by the music and the manner it was rendered. It was no slight task to bring out a light work of this character with artists who have exclusively been accustomed to a totally different and much stiffer school. Mr. MARETZEK has succeeded in a remarkable degree, and the enjoyment of the audience on Wednesday night proved that he has once more struck the public taste.

abstract: Farragut, Vice-Admiral; Salting Streets Abated; Death of
snippet: Farragut, Vice-Admiral; Salting Streets Abated; Death of
lead_paragraph: Congress and the Executive displayed the most admirable promptitude in the matter of the bill creating the naval grade of Vice-Admiral, and in the practical application of its provisions. The bill was introduced into the Senate on Tuesday, was immediately considered and passed, was passed on the same day by the House, was next day signed by the President, who at once nominated Rear-Admiral FARRAGUT to the position, which appointment was immediately confirmed by the Senate, without the usual formality of referring it to a standing committee. Vice-Admiral FARRAGUT, who is in this city, was immediately notified by telegraph of the mark of distinction conferred upon him.

abstract: The steamship Africa, from Liverpool, Dec 10, with one week's later news, arrived at Halifax yesterday. Prof. GOLDWIN SMITH, in the London Daily News, pronounces the Army of the Potomac the best-equipped army in the world. The result of SHERMAN's operations were awaited with much interest. The obsequies of Mr. DAYTON took place on the 6th, at the American Church, in Paris Dr. SUNDERLAND performed the religious services, and a detachment of troops escorted the remains as a guard of honor. Mr. FORSTER, at a reform demonstration at Bradford, spoke in favor of the North. The Earl of Carlisle died on the 5th. All the money reward in MULLER's case has been allotted to the cab driver MATTHEWS. Gen. Tom Thumb and wife had been received by the Emperor at Compeigne. Dec. 8.

abstract: 24???th Anniversary
lead_paragraph: The two hundred and forty-fourth anniversary of the landing of the Pilgrims at Plymouth, and the fifty-fourth anniversary of the New-England Society of the City of New-York, was celebrated by a banquet at the Astor House, last evening. The dining hall of the Astor was tastefully decorated for the occasion with natural and artificial flowers, with portraits of WASHINGTON, WEBSTER and FRANKLIN, and with the national colors.

abstract: duty of Volunteering
lead_paragraph: It is so important that the rebels should not enjoy any leisure during the coming Winter, and it is so unlikely that either SHERMAN or THOMAS will let them enjoy it, if they are properly supplied with men, that we sincerely trust everybody will strain every nerve to meet the call which has just been made, not next Spring, but now. We are close on the end of the year, and yet hostilities were never carried on with greater vigor and activity on our side than at this moment. SHERMAN has, to say nothing of the City of Savannah, 15,000 men and one of the enemy's best Generals, almost in his hand; the greatest naval expedition we have ever fitted out is, probably, by this time, thundering against Wilmington; THOMAS is pressing HOOD with a tenacity which promises results as fruitful if not as brilliant as those he has already secured. In fact, there has been no period since the beginning of the war, when the Union army and navy were busier than they are at this moment, though we are already near mid-Winter.

abstract: The latest news from Gen. THOMAS places his headquarters at Columbia, Tenn., with HOOD crossing Duck River with the remnant of his army. It is estimated that he has lost fully 20,000 men since he entered Tennessee, and that his remaining force is not over 20,000, cavalry included. The country around Nashville and Franklin is filled with deserters, who are daily coming and delivering themselves up. The roads Were bad, and pursuit had become very difficult.

lead_paragraph: The two hundred and forty-fourth anniversary of the landing of the Pilgrims was celebrated by a banquet at the Astor House, last evening, given by the New-England Society of the City of NewYork. Among the guests present who addressed the meeting were Vice Admiral Farragut, Commodore Drayton, Capt. Winslow, of the Kearsarge, Geo. Bancroft, William Cullen Bryant, Hon. Mr. Phelps, of Maryland, Rev. E.H. Chapin, Chas. P. Kirtland, Hon. E.W. Gantt and others. Letters were read from the President and the different members of the Cabinet, O.W. Holmes, Govs Fenton and Andrew, Geo. W. Curtis and others. At the business meeting of the N.E. Society held yesterday, the following officers were elected for the ensuing year: President -- WILLIAM CURTIS NOYES. First Vice-President, Joseph H. Choate; Second Vice-President, Elliot C. Cowdin; Councellors, E.D. Morgan, W.N. Blakeman, C.A. Stetson, S.N. Stebbins; Assistant Counsellors, Nathaniel Hayden, John W. Quincy, Wm. Borden, Frank E. Howe, T.G. Churchill, W.H. Lee, Isaac H. Bailey, Chas. S. Smith; Treasurer, Luther B. Wyman; Secretary, L.P. Hubbard.

abstract: We know of nothing that would be more suitable as a present for a lady than a Grover & Baker Sewing Machine; indeed, any good sewing machine would be a desirable present, but GROVER & BAKER's is par excellence the family machine. Beautiful in appearance, it will be an ornament to the boudoir; simple in its construction, it will be easily learned and successfully operated; its movements are so noiseless, that it will not disturb the quiet of the domestic fireside. It is capable of doing any kind of work done by the sewing machine, and, in addition, embroiders to perfection. It will lighten the labor, promote the health, and prove a source of perpetual pleasure and profit to the owner. -- N.Y. Leader.

abstract: About 11 o'clock last night, the attention of persons in the street was drawn to three brilliant globes of light that appeared almost directly in the zenith. They were supposed to be a reflection of the great fire then raging in Beekman-street; but the atmosphere was clear, and there was not a vestige of cloud in the sky. The globes slowly melted together and formed a line of light, which gradually faded away.

abstract: Common Council Gifts to Charities; Sherman's Humanity at
snippet: Common Council Gifts to Charities; Sherman's Humanity at
lead_paragraph: The Common Council have at length awaked to the necessity of retrenchment. After having, during the past year, wasted and squandered money on a great variety of objects; after the voting $5,000 of the people's taxes to a purely sectarian institution, such as the College of "St. Francis Xavier;" after liberal gifts to all Roman Catholic charities, such as $30,000 to the "St. Joseph's Asylum," $15,000 to the "Society for Destitute Catholic Children," and within a few days $2,000 to a certain unknown Industrial School of a "Sister Theresa" in Forty-second street;

abstract: The reelection of President LINCOLN was not simply a declaration of sentiment. It was a pledge. The people affirmed not merely that the rebellion ought to be put down, but that it should be put down; and they bound themselves to supply President LINCOLN with the money and the men necessary to that end. His new call for three hundred thousand more men must be met with promptitude and cheerfulness.

abstract: We noticed in Thursday's TIMES a few of the places where our readers can find holiday presents suitable for the season, but a want of space compelled us to omit many others to be found in our advertising columns where articles of equal excellence and variety tempt the seeker after the useful, the beautiful, or the curious. In fact the whole business portion ...
lead_paragraph: We noticed in Thursday's TIMES a few of the places where our readers can find holiday presents suitable for the season, but a want of space compelled us to omit many others to be found in our advertising columns where articles of equal excellence and variety tempt the seeker after the useful, the beautiful, or the curious. In fact the whole business portion of our city seems to be transformed into one grand curiosity shop for the display of holiday gifts; and old Santa Claus variously disguised in pantaloons and petticoats, broadcloth and silks, representing manhood and youth, matron and miss, can be seen hurrying about our streets, peering into the shop-windows, dodging in and out of doorways, in search of gifts suitable to the multitudinous tastes and wants of the legions who delight to call him friend and are anxiously looking for his coming. Alas! that we should so often encounter him dressed in the habiliments of mourning and with a weed upon his hat. The devastating war that has afflicted our dear land for four years past has snatched the protector from many a hearthstone, and the cherubs that gather around those chimney-corners on next Sabbath morning will gaze with tear-dimmed eyes upon the annual gifts which good Santa Claus has brought them. Let our citizens see to it that no dead soldier's home goes unvisited by him, albeit his ruddy and jovial countenance is unused to the sorrowing mood. Following in his wake let us extend our tour in search of Christmas and New-Year's presents, which shall dispel the gloom from all faces and bless alike the giver and the receiver.

abstract: Humanity acknowledged by Richmond Sentinel; Army, the Chivalry of
snippet: Humanity acknowledged by Richmond Sentinel; Army, the Chivalry of
lead_paragraph: THE CHIVALRY OF SHERMAN's ARMY. -- We are glad to see that the rebels are beginning to take back the atrocious falsehoods which they have been putting forth broadcast about the conduct of SHERMAN'S army in its march through Georgia. It is true that the splendid condition and morale of that army at this day, and at the close of its long march, alone furnishes sufficient evidence that the rebel stories about their having behaved in a reckless manner were all false. Had our men acted in the way the rebels alleged, they would have reached Savannah a huge demoralized, unbridled, uncontrollable mob, instead of the compact, solid, harmonious, well-ordered army that they were. The rebels tried to fire the Southern heart by accusing our troops of every conceivable and inconceivable outrage -- pillaging, ravaging, ravishing, murdering, insulting the living and despoiling the dead. The Richmond Sentinel, however, is now kind enough to begin by taking back one of the worst of these charges, and one which the rebel leaders evidently thought would have a tremendous effect in stirring up the Georgians -- the charge that the tombs of their fathers were being desecrated by our soldiers. The Sentinel now says it has the information that the "dwelling-houses in Atlanta are in a much better condition than was anticipated -- that the city park was not converted into a cemetery, as had been reported, nor were the vaults in the cemetery desecrated." We are glad that even at this late hour the rebels are beginning to tell the truth; by-and-bye they will doubtless be willing to concede what is the fact -- that there never was a military march conducted more purely on strictly military principles, or one in which as great regard was had to the principles of civilization and order, or one in which as great kindness or as true chivalry was exhibited for the population amid which the march was made.

abstract: CHURCH OF THE INCARNATION, MADISON-AVENUE, THIRTY-FIFTH-STREET. -- We understand that one hundred thousand dollars' worth of pews have been sold in the new Church of the Incarnation, corner of Madison-avenue and Thirty-fifth-street. Premiums have also been received to the amount of about twenty thousand dollars. The gifts to the parish amount to twenty-five thousand dollars more. The church will be consecrated as soon as the arrangements can be made for the interesting service. The success recorded above is believed to be without a parallel in the history of the Protestant Episcopal Church in this or any other city.

abstract: The Central Railroad of New-Jersey, for the West, by way of Allentown and Pittsburgh, will leave Pier No. 2, North River, on and alter Dec.26, at 8 P.M., instead of 7 P.M., as at present.... WENDELL PHILLIPS will speak about "The Next Step," at the Cooper Institue, on Tuesday evening next.... Yesterday morning the boiler of the steam-tug Aspinwall exploded, while the vessel lay at the foot of Eighteenth-street, East River. Mr. CHOSE, the engineer, and JOHN PRYCR, a fireman, were seriously scalded. The cause of the explosion is not known.... THOMAS KERRIGAN was committed to the Tombs yesterday, for having stolen from the pocket of HENRY LONG, a watch and chain worth $150, in Nassau-street.... JOHN RILEY, and CATHARINE, his wife, were arrested for picking the pocket of Mrs. NEILL, in Washington Market. The latter lost all the money she had, $19.... Yesterday morning the boiler of the steam-tug Aspinwall exploded, while the vessel lay at the foot of Eighteenth-street, East River. abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The second performance of "Fra Diavolo" last evening attracted an exceedingly brilliant audience. AUBER's light and charming music, his easy command and use of complex dramatic situations, his remarkable facility of orchestral elaboration, and the close, short, spirited way in which he deals with the chorus -- these are points that must speedily impress the public, and, in fact, have already done so. Although the applause last night missed several of the best numbers, it yet graced others that were deserving of it. Miss KELLOGG sang deliciously. The character of Zerlina could not be better rendered by any artist on this side of the Atlantic. Signor LOTTI dazzled his admirers with a new costume, and a more becoming and appropriate one than that which he wore on Wednesday night. He was much easier in the music, and in the terzetto of the first act especially was excellent. Signor BELLINI was, as heretofore, admirable. He has made a new part. The remaining characters, with the exception of Lorenzo by Signor LORINI, who was indisposed, were interpreted well, and the chorus and orchestra were very good.

abstract: To-morrow is Christmas, the merriest of all holidays, the peculiar festival of Knickerbocker New-York, sacred to our patron saint, St. Nicholas, and to the beneficient deity of all good children, jolly old Santa Claus. To most of our readers the ...
lead_paragraph: To-morrow is Christmas, the merriest of all holidays, the peculiar festival of Knickerbocker New-York, sacred to our patron saint, St. Nicholas, and to the beneficient deity of all good children, jolly old Santa Claus. To most of our readers the the stocking in the chimney corner may be a vision of childhood, and the mythical saint with his sleigh full of toys, a scarce remembered legand; yet, none the less welcome now to both old and young, is the pleasant Christmas festival which commences on morrow, for the holly bough and the evergreens that decorate the hall are not fresher than the delights of the time-honored day. Nature has donned her proper Christmas robes of white and "The sledges with the bells; Sliver bell," furnish the merry music so appropriate to the season; the considerate kindness of Jack Frost has covered our lakes and ponds with a firm glassy flooring, very inviting to the lovers of good skating, and the enterprise of the metropolis has given to sleighers and skaters the Central Park, where both can indulge in their favorite sport. A walk through Broadway or the Bowery at this time would not convey to a stranger the idea that we were a people impoverished by an exhausted war, overburdened with taxes and oppressed with woe. Gaily decorated shops, filled with articles of convenience and luxury, crowded with eager customers, attest the prosperity of the people. Never before has there been such a display on the part of the storekeepers, never so much lavishness on the part of purchasers. The inventive genius of two continents has been called upon to provide novelties for our citizens. The dry goods establishments offer the most costly laces, embroideries, shawls and fancy goods, and notwithstanding the high prices asked, their stores are overcrowded with customers. The great jewelry firm of TIFFANY & CO. and BALL, BLACK & CO. are now disposing of their large stock of beautiful and expensive wares with unexampled rapidity. The confectioners and fruiterers are reaping a harvest, and display an unusual variety of tempting sweets. A few years ago, the business of selling out flowers and bouquets was confined to one or two peripatetic venders of cheap trash; now we mention it as an evidence of growing taste. The florists have nearly thirty-five shops on Broadway, between the Fifth-avenue Hotel and Canal-street, and their show-windows are filled with a profusion of costly exotics. So far, then, from showing any symptoms of economy in their holiday expenditures, people seem bent on luxury and enjoyment at any price. The theatres this year have not provided any of the customary fairy spectacles, which are the delight of young folk, but content themselves with their usual bills. The toy-shops, however, make it up to the little ones, and furnish them with a "fairy spectacle." It is really worth the while of a child of the largest growth to look through these toy-shores. Dolls that babble papa and mamma are common, but hens that cackle and roosters that crow are among the novelties, and are only a specimen of the curious attractions in the toy-line.

abstract: This company promises to become one of the best-paying and managed in the country. It has an actual working capital of One Hundred Thousand Dollars, a greater portion of which has already been paid into its treasury, and is now being judiciously expended in the development of its lands, which have been put into the company at cost, being only one hundred dollars per acre, the lowest ever known for superior oil-bearing territory. The company has already received an offer for one-quarter of its land, which, if accepted, would pay back to the stockholders the original amount of their subscriptions. Its officers are gentlemen of high standing in the community, which insures its success. For further particulars, we refer to the advertisement in our columns.

abstract: Richmond papers of Dec. 22 contain an official dispatch from Gen. BRAGG, at Wilmington, to JEFF. DAVIS, dated Fort Fisher, Dec. 21, in which he announces the arrival of PORTER'S fleet off New Inlet, but says the weather prevents operations. He adds that he can hold Wilmington. The rebel blockade-runner Petrel was recently driven ashore off Wilmington, and subsequently destroyed in a gale. She had a valuable cargo of arms and munitions of war for the rebels. Admiral PORTER says that within the last fifty days his squadron has captured and destroyed over $5,000,000 of rebel property in blockade-runners.

abstract: Credit Abroad
lead_paragraph: There are two or more rebel organs here that still affect to regard Gen. SHERMAN's march through Georgia either as a retreat, or, at best, as a perfectly fruitless enterprise. The rebels in England take a less hopeful view of the matter. Before Gen. SHERMAN was known to have got so far as Milledgeville, the Confederate loan in London was "depressed" by reason of his progress. It seems, indeed, as if two or three additional organs may be needed here, before long, to sustain DAVIS' credit, although, it must be confessed, those we have in New-York now, work for their Southern masters like first-class plantation hands. If DAVIS could place the same reliance on his colored subjects at the South, as on his henchmen in New-York, he would arm them at once.

abstract: Both Boards of the Common Council met yesterday, and both passed an ordinance drafted and submitted to them by Mayor GUNTHER, amending the ordinance passed in January, 1862, prohibiting the sprinkling of salt on railroad tracks, so as to extend the prohibition to cover all streets and avenues, and fixing the penalty for each violation of it of not less than $500, nor more than $1,000. The Aldermen laid over a re-...
lead_paragraph: Both Boards of the Common Council met yesterday, and both passed an ordinance drafted and submitted to them by Mayor GUNTHER, amending the ordinance passed in January, 1862, prohibiting the sprinkling of salt on railroad tracks, so as to extend the prohibition to cover all streets and avenues, and fixing the penalty for each violation of it of not less than $500, nor more than $1,000. The Aldermen laid over a report from the Committee on Streets in favor of extending and widening Church-street, from Fulton-street to Morris-street. The proposed new width is 80 feet. The Councilmen concurred in the amendments to the ordinance to regulate the Fire Department. Both Boards adjourned to Tuesday, the Aldermen at 12 M and the Councilmen at 1 P.M.

lead_paragraph: The writer of the "City Article" of the London Times is, in all ordinary matters, a very sensible and sagacious man; but whenever he touches on any topic connected, however remotely, with the United States, he seems to go "clean daft." And his monomania shows itself oftener than would otherwise be the case, owing to his inveterate habit of making short excursions out of his own sphere, into discussions upon subjects about which, to speak plainly, he knows nothing whatever. His animosity to the North is so intense that he hardly ever pens an article on stocks and bonds in which he does not manage, at some point or other, to insert an expression of opinion as to the policy or strategy of the American war, or the improbability of the American debt ever being paid, or the proper construction of the foreign enlistment act, or the secret designs of LINCOLN or SEWARD.
