abstract: -- A MOTHER MURDERS HER CHILD. -- On Friday morning last, the wife of H.H. BABCOCK, Esq., of Plainfield, in a fit of mental derangement, cut the throat of her child, five months old, and then cut her own throat, Killing both. As we are informed, she had, since the birth of her child, been afflicted, with severe nervousness, which, it seems, culminated in insanity. On the morning of the sad event she arose as usual, and her husband awoke soon after, arose, asked her how she had rested, and being answered satisfactorily, went out, leaving her brother in the room with her. When Mr. B. returned a few minutes afterward, he called to his wife to accompany him to breakfast. Receiving no answer, he opened the door of her bedroom, where she had gone, and found her, with her feet against the door, weltering in her own blood. A bottle of laudanum was found in a drawer, and also a note to her husband, in which she regretted that she must leave him, and saying that it was her intention to take the little boy with her also, but that it was inconvenient. The little boy being questioned, said his mother had attempted to make him take some very bitter medicine a short time before, on the pretence that he was sick, but he ran away from her, and thus, doubtless, saved his life. Mr. BABCOCK is a merchant at Unadilla Forks, has represented his town in the Board of Supervisors, and, we believe, has been the Democratic nominee for Assembly in this district. Mrs. B. was a very amiable, kind-hearted, loving wife and mother, and her death is sadly lamented by hosts of friends. -- Cooperstown Republican, Dec. 24.
lead_paragraph: -- A MOTHER MURDERS HER CHILD. -- On Friday morning last, the wife of H.H. BABCOCK, Esq., of Plainfield, in a fit of mental derangement, cut the throat of her child, five months old, and then cut her own throat, Killing both. On the morning of the sad event she arose as usual, and her husband awoke soon after, arose, asked her how she had rested, and being answered satisfactorily, went out, leaving her brother in the room with her. When Mr. B. returned a few minutes afterward, he called to his wife to accompany him to breakfast. Receiving no answer, he opened the door of her bedroom, where she had gone, and found her, with her feet against the door, weltering in her own blood. A bottle of laudanum was found in a drawer, and also a note to her husband, in which she regretted that she must leave him, and saying that it was her intention to take the little boy with her also, but that it was inconvenient. The little boy being questioned, said his mother had attempted to make him take some very bitter medicine a short time before, on the pretence that he was sick, but he ran away from her, and thus, doubtless, saved his life. Mr. BABCOCK is a merchant at Unadilla Forks, has represented his town in the Board of Supervisors, and, we believe, has been the Democratic nominee for Assembly in this district. Mrs. B. was a very amiable, kind-hearted, loving wife and mother, and her death is sadly lamented by hosts of friends. -- Cooperstown Republican, Dec. 24.

abstract: Vital Forces of
lead_paragraph: -- The problem to be solved in this war is the same which offers in all vital struggles -- the relative strength of the combatants. At first the disparity in this respect between the rebel and the national Governments did not clearly appear. Our armies were confronted by armies equal in number and in courage; and the waste of war on either side appeared to be remedied with equal ease. Indeed, at the first, if there was any advantage in this respect, it rested with the rebels. The institution of slavery, the simplicity of Southern life, and the despotic hold which wealth and social position gave the few over the lives of the many, invested the rebel authorities in the first stage of the war with greater military capabilities than apparently belonged to the National Government. They stood the test put upon them with unwavering stedfastness and confidence, hoping that we might tire in our efforts because of their bold front so long and tirelessly maintained. They might have been wiser in their military conduct; they might have husbanded their strength with greater care, but they could not have shown a firmer determination to meet all of our strength with all of theirs. Greater modesty in their undertakings would have served their purpose better than their restless audacity has done. It is true, that their lavish and spendthrift habit of waging war has given them so formidable a seeming, that it has fostered a peace party at the North, and fomented schemes of foreign interference; but failing to gain from these any substantial results, it has failed of everything, and only hastens the final collapse and ruin.

abstract: Testimonial to
lead_paragraph: -- Last evening Inspector DANIEL CARPENTER, of the Metropolitan Police, was the recipient of a handsome testimonial from the court squads under command of Sergts. GILMORE, BRACKETT, POTTER and LEYFERTS. The present was a fine solid gold shield, of the regulation pattern, with a gold chain attached. The ceremony took place at the residence of the Inspector, No. 411 West Thirty-fourth-street. The presentation was made by Sergt. GILMORE, of the First District Police, and Mr. CARPENTER responded in an appropriate speech. The following is the inscription on the shield: "Presented to Inspector DANIEL CARPENTER by the officers attached to the Police Courts, as a token of their esteem. New-York, Dec. 24, 1864." Mr. CARPENTER has been attached to the police force of this city for the last eighteen years. He is a worthy and efficient officer.

abstract: An establishment which has been oddly, though aptly, christened by its managers, "The Sheltering arms." having for its object the care of all children, irrespective of age, whose parents may desire to avail themselves of its advantages, is now in successful operation at Manhattanville. It was opened on the 6th of October last, and an idea of its practical working may be best obtained by presenting a brief statement of the cases of the children now in the house. One is a blind girl of four years, hence, not old enough, under the rules, to be entered at the Blind Asylum. Four are chronic invalids, or permanent cripples, not likely to live to the age of maturity. Seven are orphans or half-orphans of a year old, therefore younger than are admitted to Orphan Asylums. Thirteen are children whom their friends were willing to place only here, because this institution alone, under its rules, could receive every member of the family, and thus avoid separation. Seven have both parents living, but the mothers, owing to sickness or other causes, are incapacited or unfit to take care of them. Three are children deserted by fathers, and put to board here by mothers who go out to work, or are at service. Probably, none of the inmates of this asylum would have entered any of the other institutions of the city devoted to the good of unfortunate children. Some would have been excluded by the rules governing these institutions as to the age and other disqualifications of the applicants, while quite as many more would have been kept out on account of the natural pride of the parents, and their unwillingness to lose control of their offspring. In most cases, therefore, the welfare, temporal and spiritual, of the little ones was being sacrificed. In one instance, a father, going out at early morning to his work, and returning late and weary, left each day in unavoidable filth and neglect, four little ones, the eldest a cripple of eight years. Sending them now to "The Sheltering Arms" he willingly pays more than one half his wages for their support. By this house, therefore, provision is made for children, who, although neither orphans not friendless, are as much in need of a home as though they were both. Having a contagious disease is the only bar to admission to the institution.

abstract: vs. Corsairs; Juarez, Boniface, Mexico; on Juarez' Proposed Corsairs
snippet: vs. Corsairs; Juarez, Boniface, Mexico; on Juarez' Proposed Corsairs
lead_paragraph: The rumor that JUAREZ, the Mexican President, intended to fit out privateers to harass French shipping, has alarmed and shocked M. BONIFACE, the editor of the Paris Constitutionnel. M. BONIFACE assumes to be an authority on questions appertaining to maritime law, and has repeatedly taken a prominent part in defending the character of the rebel pirates; but now that he is apprehensive lest the commercial, interests of the empire should suffer from his persistent advocacy of a bad cause, he deems it prudent to modify his views on the subject. In accordance with this determination, M. BONIFACE has inserted a note in his journal, in which he marks the distinction between a corsair and a pirate. "The former," says he, "is an armed ship, furnished with letters-of-marque by a regularly constituted and recognized Government; but a pirate has no legal character, and its acts call for prompt retribution from all Powers interested in maintaining the law of nations." This is sound doctrine, yet what becomes of the editor's argument in defence of the Southern privateers, when tried by such a test? Of course, the object of Mr. BONIFACE was not to prove the rebel ships pirates, and to upset his own logic. His design was rather to demonstrate that the expected privateers of JUAREZ would belong to the latter category. He has been much more successful, however, in assailing his former clients, and exposing his past sophistry, than in making out his case against the Mexican privateers. Whether said privateers will ever have more than an ideal existence, seems somewhat problematical, but if they should at any time make their appearance, M. BONIFACE insists that they must be treated as pirates, and that all Powers must exact prompt retribution for their acts. This is a very different conclusion from that which the gentleman arrived at when he had the case of the Alabama and Florida under consideration. The Jeff. Davis vessels were regularly commissioned to capture; plunder and destroy; they were engaged in honorable warfare; their outrages were justifiable; they were not to be treated as hostes human generis, but were to be hospitably entertained by the nations as often as they entered their ports. And yet, these vessels had been furnished with letters-of-marque by a traitor, in rebellion against the legitimate Government of his country, and whose authority had never been recognized by a single foreign State, whereas JUAREZ, whose right to send forth ships to prey upon French commerce, is denied, was constitutionally raised to the Presidential Chair of the Mexican Republic by the votes of the people, was but lately recognized, over the civilized world, as the legal head of the Commonwealth, and still continues, despite the usurpation of MAXIMILIAN, to be recognized as such by all the States of the Western hemisphere. Now, whether, is the constitutionally elected President of the Mexican Republic, who has been universally recognized, or the pseudo-President of Rebeldom, who has never been recognized at all, the better entitled to grant letters-of-marque, and to commission privateers?

abstract: Rents in New-York
lead_paragraph: -- We have a letter on house-rents from an authority perfectly competent to speak on the subject; and it is satisfactory to find that, while our correspondent corrects a presumable inference from certain reflections on the subject, that have appeared in these columns, he does not assail the essential point we desired to bring under notice. We do not question, for a moment, that landlords of the class to which CARL BENSON belongs, are content with the reasonable returns from house property which he presents, and which unquestionably apply in many instances, aside from his own experience, as he shows. What we have urged is, that the rage for mere speculation in up-town lots, the inferior class of tenements -- many of them without cellarage, and a still greater number mere shells as to their exterior and interior fittings, combined with the inadequate means of speedy conveyance to and from the suburban portions of the island, constitute a material item in our social disabilities as Islanders. We have urged nothing more than this, and we should be sorry if our correspondent disagreed with us herein. We want two or three lines of cheap through railroads, running on quick time, and subject to a directory that, may be disposed to treat passengers as something better than cattle, in the accommodation they supply.

abstract: While HOOD lay in front of Nashville, ISHAM G. HARRIS, the rebel Governor of Tennessee, fulminated a proclamation, calling upon the Tennesseans to "arise." The following paragraph occurs in it: "We have driven the enemy in confusion to your capital, and now stand before the bristling fortifications which surround it. He can, must and will be driven from this last stronghold, and beyond the limits of our State. We are here for the purpose of redeeming and protecting Tennessee or finding graves upon her soil." A great many of them found the alternative, but ISHAM's legs saved him.
lead_paragraph: While HOOD lay in front of Nashville, ISHAM G. HARRIS, the rebel Governor of Tennessee, fulminated a proclamation, calling upon the Tennesseans to "arise." The following paragraph occurs in it: "We have driven the enemy in confusion to your capital, and now stand before the bristling fortifications which surround it. He can, must and will be driven from this last stronghold, and beyond the limits of our State. We are here for the purpose of redeeming and protecting Tennessee or finding graves upon her soil." A great many of them found the alternative, but ISHAM's legs saved him.

abstract: To-day, the Christian Church throughout the world will celebrate the birth of our Saviour. Today, the grand anthem of his incarnation will be sung by millions of voices. To-day, all over the land there will be merry greetings and happy hearts. To-day, the children of all Christendom will rejoice over presents drawn from the ample stores of Santa Claus, and to-day the high and the low, the rich and the poor, on land and on sea, wherever the Christian religion is recognized, will bow in humble adoration of the event which gave to the world the Redeemer. The day occurring this year on Sunday, the services in the churches in this city will be more than usually interesting. Many of our temples of worship have been most elaborately decorated, and the forests and gardens have been stripped of their choice holly and balsam to honor the sacred occasion. The lady members of the various churches have employed much of their time, for several days past, in plaiting evergreens and tastefully arranging them in honor of the services to-day. Trinity Church has been elaborately decorated. The scene inside the edifice is exceedingly beautiful, and from porch to chancel is one of triumph. Three arches extend across the apsis through which a view is obtained of the chancel. Each arch is surrounded by a cross of evergreens, the center one bearing a star symbolical of the Star of Bethlehem and the Light of the world. The most careful attention is display in the decoration of the altar, pulpit, chorister's desks, lectern and font The church is otherwise superbly decorated. Rev. Drs. VINTON and OGILBY will officiate to-day, and the annexed programme of music will be followed:

abstract: There ought not to be a moment's longer delay, on the part of the Canadian authorities, in restoring the money stolen by the St. Albans raiders, no matter what disposition may be made of the raiders themselves. Lodging it in bank to await the issue of the investigation was a farce from the outset, because the question raised was not as to the fact of the robbery, or as to the guilt of the robbers,(we...
lead_paragraph: There ought not to be a moment's longer delay, on the part of the Canadian authorities, in restoring the money stolen by the St. Albans raiders, no matter what disposition may be made of the raiders themselves. Lodging it in bank to await the issue of the investigation was a farce from the outset, because the question raised was not as to the fact of the robbery, or as to the guilt of the robbers,(we believe they have never denied the offence,) but as to the power of the Canadian Government to hand them over for trial in the United States. No matter how this point was decided, the money remained the property of the Vermont banks, and it was therefore highly improper and scandalous for the Canadian police to make themselves the custodians, for the benefit of men who were confessedly thieves, of what was notoriously booty.

abstract: New-York; Beekman-street, Nos. 57 and 59; Loss $400,000
lead_paragraph: The loss by the fire Friday night, at Nos. 55, 57 and 59 Beekman-street is much greater than was at first reported. The fine five-story marble building, No. 55, which was owned by R. WYMAN, front, was utterly destroyed. He was insured for $35,000, but in what offices the reporters did not learn. Messrs. J.E. HALSEY & Co., dealers in hardware, who occupied the first floor, estimate their loss at $35,000; and on this they have insurance to the amount of $15,000, as follows: American, $2,000; Firemen's Fund, $3,000; Importers and Traders, $5,000, and Park, $5,000. The second floor was occupied by Messrs. FOSTER & TOWER, hardware dealers, who were insured for $5,000 in the North American and $5,000 in the Croton. Loss, total, Messrs. WOLF, DASH & FISHER, hardware dealers, on the third floor, were insured by the Niagara Company for $15,000; their loss is fully that amount. Messrs. SEMON, BACHE & Co., dealers in window glass, in the basement, lost everything; they were insured by the Hoffman Company for $5,000; by the Greenwich for $5,000; the Bowery, $5,000; Commonwealth, $5,000; Merchants', $3,300; Lafayette, $3,000; Hope, $2,500, and Lorrilard, $6,500. Messrs. E. ROBBINS & BRADLEY, a firm which was formerly engaged in Southern trade, had a stock on storage in the sub-cellar, the value of which has not been reported. The firm insure themselves. In the basement the Baldwin Tool Company had stock which was insured for $3,500; total loss.

abstract: The merriest season of the year, the old, timehonored Christmas festival, began last evening. Rigid sticklers for ecclesiastical compulation may feel inclined to (dispute the correctness of our reckoning, and require us to antedate holidays nearly a fortnight; but Christmas belongs to the people, and they have practically settled the matter by fixing on Christmas eve as the commencement of the great Winter holidays. The ecclesiastical season, proper,...
lead_paragraph: The merriest season of the year, the old, timehonored Christmas festival, began last evening. Rigid sticklers for ecclesiastical compulation may feel inclined to (dispute the correctness of our reckoning, and require us to antedate holidays nearly a fortnight; but Christmas belongs to the people, and they have practically settled the matter by fixing on Christmas eve as the commencement of the great Winter holidays. The ecclesiastical season, proper, continues till the 1st of February, or the evening before the purification of the Virgin; but, practically, the holidays comprehend a period of a fortnight, commencing on Christmas eve and ending on Twelfth Day. The whole of this season, even in hardworking America, is still thoroughly imbued with the spirit of the "Merry Christmas" greeting which it is ushered in; but even where the festival is most mirthfully observed, it is very much changed from what it was in the rude old feudal times, when people better understood the art of making merry. It is enough to make one's blood glow, on the coldest Winter night, to read how our English forefathers used to celebrate Christmas and the following holidays:

abstract: This well-known and splendid skating resort, located at the foot of Seventh-street, Hoboken, close to the ferry, will be reopened this season. The accommodations and arrangements at this pond, though much the same as last year, are ample and good. It is lighted with innumerable variegated Chinese lanterns, upon the style of the Cremorne Gardens. Music will be in attendance every fine evening. Sylvan Lake is one of the largest and finest skating resorts in the United States, being over 26 acres in extent. It will this season be under the sole management of Mr. GEORGE LINGARD. It is reached by any of the Hoboken ferries.

abstract: Earl Russell on; Russell, Earl, on Neutrality
snippet: Earl Russell on; Russell, Earl, on Neutrality
lead_paragraph: -- We have published the text of Lord RUSSELL's reply to the last rebel manifesto. Though brief, it contains not a few words of considerable significance. Lord RUSSELL probably did not mean to be specially offensive to the Government of the United States. And yet we think common international courtesy might have taught him something more gracious toward a friendly Power, than to declare inferentially that the division of this Republic is an accomplished fact. Nor do we think Lord RUSSELL was correct, either as to a matter of history or taste, in speaking of the friendly relations existing between the British Government and the Northern and the Southern States before this war commenced. The British Government sustained no relations of a political nature toward any section of the United States, Northern or Southern, before the war broke out. Her relations were with the Federal Government of the Republic. And Mr. SEWARD might with equal propriety address himself on any frivolous pretext to the question of the friendly relations which his Government has always maintained toward Ireland as well as Great Britain. It would be deemed offensive in England were Mr. SEWARD to say such a thing as this. But the peculiar practice of British neutrality which we witness all around us on the ocean, at British Colonial ports, and on the Provincial frontiers, probably ought to accustom us even to a less gracious style of diplomatic observation than Lord RUSSELL's.
headline: {'main': 'LORD RUSSELL ON NEUTRALITY.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'LORD RUSSELL ON NEUTRALITY.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Yesterday early in the morning the "ball was up," and the cars and stages running to Central Park, Fifth-avenue and the other ponds were crowded with people anxious to enjoy the first skating of the season. Nearly all the ponds above described were in good condition for skating, and those who love the sport seemed determined to embrace the first opportunity to enjoy themselves. Although the Central Park lake could hardly be considered to be in "prime condition," still there was sufficient ice to make that locality exceedingly hilarious. About noon the weather began to moderate, and before nightfall the ice was considerably cut up. In Hoboken, Jersey City and on Staten Island the ice could hardly have been better.

abstract: the Various Ponds
lead_paragraph: The skating season has already been inaugurated, the recent cold snap having formed ice of sufficient strength on nearly all of the ponds in this city and vicinity. The season of 1864-65 promises to be a long and brilliant one, equalling if not surpassing that of 1860-61. Accordingly, the arrangements of all parties are numerous and extensive.

abstract: This favorite skating resort enters upon its third year under the most favorable auspices, and will, undoubtedly, be the principle pond in the Western District. It will continue under the able management of Messrs. WEED & DECKER. The skating superficies at this pond is larger by, perhaps, an acre, than any other pond in the city, all of it being fit for use. The improvements this year are both numerous and important. The sides of the dock or walk in front of the Club-house had been extended and closely boarded up, so that the embankment cannot possibly give way or the earth fall in upon the ice, which is a most important improvement. Several more bridges, too, have been provided, and a railing run all along the above-mentioned gallery. A shed, or rather a pavillion, has been erected on the north bank of the pond (on the site of the engine house,) as a resting place for the skaters. The restaurant and skate-department have been greatly enlarged, while the other rooms have been refitted, and generally improved The Capitoline Skating Lake is accessible by three car routes, viz.: the Fulton-avenue, the DeKalb-avenue and the Atlantic-avenue routes, all of which leave Fulton Ferry, the last two passing the Catherine-street Ferry and (the Atlantic) Wall and South ferries. The pond is located on Nostrand-avenue, one block from Fulton-avenue. A prominent change in the rules is single admissions, which can be obtained for 50 cents.

abstract: Christmas was more generally observed in this city, yesterday, than for many years past. The churches were very elaborately decorated, the services were imposing, and the attendance large. The day was exceedingly fine, and "peace and good-will to all men" seemed to pervade the entire community. It has been determined to further celebrate Christmas by secular observances to-day. The Custom-house will only be kept open for an hour, for the purpose of recording arrivals and clearances. The Mayor's office is to be closed. In all the City Departments there will be no business transacted. The judges have united in adjourning all the courts, and no trials will take place to-day. The "Gold Room" is to be closed -- the speculators determining to honor the festival. There will be no business transacted at the Petroleum Board. In addition to these, all the insurance, shipping and commercial offices will be closed. Business will also be suspended for the day at the various Consulates.

abstract: SHERMAN'S resplendent campaign has had a logical termination, in the capture of Savannah, the chief city and seaport of the State of Georgia. This campaign, so unique and striking, is thus rounded and made complete. The military mystery, which for so long a time amazed and puzzled the country,...
lead_paragraph: SHERMAN'S resplendent campaign has had a logical termination, in the capture of Savannah, the chief city and seaport of the State of Georgia. This campaign, so unique and striking, is thus rounded and made complete. The military mystery, which for so long a time amazed and puzzled the country, is revealed, and is seen to be a thing whose character and object were fixed, definite and grand. The army, about which the rebels told so many falsehoods, from the hour of its "retreat" from Northern Georgia to the day they "ruined" it near Atlanta -- from the time they had it "floundering through the bogs of Georgia" to the moment they brought it up in blank despair before the fortifications of Savannah -- through all the defeats it suffered without knowing of them, and amid all the failures it enjoyed to read about -- has marched onward to its destination with triumphant tread, has reaped fruits of victory as it went, and has grasped the prize when it reached the goal.
headline: {'main': "The Close of Sherman's Great Campaign Savannah Ours.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "The Close of Sherman's Great Campaign Savannah Ours.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Artists' Fund Exhibition, Second Notice
lead_paragraph: The present exhibition of the Artists' Fund, though fairly attended, does not receive the attention which it deserves. We should be glad to see once more, in these splendid rooms, the crowds of delighted visitors that were wont to assemble at exhibitions far less worthy than this. A few years ago most any collection of pictures would attract fall attendance during a long season. In those days, it was rare, if ever, that so many good pictures were got together. This collection is so generally excellent, and so rich withal in works of the rarest excellence, that no visitor could fail to be delighted. Unfortunately, so universal and so indiscriminate is the puffing indulged in by most of our writers on art matters the present day, that the oft-deluded public cannot, by any amount of their persuasion, be induced to visit any gallery or work of art. Terms of the highest commendation known to the language of these so-called critics, have been for years most perseveringly lavished upon pictures and galleries. The advertising quack would hardly stoop to employ such nauseating puffing as is daily issued by some of our city papers, bestowing upon all, worthy or unworthy, an equal eulogium.

abstract: Citizens' Association on Blunt Testimonial; Supervisors and Testimonials
snippet: Citizens' Association on Blunt Testimonial; Supervisors and Testimonials
lead_paragraph: We publish in another column a correspondence of some interest to the public. The Citizens' Association has undertaken to protect the city, so far as possible, from the profligacy and extravagance by which the action of its public bodies of late years has been marked. Having heard that the Board of Supervisors had voted $50,000 to Mr. ORISON BLUNT, one of their members, as a testimonial for his services as Chairman of the Committee on Volunteering, they made inquiry from Mr. BLUNT himself as to the facts. Mr. BLUNT, in his reply, evades the question, and attempts to be facetious upon the Association by which it is asked. He will scarcely dispose of it to the satisfaction of the public in that manner.

abstract: Rebel Gen. Lyon's raid on
lead_paragraph: An official dispatch from Gen. SHERMAN to the President, dated at Savannah, on Thursday, the 22d inst., announces his occupation of that city, and the capture of one hundred and fifty guns, a large quantity of ammunition, and about 25,000 bales of cotton. Gen. SHERMAT's brief dispatch is supplemented by an official dispatch from Gen. FOSTER to Gen. GRANT, in which the particulars of the occupation of the city are given. Gen. FOSTER states that Savannah was occupied by Gen. SHERMAN on the 21st inst., and that on the preceding day and night, Gen. HARDEE, anticipating an assault, had escaped with the main body of his infantry and light artillery, by crossing the river to Union Causeway, opposite the city. The rebel ironclads were blown up, and the navy-yard burned. All the rest of the city remains intact, and contains twenty thousand citizens, who are quiet and well disposed. The captures include, according to Gen. FOSTER, eight hundred prisoners, one hundred and fifty guns, thirteen locomotives, one hundred and ninety cars, a large supply of ammunition, and other material of war, three steamers, and thirty-three thousand bales of cotton, (Gen. SHERMAN says 25,000.) The fleet was in communication with the city, and arrangements were making to clear the channel of all obstructions. These are are the splendid fruits of an almost bloodless victory. The position of HARDEE's forces is not indicated in either of the dispatches.

abstract: Special entertainments, suitable for the young folk and the festive season, are provided at nearly all our places of amusement, except where a change is undesirable, as at the Academy of Music and the Winter Garden. At these establishments "Fra Diavolo" and "Hamlet" are repeated to-night.
lead_paragraph: Special entertainments, suitable for the young folk and the festive season, are provided at nearly all our places of amusement, except where a change is undesirable, as at the Academy of Music and the Winter Garden. At these establishments "Fra Diavolo" and "Hamlet" are repeated to-night. The opera steadily increases in public favor, and will remain the attraction until the close of the season on Saturday next. It is just the sort of work to add cheerfulness to the season. The music is light, graceful and melodious. The mise-en-scene and costumes are alike admirable. Mr. BOOTHS Hamlet has fairly electrified the town. He has given it twenty-four times, and the tragedy, with its beautiful scenery, seems destined to run for several weeks to come. Those who would enjoy an intellectual treat should by all means patronize the Winter Garden. At Wallack's Theatre to-night, TOM TAYLOR's comedy of "Masks and Faces" will be performed. It is an excellent piece and is admirably rendered by the company at this house. At Niblo's Garden the popular favorites, Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS, will present three of their amusing pieces, the "Fairy Circle," "In and Out of Place," and "Barney the Baron." A night of merriment can certainly be enjoyed here. At the Olympic theatre the drama of the "Streets of New-York" has proved so eminently successful that it remains on the bills for another week. A new holiday piece is in preparation. At the Broadway Theatre Mr. J.E. OWENS repeats his inimitable personation of "Solon Shingle," and for the first time appears in a comicality called the "Live Indian." At Barnum's Museum a new fairy spectacle, long in preparation, will to-day be brought out in a style of great splendor. It is called the "Ring of Fate, or Fire, Air, Earth, and Water," and is described as being in three parts and four elements. It will be played many times to-day, and during the week, every afternoon at 3 and evening at 7. Mr. BARNUM has made several important additions to the Museum -- among others are WOODRAFE's Bohemian Glass Blowers, heretofore at Hope Chapel. At the French Theatre there will be performance to-day at popular prices. The pieces are "La Poudre aux Yeux" and "Les Deux Timides." At the Hippotheatron, in Fourteenth-street, extensive arrangements have been made for the holidays. A new Christmas pantomime, on the old-fashioned plan, has been prepared, and will be brought out for the first time this afternoon. The introduction has been written by Mr. JOHN DARCIE, and the entire work has been many weeks in preparation. It enjoys the name of "Harlequin Blue Beard; or the Good Fairy Preciosa and the Bad Demon Rustifusti." The usual attractions of this well-conducted establishment are in addition to the pantomime. At HELLER's "Salle Diabolique" Programme No. 4, and the great Ravel panomime of "Harlequin Santa Claus," are the sufficient inducements. No one can make a mistake in visting HELLER's most amusing establishment. There will be four performances at VAN AMBURGH's Mammeth Menagerie to-day. The collection of birds, animals, &c., is remarkably fine.

abstract: The steamship Peruvian, of the Montreal line, With dates to the 16th, passed Cape Race on Saturday, and a portion of the news received by telegraph was given in our yesterday's issue. We have fuller particulars this morning. We have also some additional details of European news by the Canada's mails, which arrived here last evening. The English pro-rebel press have begun to whine, desparing for a cessation of hostilities in the interest of the desparing Confederacy. The London Times forsees that unless terms of peace can be arranged, the South will be made "a howling wilderness." The Queen had again made a special observance of the anniversary of her husband's death, and her inconsolable seclusion was again the subject of pointed commentary by the press. The only item of Continental news noted in the report, worth noting, is contained in a Constantinople dispatch which says that the Porte has accepted the proposal of a commission by the Great Powers to replace the police of the Danube under international control. The American brig General Ward blew up at Shanghae on the 21st of October. All the crew were killed save one. American securities, both in London and Frankfort, continued firm.

abstract: THE NEW HOSPITAL TRANSPORT GEN. J.H. BARNES. This magnificent new hospital ransport, named after the Surgeon General of the Army, has just been completed, and saild on Saturday for Hilton Head the best adapted ship for the purpose ever fitted up in this country. The vessel was chartered for the Medical Department while she was yet on the...
lead_paragraph: THE NEW HOSPITAL TRANSPORT GEN. J.H. BARNES. -- This magnificent new hospital ransport, named after the Surgeon General of the Army, has just been completed, and saild on Saturday for Hilton Head the best adapted ship for the purpose ever fitted up in this country. The vessel was chartered for the Medical Department while she was yet on the stocks and before the usual state-rooms, saloons and other accommodations for passenger-vessels were commenced. She has been finished, therefore, with a single aim for convenience in the special service for which she is designed. The work has been done under the immediate supervision of Col. MCDOUGAL, Medical Director of this Department, aided by Dr. HOFF, Gen. VAN VLIET's Chief Quartermaster, and the owners. The ship is 1,400 tons burden, draws 12 feet of water, will make 12 miles an hour at sea, and can reach City Point, Va., or any other of the principal landings on the Southern coast. The accommodations for the officers and crew are entirely separated from those for the sick. They are upon the upper deck, and all the remaining space is used for hospital purposes. Accommodations for the Chief Surgeon and his Staff, for nurses, cooks and other employes, are arranged also with special reference to economy, as well as the rooms for the dispensary, clothing, commissary stores, kitchen and dining-room for the patients, beside bath-rooms, ice-room, water-closets, with wards for 650 sick and wounded, containing well-filled bed-sacks, linen sheets, pillows, &c., &c., with every facility for lighting and ventilation. The entire vessel is heated by steam-pipes. The berths are arranged to slide up and down, so that the patients can be placed in them without difficulty or danger, and they are supported in their positions by iron pins. The J.H. Barnes is under the charge of Assistant Surgeon THOS. MCMILLEN, U.S.A., who is an eminently kind, humane and efficient officer, assisted by a full corps of medical officers, cadets, stewards and nurses. The Surgeon-General receives a deserved compliment in the naming of this ship, and those engaged in her construction and splendid outfit, may point to her with confidence, as a beautiful testimonial of the care of the Government for its suffering but uncomplaining heroes.

abstract: Remarkable Narrative
lead_paragraph: There arrived in this city last week, from Charleston, S.C., which place she left Nov. 6, a lady named Mrs. THOMAS PIERCE, whose experiences form one of the most remarkable narratives that this remarkable war has yet given rise to. In March, 1861, her husband, THOMAS PIERCE, who was a Northern man, born in New-Hampshire, but residing in South Carolina for fourteen years previously, was compelled, in consequence of his strong Union sentiments, to leave his wife and plantation, near Charleston, and come North. So strong was his hatred of the originators of the rebellion who had thus exiled him, that he enlisted in one of the West Virginia regiments as a private, and participated in the battle of Winchester, under Gen. SHIELDS, and subsequently in all the battles of the Army of the Potomac, from Harrison's Landing to the battle of the Wilderness, in May last, and, as a reward for faithful service, had been promoted to the rank of First Lieutenant. At this battle he was taken prisoner, and confined at Richmond until August last when the rebel authorities discovered that he was a citizen of South Carolina, and he was taken out of prison and deliberately shot. This information was communicated to Mrs. PIERCE by a rebel soldier from Charleston, who knew her husband and was cognizant of the murder. About a year after her husband's departure, Mrs. PIERCE endeavored to reach our lines at Newbern. N.C., with her horses, mules and slaves; but, when almost within our lines, she was apprehended by the enemy and sent back to Charleston. After this manifestation of Union feeling, she was regarded with much suspicion by the rebels, and her crops, buildings and property of all kinds unceremoniously appropriated, without even a shadow of compensation. Her male slaves, forty-three in number, were impressed for labor upon the Charleston fortifications, and their monthly wages, which all who were rebels regularly received, were confiscated by the rebel Government; and this was the general course of the rebels toward this lady throughout her residence there. When Union prisoners began to be confined at Charleston, she improved the opportunity to supply the sick and wounded with nourishment and bandages, which the rebels permitted in case such favors were equally distributed between rebel and Union patients. She dressed the wounds of many Union soldiers, who will, undoubtedly, remember her with gratitude, and whom she would gladly meet now, if it were possible. One young man in particular, Orderly-Sergeant CHARLES MULLEN, of a New-York regiment, she would be glad to see now. His life was saved through this lady's kindness. Another soldier, whose name she has forgotten, but who may recollect her, she would like to inform of the location of $35 in gold which he begged her to take and secrete to prevent the rebels from robbing him of it. But, at last, the rebels charged her with being too partial, and refused her permission to visit the hospitals. She soon afterward resolved to reach the North, if possible. Provided with a rebel passport to pass the lines, she proceeded by way of Branchville, S.C., Little Washington, N.C., and Weldon, to Staunton, Va.; at the latter place, ambulances were taken for the Union lines in the Valley, but soon afterward the party was captured by a party of guerrillas, and completely robbed of everything they possessed. These thieves respected no appeals. Trunks, wearing apparel, $500 in gold, a gold watch, a quantity of silver ware, and even ear-rings and the deeds of her property in the South, were all taken from Mrs. PIERCE, and appropriated by the robbers. Then, mounted on mules, without saddles, the party were taken through the mountains a long distance, and finally set down at Beverley, Western Virginia, where they got into the Union lines.

abstract: Two Months of War and their Significance
snippet: Two Months of War and their Significance
lead_paragraph: The past two months' campaigning has taught the rebels a hard lesson. Each isolated event has an important lesson of its own, but taken together they open up startling revelations. It must be sufficiently distasteful to the rebels that an army of fifty thousand men can cut itself off from its base at Atlanta and at leisure establish another three hundred miles distant, on the Atlantic coast. This fact alone proves the helplessness of the Confederacy outside of its intrenched strongholds. The rebels may agree with DAVIS that Richmond, or any other fortified point, may be forced from them without their suffering vital loss, but this will not make them relish being pummeled everywhere else. Then, again, HOOD's defeat, taken by itself alone, conveys a scathing comment on DAVIS' policy of waging war. The same may be said of PRICE's defeat in Missouri, or of EARLY's in the Shenandoah. But in the summary, and considering the total result, there is conveyed to the minds of the rebels a still more disagreeable suggestion than is involved in simple defeat or indiscretion, and that is, that as their relative strength is diminished, the proportion of the waste attendant upon the war on their part is greatly increased.

abstract: Christmas Present to the Nation, (Savannah)
lead_paragraph: The full financial value of SHERMAN's Christmas present it would be hard to estimate even roughly; but we get a ready notion of the worth of one item included in the Christmas gift. Gen. FOSTER tells us that Gen. SHERMAN has got 33,000 bales of cotton, and if we take these bales at the ordinary weight, we get a gross sum in greenbacks for them in New-York of $18,150,000; or at Liverpool (by the cotton quotations which we publish in the European news summary this morning,) SHERMAN's gift can be turned into $7,821,000 in solid gold. Eighteen odd millions make up a tolerably handsome Christmas present without counting in the guns, the ammunition, the ships, cars and locomotives, and the prisoners, with which SHERMAN has supplemented his holiday token of remembrance.

abstract: Rebel Press, Despairing Howls of
lead_paragraph: The panic which has seized upon the home and foreign rebel sympathizers is illustrated with much effect in the tone of the English Pro-Southern press. The London Times, it will be seen from our European news report, has at last come to the conclusion that, if the rebels still persist in carrying on the war, the South will be made "a howling wilderness." It reasons likewise, of course, that the North will be seriously injured in its financial and industrial concerns, unless peace can be brought about by negotiation. But this makes the admission of the hopeless condition of the Confederates not a whit less significant. Hitherto the London Times has defiantly proclaimed, in the face of the liberal intelligence of Europe, the absolute invincibility of the Confederated rebels. Through its agents at Richmond and at New-York, and by every species of partisan argument in its editorial columns, it has labored for years to convince the political and financial circles to which it finds access, that the permanent subjection of the South is an utter impossibility; that the North would itself be ruined before the task was well begun, and that it is for the interest of Europe that the "belligerents" should be regarded as entitled in every sense to a perfect equality in the consideration of foreign Governments.

Late on Saturday night the Police arrested two men named THOMAS RYAN and PATRICK MCCARTHY, who are charge with committing the burglaries. MCCARTHY resisted the officers with much vigor, and after his arrest a number of his friends made a desperate but unsuccessful attempt to effect his rescue.

abstract: Noyes, William Curtis
lead_paragraph: WILLIAM CURTIS NOYES died at his residence, In this city, yesterday morning, of appoplexy. Mr. NOYES was born in Schodach., Rensselaer County, N.Y., Aug. 19, 18[???]5. He commenced the study of law when fourteen years of age, in the office of SAMUEL B. LUDLOW, Esq., then of Albany. In 1823 he became a student in the office, of the late Hon. HENRY STORRS, and in 1827, completed his studies, and was admitted to the bar. He commenced his professional life in Rome, where he was connected in business, first with the late WHEELER BARNES, Esq., and subsequently with Hon. HENRY A. FOSTER. In 1834 he removed to Utica, and formed a partnership with WILLIAM TRACY, Esq. Since 1838 he has been actively engaged in the practice of law in this city. The commanding position Mr. NOYES has for many years held at the bar in this State, his high social position and his unsullied character, and his indomitable perseverance in the prosecution of the business of his profession, will make his loss deeply felt by this community.

abstract: On Christmas Eve Madame DEMOREST gave a brilliant reception to about one hundred and fifty of her needlewomen. A large and full-bearing Christmas tree stood out prominently in the parlors, and the scene which was presented in the happy faces of the fair ones gladdened the hearts of all present. For several years past it has been the custom of Mme. DEMOREST to invite all in her employment to meet her on Christmas Eve, to exchange the compliments of the season, and each guest receives something as a memento of the employer's kindly feeling and good wishes. This custom of Mme. DEMOREST's is one which might be emulated by other employers, with great advantage to themselves and their workpeople.

abstract: The bonded warehouse at No. 5 Whitehallstreet was entered by burglars about three weeks ago, and property consisting of silks and laces, to the amount of $1,000, was stolen. An entrance to the premises was effected from the roof through the scuttle.
lead_paragraph: The bonded warehouse at No. 5 Whitehallstreet was entered by burglars about three weeks ago, and property consisting of silks and laces, to the amount of $1,000, was stolen. An entrance to the premises was effected from the roof through the scuttle. Search was made for the offenders, but the Police were for a time unable to ascertain their whereabouts. On the night of the 21st inst., the same warehouse was again entered in a similar manner, and the burglars then stole fifty-three boxes of valuable imported cigars. Saturday night, Officers DOYLE and KEIRNS, of the First Precinct, received information which induced them to suspect that two young men, named THOMAS RYAN and PATRICK MCCARTHY, were the guilty persons. They therefore started in pursuit, and after much effort succeeded in capturing them. RYAN was first arrested, and at a later hour of the night, MCCARTHY was found in a public house at the corner of Washington and Rector streets. The latter resisted the officers with all his power, and after he had been taken into custody, a desperate attempt was made by several of the prisoner's friends to effect a rescue. In this they did not succeed. The two were taken to the Station-house, where, soon after, the officers learned that a portion of the stolen cigars had been sold to MARTIN BUTTS, corner of Greenwich and Rector streets, for a sum much below their value. These were recovered, and the officers think they will be able to recover the residue. The stolen silks and laces have not been found. Yesterday morning the accused were committed to the Tombs.

abstract: FUNERAL OF A SOLDIER. -- The remains of Sergt. GEORGE E. WINSLOW, of the One Hundred and Thirty-ninth Regiment, New-York Volunteers, were consigned to their last resting place, in Greenwood Cemetery, yesterday afternoon. The ceremonies were conducted by Rev. Mr. GILES, at Plymouth Church. Company D, of the Twenty-third Regiment, with the Drum Corps and Seventh Regiment Band, escorted the remains to the grave. The deceased was killed in front of Petersburgh, Va., by a rifle-shot, fired by one of the enemy's pickets. Sergt. WINSLOW was about 25 years of age. He formerly belonged to the Twenty-third Regiment, and was much thought of by his companions.

abstract: Appraiser's Decision Conclusive; U S vs Harris
snippet: Appraiser's Decision Conclusive; U S vs Harris
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. Abraham Harris. -- This was an action at common law, to recover duties from the defendant in an importation of merchandise which merchandise had been surrendered to the defendant as being worth only a fraction of the duties claimed. The Government chose rather to consider the duties as an indebtedness that had accrued to them, and decided to enforce their claim by a personal suit, rather than by a suit in rem.

abstract: Convention called, Chanced Attitude of State
snippet: Convention called, Chanced Attitude of State
lead_paragraph: A call for a State Convention appears in the Kentucky papers, to consider the policy that ought to be adopted by the State in respect to its own domestic interests and its loyal obligations. It is evident that Kentucky is at last seriously realizing the necessity of ridding herself of the institution which has done more than all things else to compromise her loyalty and protract her troubles. The altered tone of the Louisville Journal, since the election, so that it is not only respectful toward the Administration but positively friendly to the emancipation policy, is, of itself, a very significant token that public sentiment in the State is no longer what it was. This change is just what ought to be expected from sensible and true-hearted men.

abstract: WM. TUCKERMAN, convicted about eight years ago of robbing the mails between New-York and Boston, received, yesterday, a full and unconditional pardon from the President of the United States, and will leave the Wethersfield Prison to-day. Since his incarceration he has conducted himself in such a manner as to gain the sympathy of all connected with the prison, and of persons who visited the institution. His history has often been written in the newspapers, and a sad story of domestic affliction, connected with his imprisonment, went the rounds of the press less than a year ago, having started in Boston, where his family friends reside. He was sentenced to the Wethersfield Prison for twenty years. -- Hartford Courant, Dec. 23.

abstract: Finances of
lead_paragraph: Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER, while reading the usual notices before beginning his sermon yesterday morning, availed himself of the opportunity afforded in announcing that the annual auction sale of pews in the church will be made on the 3d inst., to pay a well-merited compliment to his congregation. He said that of the five or six hundred accounts for sittings in the church during the year about to close, not one cent had been lost -- the great majority of the pew rents having been paid in advance, in compliance with the condition of the sale, and the last of the few tardy lessees having paid up within a few days. This paying of the pew rents to the uttermost farthing, continued Mr. BEECHER, was not an exceptional case, either, with the Plymouth congregation, but merely their ordinary mode of doing business. He was gratified in being able to say that in financial matters, at least, his people had proved themselves a model church. Mr. BEECHER then read the following condensed exhibit of the church rents for the year 1864, and said that the credit of the matter belonged in a great degree to the Treasurer of the Society, whose excellent management had brought about this handsome result:

abstract: Farragut, Admiral, Testimonial to
lead_paragraph: -- The subscriptions to the Farragut testimonial already exceed $40,000. They will, undoubtedly, reach $50,000. There is a current impression that the Admiral is entitled to a handsome sum as prize-money from captures made of vessels trying to run the blockade. This is a mistake. He has never been in command of a blockading squadron, and has had no opportunities to earn prize-money in that way. From first to last, he has commanded a fighting fleet, as at New-Orleans and Mobile, and consequently, the only pay he gets for his labors and risks is the salary attached to his office. We are confident the public will regard his services as worthy of a more substantial reward.

abstract: Fox, John Lawrence, Surgeon United States Navy; Aga???am, Gunboat, Officers of
snippet: Fox, John Lawrence, Surgeon United States Navy; Aga???am, Gunboat, Officers of
lead_paragraph: OBITUARY. -- Fleet-Surgeon JOHN LAWRENCE FOX, United States Navy, of Rear-Admiral DAVID DIXON PORTER's staff, died at his home in Roxbury, Mass., on Saturday last, aged 54 years. Dr. FOX was born in Salem, Mass., and in 1831 graduated at Amherat. In 1837 he entered the United States Navy as Assistant Surgeon; on the 6th of June, 1842, he was commissioned as Passed Assistant Surgeon, and on the 16th of August, 1847, he was commissioned as Surgeon, and he had seen about seven years' sea service under that commission -- his total sea service being nearly fifteen years; on shore duty, eight years, four months; unemployed, seven years, four months. Admiral PORTER selected Dr. FOX as his Fleet-Surgeon some months since, and in the performance of the duties of organizing the medical department of the largest armada of the war he overtaxed his system, and now sleeps in peace a victim of this war. His remains were taken to Salem, for interment, on Tuesday, after the funeral services in Roxbury.

abstract: Reply to Citizens' Assoc on Testimonial; Testimonials from Public Money
snippet: Reply to Citizens' Assoc on Testimonial; Testimonials from Public Money
lead_paragraph: -- Mr. BLUNT's "smart" reply to the Citizens' Association furnishes one more argument in favor of taking away from all public bodies in this city the power of making gifts, donations, or testimonials, out of the public money. Testimonials to public men for services rendered to the public, are often both useful and graceful; but to have any value, and not to be abused, they should be very rare, and the power of bestowing them should be lodged in the hands of a body of eminent and indisputable tact, honesty, and discretion. We have no such body in this city, and therefore the practice of making appropriations out of the taxes for such purposes had better be abolished altogether, and the duty of bestowing special marks of gratitude on public benefactors be left to individual munificence. If the public takes the same view of the value of Mr. BLUNT's services that he does himself, nothing will be easier than to raise the sum of $50,000 for him by voluntary subscription; but we deny the right of any body to hand him over that sum out of the pockets of the tax-payers without their consent. We have already commented more than once on the performances of the Common Council in this same field. We hope the Legislature will look into this matter this Winter, and put an end to such abuses.

abstract: Boardman, Hon D S
lead_paragraph: -- Admiral PEARSON, it will be seen by the Central American news of this morning, has adhered to the prudential course he marked out for himself when he captured the pirate HOGG and his gang on board the Pacific steamer Salvador. Finding that President CALANCHA could not assume the power of permitting the prisoners to be transferred to the Atlantic Coast through the territory of the Colombian Confederation, Admiral PEARSON had them confined on board the Lancaster, in Panama Bay, until he received orders for their disposition. These orders have reached the Admiral, and the pirates have been sent to San Francisco, to be put in durance at that place.

abstract: Christmas Festivities at New-York
lead_paragraph: The Christmas festival of 1864 will long be remembered as among the most jubilant and happy holiday season which our citizens have enjoyed for many a year. The falling of Christmas day upon the Sabbath was most appropriate for the religious observance of the sacred anniversary, but our people were not willing to forego their customary secular enjoyments of the annual jubilee, and accordingly yesterday was set apart for the more gay and festive celebration of the holiday. The Mayor's office and the various city departments were closed. The courts adjourned, and there was a general suspension of business throughout the citp. The weather alone was inauspicious, and manifested its usual fickleness and uncertainty. A drizzling rain commenced early in the morning and continued without intermission through the day, thus belying the goodly promise with which it ushered in the Christmas festival, and blasting the hopes and anticipations of skaters, and those who delight in the jingle of the merry sleigh-bells. The outward gloom and drizzle, however, only gave additional zest to the indoor pleasures, and the parlors and drawing-rooms of the metropolis never rang with more joyous mirth and gleeful merrymaking than throughout the day and evening of yesterday. The announcement in the morning papers of the splendid "Christmas gift" which Gen. SHERMAN and his brave army had prepared for the loyal people of the country, put everybody in the best of humor, and all felt like extending a cordial greeting and welcome to their brethren of the goodly City of Savannah, who had at last escaped the tyranny of rebel rule and were brought once more into the Union fold.

abstract: Victories in the Southwest
lead_paragraph: Gen. THOMAS fairly and equally divides the honors in the Southwest with Gen. SHERMAN. Every day adds to the magnitude of THOMAS' victory in Tennessee enlarging at once our view of the greatness of the victory achieved in front of Nashville on the first three days of battle, and adding to the completeness and importance of the triumph by the vigor and success of the pursuit. It is twelve days ago this morning since the battle commenced by the great assault of our forces upon the Confederate army, which JEFF. DAVIS and Gen. HOOD had had the audacity and foolishness to march into Middle Tennessee and up to the capital of the State. From our victory of the first day on the rebel left -- from the second day's victory "at all points" -- from the third day's victory which sent the enemy reeling beyond Franklin -- onward through the general pursuit which began on Sunday of last week and lasted till the week's close, leaving HOOD and his wreck of an army upon the south side of Duck River -- our forces have enjoyed success continuous and brilliant, its value being demonstrated by the immense captures of prisoners and artillery which have been officially and unofficially chronicled in our columns.
headline: {'main': 'The Southwestern Victories.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Southwestern Victories.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: business of recruiting having been transferred by Supervisor BLUNT from the Battery grounds to the City Hall Park, the old system of swindling on the part of bounty brokers has been resumed at Castle Garden. It is now hardly safe for a newly-arrived emigrant to leave the protection of the Commissioners of Emigration and venture into the city unless accompanied by a policeman. The arrival of steamers at Castle Garden draws around that institution a class of vagabonds, whose daily object is to rob emigrants, either by picking their pockets or enticing them into some private recruiting office and swindling them out of their bounties. Mr. CASSERLY, the General Agent of the Commissioners of Emigration, is about introducing a system through which all unsuspecting foreigners will be fully informed of their rights, and warned of the shares that may be thrown around them. Mr. CASSERLY, on previous occasions, when Castle Garden was infested by bounty swindlers and thieves, proved himself equal to the emergency, and through his efficient police force drove from the premises all interlopers. It is is be hoped that in the future he may be equally successful.

snippet: Marselles, Capt USN, Drowned at Hoboken
lead_paragraph: FATAL END OF A RIVER THIEF. -- Justice CUTTER, of Jersey City, held an inquest, yesterday, on the body of an unknown man who, was detected the evening previous stealing pig iron from the Morris Canal Company, and while attempting to escape the private watchman sunk his boat by throwing a bar of iron into it; the boat was sunk, and while the thief was swimming to the shore, he sunk and was drowned. On his yacht, the Fawn, moored a short distance away, was found a letter, from which, it is supposed, the name of the deceased was CHAS. H. VERRITY. A verdict in accordance with the facts was rendered, and the watchman was held blameless.

abstract: The steamship Champion, from Aspinwall on the 16th, arrived at this port last evening. We learn from Panama papers that the seven prisoners captured on board the Salvador, and who have been confined for several weeks past on the United States steamship Lancaster, in Panama Bav, have been transferred to the sloop-of-war Saginaw, to be conveyed to San Francisco, where they will be confined in Fort Alcatsaz.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Champion, from Aspinwall on the 16th, arrived at this port last evening. We learn from Panama papers that the seven prisoners captured on board the Salvador, and who have been confined for several weeks past on the United States steamship Lancaster, in Panama Bav, have been transferred to the sloop-of-war Saginaw, to be conveyed to San Francisco, where they will be confined in Fort Alcatsaz. Acting Ensign ROCKIEWAY, of the United States sloop-of-war Saginaw, was shot in the right arm by the accidental discharge of an Enfield rifle in the hands of the gunner's mate on board the Saginaw, on the 6th. The Saginaw had just left Panama, but, on the occurrence of the accident, immediately put back. ROCKIEWAY's arm was amputated, but he died the same evening. He was a native of Connecticut. The only news of importance from Central America is the almost universal complaint of the destruction of the cotton plant by worms. In regard to the would be pirates arrested recently at Panama, we learn that the man BRADSHAW, alias Johnson, the chief of the gang, when he found that the plot was discovered, divulged many of their plans. He said he had purchased, some time ago, for $2,000, the island of San Elmo, in this bay, which they had made a depot for coal and guns. The latter statement is not believed. BRADSHAW also stated that, though they had failed to seize the Guatemala, they had not given up all hope of securing the ship. On the 3d instant, BRADSHAW and his gang left Acajutta for Belize, on the Atlantic. Before leaving they had a fight among themselves, and some of them were hurt. Some of the gang had threatened the life of BRADSHAW, and at his request the Government furnished him with a guard.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The weather was too unpleasant, last evening, for the dainty habitues of the opera, and the attendance in consequence was anything but good. "Fra Diavolo" was given for the third time, and as frequently happens on such occasions with rare spirit and effect. All the artists were in good voice, and the performance elicited much applause, and passed off most agreeably.

abstract: An evening cotemporary suggests, very pointedly, that the true difficulty in regard to our City Government, and the troubles we all suffer from it, is that the minority is not represented in it. This obvious defect has been frequently dwelt upon in our columns.
lead_paragraph: An evening cotemporary suggests, very pointedly, that the true difficulty in regard to our City Government, and the troubles we all suffer from it, is that the minority is not represented in it. This obvious defect has been frequently dwelt upon in our columns. It is well known that property interests in New-York to the value of hundreds of millions, both public and private, are entirely controlled -- so far as legislation is concerned -- by some 50,000 voters, who have not a penny's worth of real estate, and the 20,000 or 30,000 minority, who mainly represent the property and the intelligence of the city, have scarcely a vote either in the City Government or the Legislature. They are virtually disfranchised.

abstract: and Southern Cruelties to Our Soldiers; Retaliation Should be Tried
snippet: and Southern Cruelties to Our Soldiers; Retaliation Should be Tried
lead_paragraph: It is worse than useless to disguise or ignore the fact that the condition of Union prisoners in rebel hands is exciting the profoundest feeling in the public mind, and that the action of the Government upon the subject is not regarded with satisfaction. This feeling is perfectly natural and not unreasonable. So far as the public has been informed of the action of the Government, that action does not seem adequate to the awful emergencies of the case. And while the whole subject is surrounded with difficulties, it is felt that nothing but absolute necessity -- no question of etiquette, no fear of embarrassing concessions, no question of policy and expediency merely, should lead the Government to permit 40,000 of our soldiers to perish by starvation and exposure at the hands of their Southern captors.
headline: {'main': 'What Can be Done for Our Prisoners?', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'What Can be Done for Our Prisoners?', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: and Government Charities; Government Charities to Refugees, >amp;c.
snippet: and Government Charities; Government Charities to Refugees, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: So far as we have been able to ascertain, no mention has been made in any of the departmental reports, of the extensive charities of the Government. It is well known that a large number of persons in the frontier States mostly white refugees are now supported by the United States. Rations are constantly issued to them, clothing is sometimes supplied, and other expenses are incurred in their behalf. A considerable multitude of freed negroes, also, in the Border States, are understood to be fed and cared for by the War Department. Probably no exact report can be made of the amount of provisions and clothing issued to these various dependents, as they are usually included in the supplies drawn for other objects, but there is no question that they amount to a considerable quantity.

abstract: Arrested at Concord, N H
lead_paragraph: We learn by a telegram from Concord, N. H., that three of the St. Alban's burglars, in attempting to escape a second trial in Canada under the new order of arrest, have turned up at Lebanon, in New-Hampshire. At that point they enlisted in the United States Army, but the detectives were "too many" for them. They are now in jail at Concord. There will thus be raised a question of non-concurrent jurisdiction, in a novel form. At Montreal, six of the burglars are again on trial before a Superior Court Judge, for the purpose of testing their liability to surrender under the Extradition Treaty. The decision at Montreal, whatever it may be, may possibly precede -- as it cannot help, in a great measure, influencing -- the disposition of the prisoners in custody on this side of the line. On the other hand, the fact of JEFF. DAVIS' commissioned belligerents enlisting in the United States Army will place the prisoners in Montreal in a singular position as to the line of defence they have chosen to adopt. The three ruffians caught at Lebanon have now to choose between confessing themselves burglars or spies. If they confess themselves burglars, they become witnesses against their confederates now in durance in the Province; but they save their necks and merely incur the penalty of robbery in the most aggravated form -- involving possibly ten or fifteen years in the penitentiary. If on the other hand, they make the plea of "belligerents," they render themselves liable to be hung as spies, merely by virtue of their enlistment in the army of the United States.

abstract: Narcissus, Gunboat, Officers of
lead_paragraph: THE GUNBOAT NARCISSUS. -- The gunboat Narcissus, which was destroyed by a torpedo in Mobile Bay on the night of the 7th inst., was a purchased steamer, and was fitted at New-York for Admiral FARRAGUT'S squadron, in the early part of the year. She sailed from the Brooklyn Navy-yard on the 2d of February, 1864. The following is a list of her officers: Acting Ensign, W.G. Jones; Acting Master's Mates, C.R. Marple, E.A. Morse, E.G. Caswell; Acting Third Assistant Engineer, J.L. Young, C.E. Black, M. Berry, J.R. Davidson. The Narcissus was a screw tug boat of 101 tons, and carried a battery of two guns. The casualties by this accident were very small considering that the steam from the boiler escaped so freely. Only three were scalded; two severely -- SAMUEL KEELAN, quarter gunner, and GEORGE CASSEY, seamen.

abstract: New-York--Cancemi, Murderer of Policeman Andersen Pardoned by Gov Seymour
snippet: New-York--Cancemi, Murderer of Policeman Andersen Pardoned by Gov Seymour
lead_paragraph: Gov. SEYMOUR has signalized his retirement from office by pardoning the Italian barber, CANCEMI, who was convicted of the murder of policeman ANDERSON and, sentenced to the State Prison at Sing Sing for life. CANCEMI arrived in this city on Friday last. The circumstances connected with this murder created intense excitement at the time, and, notwithstanding the great efforts made by the prisoner's counsel to procure his liberty, he received the sentence above stated. CANCEMI was caught in the act of robbing the shoe-store of Mr. S. SAMMIS, corner of Grand and Centre streets, and Pursued by officer Anderson. During the pursuit CANCEMI raised a pistol and fired at the officer, the charge taking effect and producing injuries which soon resulted in death. The murderer was then followed by a number of persons who witnessed the shooting, and secured in a building in Leonard-street. An indictment against the accused was promptly found, and he was arraigned for trial. The case was subsequently carried to the Court of Appeals and a new trial ordered, which resulted in a sentence for life.

abstract: An official dispatch from Secretary STANTON, gives the reports from Richmond papers of yesterday, forwarded by Gen. GRANT. Dispatches from Wilmington, dated the 25th, say that Admiral PORTER'S fleet opened the attack at one o'clock on the 24th, with a furious bombardment, averaging about thirty...
lead_paragraph: An official dispatch from Secretary STANTON, gives the reports from Richmond papers of yesterday, forwarded by Gen. GRANT. Dispatches from Wilmington, dated the 25th, say that Admiral PORTER'S fleet opened the attack at one o'clock on the 24th, with a furious bombardment, averaging about thirty shots per minute till night. On the morning of the 25th, at ten o'clock, the attack was renewed with additional fury. On the evening of the 24th, a large force of troops, estimated at three brigades, the rebels say, were landed on the beach above Fort Fisher, and were attacked by the rebels, but the dispatch admits that our troops occupied the field at night. It also claims that at a late hour our troops assaulted the fort, but were repulsed. The editorial comments on this news by the rebel papers view the investment of the fort, which cuts it off completely, as a very serious matter. The fort is probably in our h[???]n is ere this.

abstract: London Times Eager for Peace; "Friendship"--London Times
snippet: London Times Eager for Peace; "Friendship"--London Times
lead_paragraph: The London Times is again eager for peace. It urges the "opening of negotiations" in America. Its delicate sensibilities are shocked and outraged at the prolongation of our civil war. They always were, whenever the Union cause was gaining ground. The tenderness of the Times, whenever the rebels seemed likely to get their deserts, was always extremely touching. When they were prosperous, its bowels of compassion for suffering humanity were never stirred. It could rehearse the tale of their piratical burning of American ships, with no feeling but admiration for their heroic valor. It could dismiss the damning facts of their savage treatment of our prisoners with a sneer of incredulity. It has never failed to chronicle our defeats with exultation, or to give the whole tremendous weight of its influence to blacken our character and damage our cause.
headline: {'main': 'England and America.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'England and America.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC -- Mme. CAROZZI ZUCCHI took her benefit here last evening. BELLINI's opera of "Norma" -- always a favorite with our public, was revived for the occasion. The distribution was extremely good, and the performance excited the enthusiasm of the audience. Mme. CAROZZI's dramatic abilities are displayed to great advantage in the role of the Druidess. The many declamatory passages of the part were rendered with an intensity that could hardly be excelled. The opening recitative has rarely been given with such power of voice and authority of style. We were not so well pleased with the Casta Diva, but the subsequent quick movement was excellent. Signor MASSIMILIANI is certainly one of the best Pollio's we have ever had here. Of Mlle. MORENSI as Adalgisa, and Signor SUSINI as Oroveso, it is unnecessary to speak. They have sung the parts previously, and were in ordinary voice last night. The opera, as we have before remarked, was received with great favor, and had the weather been fine, the house would undoubtedly have been crowded. We are glad to hear that "Norma" will be repeated on Friday next. Our readers must not forgot that Miss KELLOGG takes her first benefit here to-night, playing Zerlina in the opera of "Fra Diavolo." The lady is a deserved favorite with the public, to whom she has often lent her gratuitous services. As a compliment to the best artist America has yet produced, we trust the house will be filled to its greatest capacity.

abstract: Prospect, the
lead_paragraph: It may easily happen that our people may be too sanguine with reference to the immediate results of Gen. SHERMAN'S march and his capture of Savannah. JEFF. DAVIS said, in his late message, with some truth, that the existence of the Confederacy, and the success of their cause, does not at all depend on their possession of cities. In our own struggle with Great Britain during the War of Independence, that Power held for years many of our largest cities, and marched her armies from one end of the country to the other, without perceptibly affecting the decision of the contest. A vast agricultural country as this was then, and as the South is now, does not depend at all on cities; in fact, the population of towns in a severe blockade becomes often a burden on the producing classes. We might now, JEFF. DAVIS has said, hold Mobile, Wilmington, Charleston, and Richmond, and the essential resources of the Confederacy remain much as they have been.

abstract: the Popular Majority for
lead_paragraph: -- The next day but one after the Presidential election we stated that Mr. LINCOLN's popular majority would reach "nearly, if not quite, four hundred thousand." The Opposition press flouted at this as a ridiculous extravagance. They declared the majority would not reach half that, and have ever since persisted in greatly under-estimating it. The returns from all the States -- official, with the exception of Nevada and Oregon -- make Mr. LINCOLN's majority to be 407,302. This does not include the majorities given in Tennessee, or any other State reclaimed from the rebellion. Thus our statement, deemed so hyperbolical, really fell below the mark.

abstract: Wilmington and its Defences Described
lead_paragraph: Wilmington, the principal city of North Carolina, is situated on the left bank of the northeast branch of Cape Fear River, at its junction with the estuary of that river, a little more than thirty miles from the sea. It is the terminus of the Wilmington and Weldon, and Wilmington and Manchester railroads, the former of which is threatened by the cooperating expedition up the Neuse. Before the war Wilmington contained about 9,500 inhabitants. The principal exports were timber, turpentine, resin, tar, pitch, shingles, and cotton. Ever since the outbreak of the rebellion, and more especially since the ports of Charleston, Savannah and Mobile were closed against blockade-runners, or so strictly guarded by our blockading squadrons as to render the operations of these enterprising gentry both difficult and dangerous, Wilmington has been the grand entrepot of the contraband foreign trade of the Southern Confederacy; and all the vigilance of a powerful blockading squadron was insufficient to put an end to it. The approaches to the city are admirably adapted to blockade-running, and the rebels, fully alive to the importance of the foreign trade in arms, munitions of war and other supplies of every variety, have increased their natural advantages by the erection of forts and batteries on the shore of the channels at the mouth of the river. A glance at the map will show that a long narrow island stretches directly across the mouth of the river, leaving two narrow inlets at either end. These are denominated Eastern and Western Bar, or Old and New Inlet.
