abstract: We understand that Maj. JAMES HAGGERTY, who is very generally acknowledged to have been an efficient speaker for the Union in the late campaign, and to have invariably brought together the largest audiences, has prepared a lecture on "Wit and Humor," which he proposes to deliver during the Winter in the large cities and elsewhere, should invitations be tendered. The lecturer has studied his subject well, and there is no doubt that it will prove instructive as well as entertaining to his audiences.

abstract: Reports yesterday from the Wilmington expepedition were very conflicting, and partly assumed an unfavorable turn, But the Secretary of  War forwards extracts from Richmond papers of ...
lead_paragraph: Reports yesterday from the Wilmington expepedition were very conflicting, and partly assumed an unfavorable turn, But the Secretary of War forwards extracts from Richmond papers of yesterday, which contain an official dispatch from Gen. BRAGG, dated Tuesday evening, Dec. 27, 6 P.M., which states that on Monday evening our land forces were reembarked, but that the next movement was undeveloped. BRAGG claims that but two guns in Fort Fisher were disabled, but admits that the fort suffered severely. The buildings inside were burned. It is therefore, untrue that the attack has been abandoned.

abstract: The Common Council of Jersey City at their meeting on Tuesday night, passed a resolution offering bounties to volunteers, payable in city bonds, as follows: Three years' men, $500; two years men, $400; one year men, $300. The following named Aldermen were appointed a Special Committee on Enlistment: Aldermen Gainey, Decker, Terry, Pang born, Gaddis and Kane. The quota on the last call will be about six hundred men.

snippet: His Progress, Savannah Journals on; Press and Southern Sentiment
lead_paragraph: It will be extremely interesting to learn how the belligerent press at Richmond relishes the tone assumed by the Savannah journals on the eve of SHERMAN's entrance into that city. It will be scarcely less interesting to know how the altered manner of the Georgia journalists is regarded by the different rebel organs of New-York, and by their coadjutors in England and France.

abstract: The gold speculators endeavored yesterday to qualify our Savannah victory by bidding up the price on rumors from Washington of disaster to BUTLER and PORTER. The early sales of the day were 217 @216  cent.; but on the rumors referred to, the offers to-day were rushed up to 224, soon returning, however, to a point below 220 cent. The Stock Market was generally steady; money in some request.
lead_paragraph: The gold speculators endeavored yesterday to qualify our Savannah victory by bidding up the price on rumors from Washington of disaster to BUTLER and PORTER. The early sales of the day were 217 1/2@2161/4 cent.; but on the rumors referred to, the offers to-day were rushed up to 224, soon returning, however, to a point below 220 cent. The Stock Market was generally steady; money in some request.

abstract: Wendell Phillips on; on Reconstruction
lead_paragraph: It is probable that the question of reconstruction will soon become the dominant topic of the day. The States reclaimed from the rebellion must have some regular civil government, with a settled basis internally, and also settled relations to the national authority. The President has not yet committed himself to any definite scheme, further than is involved in his recommendation that Louisiana be admitted as she stands, and also that the Federal Constitution, be so amended as to prohibit slavery throughout the land. But these points, we take it, are a sufficient index of his general policy. He would not interfere with the internal organization of the reclaimed State further than to exclude slavery from it by constitutional law, binding alike on all.
headline: {'main': 'Wendell Phillips on Reconstruction.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Wendell Phillips on Reconstruction.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- Last night two desperadoes called at the residence of a respectable widow in the Eastern District, and represented themselves to be Deputy Provost-Marshals in search of deserters. The lady admitted them to the house unsuspectingly, when they fastened the hall and back door, and, finding the lady alone, committed a fiendish outrage upon her person and decamped. The wretches are known to the police, and will probably be arrested this morning.

abstract: Capt. MELLON T. HOLBROOK, of the One Hundred and Seventy-third Regiment, New-York Volunteers, received his commission yesterday as Lieutenant-Colonel, for meritorious services in the Red River country, and also in the Shenandoah Valley. The evening previous his friends presented him with a sword, sash and belt, valued at $200. Lieut.-Col. HOLBROOK was formerly Caption of the Forty-third Precinct Police of Brooklyn. The presentation was made by Capt. GEORGE R. RHODES on behalf of the members of the police force. Addresses and responses were made and a very agreeable time was passed.

abstract: At a special meeting of the Board, last evening, the President, JAMES M. MCLEAN, Esq., in the chair, a communication was received from the Clerk of the Common Council, reporting the names of members elect for 1860, and a petition for advance of salaries was read from the teachers and others who are now employed by the Department Alter desultory discussion the Annual Report of the Finance Committee was rendered, showing the total receipts for 1864 to have been $1, 787,043 84, the expenditures $1,862,161 38, and the overdraft for warrants that have been drawn to date $75,117 54. An appropriation of $3,592 72 was voted to cover expenses above the amount that had been appropriated for repairs in Ward School No. 29. in the Twenty-first Ward. The Board confirmed the appointment of Miss FRANCES A. STEVENS as Principal of Primary School No. 6. in the Eighth Ward. Mr. JOHN T. BARNARD, who a year ago contracted to supply coal for the city schools at $8 90 a ton, sent in a petition for relief, and a majority report proposed that the Board allow the petitioner $10 65 per ton of 2,240 pounds, being $1 75 per ton above the contract price. A minority report, rejecting Mr. BARNARD'S application, after animated discussion, prevailed. After the customary vote of thanks to the President and Clerk for the urbanity and fidelity with which they had discharged their duties during the year, and several very happy congratulatory speeches were made by Messrs. HASTIE, ROOSEVELT MILLER, SMITH, WEST, SMYTH, and FARE, the Board adjourned without day.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. Miss KELLOGG was complimented last evening by one of the finest "houses" that has yet attended the performance of "Fra Diavolo." The lady, on her entrance and subsequently, was received with enthusiastic applause. Benefits ...
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Miss KELLOGG was complimented last evening by one of the finest "houses" that has yet attended the performance of "Fra Diavolo." The lady, on her entrance and subsequently, was received with enthusiastic applause. Benefits are the proper occasions for this display of heartiness, and toward Miss KELLOGG there is but one sentiment. It found vent in every possible manner. The most accomplished artist America has yet produced, Miss KELLOGG is also the most willing, obliging and conscientious. We rejoice to find that her merits are so thoroughly appreciated by the public.

abstract: CITY NOTES. Soon after the 1st of January the Hudson River Railroad Company will run street cars from Thirty-first-street to the Warren-street depot. City passengers will also be carried at the rates of fare charged by the other city railroad companies.
lead_paragraph: CITY NOTES. -- Soon after the 1st of January the Hudson River Railroad Company will run street cars from Thirty-first-street to the Warren-street depot. City passengers will also be carried at the rates of fare charged by the other city railroad companies.....The contribution of pictures in aid of the Artists Fund Society, will be sold on Friday evening, at the Derby Galleries, No. 625 Broadway, by Messrs. LEEDE; & MINER. The collection numbers sixty-fire pieces, the productions of some of our best artists....The remains of the late Mr. WALLACK were burled on Tuesday in the vault of the family at Greenwood Cemetery. In accordance with a special request of the deceased, the funeral was conducted in as private a manner as possible. It took place as early as 9:30 in the morning, the hearse being followed by only some half a dozen carriages, in which were the male relatives, a few intimate friends, and some members belonging to the company of the theatre which bears Mr. WALLACK'S name....An interesting annual exhibition of the Sunday School of the Thirty-seventh-street M.E. Church is announced for this evening....Mr. JAMES E. AYLIFFE will "ring out the old and ring in the new "year by chiming the Trinity Church bells, beginning at 11:15 P.M. The programme includes ten popular melodies....NICHOLAS HORN and PAUL DINGLEMEYER were arrested yesterday, charged with having passed a counterfeit $10 bill of the Montgomery County Bank on Mr. LEVY, clothier in Eighth-avenue. They were committed to answer....On Tuesday evening, Mr. JOHN D. OTTIWELL, Alderman of the Fourteenth District, was the recipient of a watch and chain, which cost at least $700, the gift of his friends and constituents.
headline: {'main': 'GENERAL CITY NEWS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'GENERAL CITY NEWS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: LOVEL'S excellent play of the "Wife's Secret" was revived here last evening, and received with much favor by a fashionable audience. The work is well known to the frequenters of the theatre. It is filled with the picturesque contrasts that belong to the period of the Roundheads and Cavaliers. The story is direct and the interest unflagging. The distribution last evening was in many respects the same as heretofore. Mr. FISHER was Sir Walter Arnyot; Mr. GILBERT the Jabez Sneed; Mr. FLOYD the Lord Alden; Miss FANNY MO-BANT the Page, and Miss IONE BURKE the Maud. Of these artists we have frequently written in terms of warm appreciation. They were excellent last evening. The only change in the bill was in the Lady Arnyot, which, on this occasion was played by Miss HENRIQUES. The part is an extremely important one, and is peculiar and trying, inasmuch as its intensity begins with the first act and continues to the end. We are glad to say that Miss HENRIQUES -- whom we regard no longer as a novice, but as an artist worthy in many respects of the high position she is beginning to occupy was fully equal to the opportunity presented to her. It is by far the best and most consistent representation she has yet given, and was particularly free from certain tendencies (not yet wholly eradicated) to exaggerate her naturally soft and pleasing voice. A few performances will undoubtedly enable the lady to claim the role as the strongest in her extensive and rapidly studied repertoire. The play will be repeated to-night and on Saturday.

abstract: The dispatches about the Wilmington expedition are not very easily comprehended. First came one yesterday afternoon from Fortress Monroe, which was published in the evening papers, and professed to be upon ...
lead_paragraph: The dispatches about the Wilmington expedition are not very easily comprehended. First came one yesterday afternoon from Fortress Monroe, which was published in the evening papers, and professed to be upon official authority, announcing that both the land and naval forces had returned from Wilmington to Fortress Monroe, and conveying the impression that the expedition had suddenly and unexpectedly proved unsuccessful. It did not seem possible that this dispatch could be correct, as we were otherwise informed that operations were still in progress on Monday last. This first dispatch was soon followed by another from Washington, saying that "it would seem to be a mistake that the naval and military fleet had returned;" that the "Navy Department had no such intelligence," and giving some details of movements. In the course of the night, Secretary STANTON's official bulletin came to hand; but all it contained regarding the Wilmington expedition was an extract from the Richmond papers of yesterday, which averred that Admiral PORTER's naval bombardment had done very little damage to Fort Fisher, and that BUTLER's troops had reembarked on Monday night. We shall have to wait for later advices before we can comprehend the situation at Wilmington.

abstract: The patrons of this establishment -- and their numbers of late have sorely taxed its capacity -- are now enjoying the luxury of a Christmas pantomime. Of all places in the world for the production of such a work, this surely was the least convenient, and the one that most needed preliminary courage on the part of author and scene-painter, Nor was this alone sufficient. It was necessary that the fairies should be blessed with hardy constitutions and great muscularity in the extremities. The art of tripping lightly through luxurious fields of wonder-land resolves itself, when performed in the ring, to a matter of wading. Although it was not without emotion that we beheld the charming preciosa standing standing ankle-deep in sawdust, we were yet glad to find that she and her companions were equal to the trying situation. And the dramatist, too, has made a circular Introduction, which enables everything to go on literally under one's nose. His rhymes and jokes are capital. Toe stage artist, also, has performed wonders. His scenery partakes of the marvelous. Description is out of the question. Suffice it that the two entrances are the places where he displays his talent. Everything from a vision of Elysium to an ordinary street scene, is packed into those rather draughty passages. There is room for the imagination at the Hippotheatron, about the only thing there is room for.

abstract: Tuttle, Doremus
lead_paragraph: Mr. DOREPHUS TUTTLE committed suicide on Sunday morning last, by shooting himself through the head with a pistol, on the front steps of a house in West Twenty-sixth-street. He died in a few minutes after having fired the shot. The ball entered immediately over me right eye, and penetrated the brain. The motives that induced the man to commit the deed, are, as we learn them, briefly as follows; About two years ago. TUTTLE was married to a Miss SMITH in the city of Boston. At the time the marriage ceremony was performed she knew that he had been previously married, but believed, as she says, that a legal divorce had been granted by a competent Court. For a time they lived happily together, but quite recently the wile was advised by a respectable lawyer of this city, to whom she presented the divorce papers, that the same were forgeries. Hence she gave notice to her husband that she would not longer cohabit with him. On Sunday last she had an interview with him in Twenty-sixth-street, when he asked her the question if she intended to live with him? Her reply was, "No, you have another wife who has a higher claim on you than I have." He then said. "I shall immediately do something which you will regret." When he took his leave, she accompanied him to the door, and when he was on the front steps he drew a revolver and shot himself as above stated. When the wife saw what he was about to do she used every effort to prevent the suicide, but without effect. The coroner's jury rendered a verdict in accordance with the above facts.

lead_paragraph: In accordance with the proposed plan or reorganizing the Union Central Committee, the following named gentlemen are claimed to have been elected last week from the several Assembly Districts. On Thursday, the 5th proximo, the delegates will meet at the Union Headquarters, corner of Twenty-third-street and Broadway, to perfect the organization. There are several contesting representatives, and some difficulty may be expected in settling disputes. Among the candidates proposed for permanent Chairman of the Central Committee are Simeon Draper, Abram Wakeman, Waldo Hatch-lag, William R. Stewart, James Kelley, and E. Delafield Smith:

abstract: Burnside, Park, Wreck and Suffering of Crew
snippet: Burnside, Park, Wreck and Suffering of Crew
lead_paragraph: Capt. JOHN EYNON, of the steamship City of Dublin, arrived yesterday, reports: Dec. 17, in lat. 49 41, lon. 31 14, fell in with a wreck, on approaching which the steamer's wheels were stopped, and one of the ship's life-boats manned and lowered immediately, in charge of the second officer, Mr. PETER FLETCHER, who in the most daring manner, in the face of a high sea, succeeded in rescuing from the wreck three survivors, named GEORGE SMITH, steward, of Liverpool; GILBERT DUNCAN, a seaman, of Shetland; and JOHN JOHNSTON, a seaman, of Guttenbergh, Norway. The remaining ten, whose names we have not learned, had perished. The wreck was the British bark Burnside, of Greenwich, and when first seen had her fore lower mast standing, and part of the rigging; also the lower mizzen-mast. The extreme fore-and-aft part of her seemed to be occasionally above water, but the whole main deck was immersed, and the sea making a clean breach over tax. Upon approaching her, the three men were seen standing by the rudder-post, and occasionally immersed in the water. Their condition was most deplorable, having scarcely any clothing about them, except some pieces of old sail, tied with bits of spun yarn, their flesh, and particularly their arms, feet and legs, were swelled, and of a putrid appearance, in some places broken out in bolls, and they were so weak and exhausted that it was with great exertion and the excitement of their being rescued that enabled them to stand. Having been got on board the steamer in safety, they were finally cared for by Dr. BLACK, and on their arrival in this port were convalescent and able to walk about.
headline: {'main': 'DISASTER AT SEA.; Wreck of the Bark Burnside--Three Survivors Rescued by the Steamship City of Dublin--Loss of Life and Great Suffering.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'DISASTER AT SEA.; Wreck of the Bark Burnside--Three Survivors Rescued by the Steamship City of Dublin--Loss of Life and Great Suffering.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Publication of Returns; And Publishing Incomes
snippet: Publication of Returns; And Publishing Incomes
lead_paragraph: Amongst the many imperfections of the Internal Revenue Law, the failure to impose secrecy on the assessors of the income tax is certainly not one of the least important. The Evening Post commented a few days ago in severe terms on the smallness of the amount returned as their yearly income by great numbers of persons whose style of living unquestionably proves the receipt of five or six times as much, and it recommends sarcastically that Mr. PUTNAM should use the records in his possession to make up a book exposing the fraudulent concealments and evasions of some of our wealthy citizens in their dealings with the Government. It says:

abstract: The book publishers met on Tuesday at the Trade Sale Rooms. No. 498 Broadway, to consider the present tax law on books. As the law now stands books are classed among manufactured articles, and are taxed as such, although the paper and other materials used are taxed before they assume the book form. After some discussion, it was decided to ask for an equalization of the burden, whereby the printers and bookbinders might be made to pay their share of the tax now imposed alone upon the publishers. Messrs, Appleton, Harper, and Mason of New-York, Littleton of Boston, and Lippencott of Philadelphia, were appointed a committee (with power to act) to proceed to Washington, and lay the matter before the proper authorities.

Messrs, Appleton, Harper, and Mason of New-York, Littleton of Boston, and Lippencott of Philadelphia, were appointed a committee (with power to act) to proceed to Washington, and lay the matter before the proper authorities.

abstract: CHARLES WINDSOR, the absconding Teller of the Mercantile Bank, has been arrested in London, and it is reported that a large proportion of the missing funds, which amounted, according to the announcement of the President of the Bank, to $207,000 in currency and $32,000 in gold, has been recovered. WINDSOR left this city on Oct. 29, and was arrested by the New-York detectives. His friends claim him to be innocent of the crime....Forty-six thousand dollars have thus far been subscribed to the Farragut testimonial, and it is likely that to-day the full amount proposed -- $50,000 -- will be subscribed. Many of the contributors are in favor of inventing the sum in "seven-thirty" Government bonds....The meeting of the members of the Bar, called to express their sense of the loss sustained in the death of Mr. WILLIAM CURTIS NOYES, will be held of the U.S. District Court-room, at 12 M. to-day.

abstract: Hamberjer's Street-sweeping Machine
lead_paragraph: Prof. HAMBERJER, of this city, has recently inveted and obtained a patent for a machine for roughening, cleaning, sprinkling and sweeping street pavements, which in construction is very ingenious. The principal features of the machine are first, sharp cutters by which ice is removed; second, a grooving drill for roughening the pavement; third, a broom, which is so arranged as to sweep from each side of the street the thickest deposit of mud; fourth, a large sprinkler to wet the streets when necessary; and fifth, an arrangement for collecting the dirt and "dumping" it in heaps. The Professor has been authorized by the Croton Board to groove the Russ Pavement in Broadway, between Fulton and Ann streets, and if he is successful in his experiment he will undoubtedly find a more extensive field for his operations.

abstract: In behalf of the 63 survivors from the 239 officers, passengers and crew of the U.S. transport steamer North American, wrecked Dec. 22, 1864, we tender our sincere thanks to Capt. THOS. L. LIRBY, of the bark Mary E. Libby, Portland, Mc., in whom we recognize our generous benefactor, the brave seaman and the noble man, who exerted himself for our rescue at the peril of his own vessel, and from whom we received the most kind and courteous attention during our stay on board. Our gratitude is also due to Capt GADSDEN, of the Arago, the bounty of whoso board is only exceeded by his generosity of soul, manifested in his unremitting efforts to render pleasant and comfortable the terminus of our sail and unfortunate voyage.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC -- Mr. MARETZEK's season ends positively to-night. The company leaves for Boston to-morrow, and owing to this circumstance there will be no matinee. For the last night, then, Mr. MARETZEK appeals to his patrons. The opera is "Norma," always a favorite work with them, and especially so now. It was as the Druidess that Mad. ZUCCHI made, on Tuesday last, her greatest success. The dramatic grandeur of her rendering of this part has rarely been equaled, and vocally, too, the largeness of her declamation places it among the most memorable performances we have ever had in this city. There cannot be a doubt that the house will be crowded to its greatest capacity.

abstract: Expedition; The Failure of; Failure of Attack on Fort Fisher
snippet: Expedition; The Failure of; Failure of Attack on Fort Fisher
lead_paragraph: The great and glittering victories, which have illumed the horizon of the nation for the last two months, have been suddenly succeeded by an unexpected reverse, whose magnitude must be at once acknowledged. The naval and military expedition against Wilmington, under command of Admiral Porter and Gen. BUTLER, has failed to accomplish its work. It has returned to Fortress Monroe, after an absence of two weeks.

abstract: Underhill vs Alcott; Lunacy Case; Verdict Six Cents
snippet: Underhill vs Alcott; Lunacy Case; Verdict Six Cents
lead_paragraph: At noon, yesterday, the jury in the case of CAROLINE D. UNDERHILL, against net nephew, GEORGE OLCOTT, and her sister, Mrs. OLCOTT, returned with a verdict awarding six cents damages. This suit was brought, on Thursday of last week, before City Judge GEORGE G. REYNOLDS, of Brooklyn, upon an allegation that the plaintiff's relatives were striving to defraud her of certain property which her father had willed to the children and mother jointly. This property consisted of a house in Brooklyn, wherein the testator directed that the plaintiff should have a home so long as she should remain a maid, and the income thereof is $1.000 annually. The plaintiff, moreover, alleged that her sister and nephew, conspiring to deprive her of the home which her father, Mr. STEPHEN UNDERHILL, gave her, trumped up a charge of lunacy, and thereupon thrust her into the Bloomingdale Asylum for the Insane. That Miss UNDERHILL had been consigned to Bloomingdale, neither her sister nor her nephew for a moment sought to deny. On the contrary, throughout the tedious trial, their counsel held that they did but their duty in sending the plaintiff thither for treatment, there being, in the judgment of trustworthy physicians, clear evidence that she was of unsound mind' On this point the defence based their case; and, to sustain their theory, they introduced testimon syhowing that Miss UNDERHILL had indulged in hallucinations that could not have been harbored by any sane unmarried woman.

abstract: Adams, Minister, Reply to British Emancipation Society
snippet: Adams, Minister, Reply to British Emancipation Society
lead_paragraph: -- By the Australasian we have the test of Mr. ADAMS' reply to an address of the British Emancipation Society, congratulating President LINCOLN on his reelection. Such an address offered to a mere partisan politician, would most certainly have evoked a torrent of turgid rhetoric, in w??? things visible and invisible would have been confounded; with a perfect disregard of consequences. To Mr. ADAMS the address of the British Emancipation Society came simply in the form of a logical statement of facts patent to the Minister and to everybody else.

abstract: We print this morning two full accounts of the bombardment of Fort Fisher and the operations off Wilmington--one being the official report of Admiral PORTER, and the other the very lucid and succinct account of our special correspondent with the expedition, Mr. WHITMORE.
lead_paragraph: We print this morning two full accounts of the bombardment of Fort Fisher and the operations off Wilmington -- one being the official report of Admiral PORTER, and the other the very lucid and succinct account of our special correspondent with the expedition, Mr. WHITMORE. To these accounts we refer our readers for particulars, and for the reason of non-success thus far. The bombardment was terrible and effective, but the declination of Gen. BETLER to assault the fort, seems to account for its non-capture. Admiral PORTER would continue the bombardment.

abstract: Gen. STONEMAN, who arrived at Nashville on Thursday night, on his return from the great raid into Southwestern Virginia, fully confirms the previous reports of the extent of the damage done.
lead_paragraph: Gen. STONEMAN, who arrived at Nashville on Thursday night, on his return from the great raid into Southwestern Virginia, fully confirms the previous reports of the extent of the damage done. Gen. BRECKENRIDGE's forces were found scattered in small detachments, beaten in detail, and finally driven over the mountains into North Carolina. Every bridge on the East Tennesseee and Virginia Railroad, from Bristol to New River, were destroyed. Thirteen trains of cars, with their engines, were captured. Among other spoils were 2,000 horses, 1,000 mules, and 24 officers and 845 men taken prisoners. The salt works and lead works were entirely destroyed.

abstract: Legal Profession and Relations to Christianity
snippet: Legal Profession and Relations to Christianity
lead_paragraph: The death of WILLIAM CURTIS NOYES is to be made the occasion of an address by Rev. Dr. ROGERS, at the South Dutch Church, to-morrow evening, to the Young Men's Christian Association and the Law Schools of the city, on the "Relations of the Law and Lawyers to Christianity." In the existing state of American society and of public affairs, it would be difficult to mention a more important theme. The absence among us of a large class of men of leisure and cultivation, such as is found in nearly every European country, leaves to the clergy and the bar all but a monopoly of our mental training, and the lawyers may be said to be the only men in the community who bring disciplined intellects to the discharge of public duties. The natural consequence is, that the management of our political affairs, at least at the North, has always fallen, and will probably always fall largely into their hands; and this fact alone, to say nothing of their being administrators of the law, render, and will always render, their character and aims as men, of the last importance to the country.

abstract: The schooner W.F. Johnson, laden with sutlers stores, consigned to JOHN WOODRUFF, sutler, One Hundred and First Pennsylvania Volunteers, Roanoke Island via Hatteras Inlet, to which point she was regularly cleared at Baltimore, on a permit from the Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, approved by Gen. BUTLER, was seized after entering Hatteras by the Supervising Agent of the Treasury Department at Newbern, and returned to Baltimore in charge of a revenue officer, as a lawful prize, she entering through Hatteras Inlet, which, not being a port of entry, and having a cargo amounting to $8,500, being $6,000 more than is allowed by the Treasury regulations to any one sutler per month.

abstract: The Moral Aspect in Sherman's Leniency
snippet: The Moral Aspect in Sherman's Leniency
lead_paragraph: Gentlemen who have left Savannah since SHERMAN'S occupation of the city, inform us that the people seem to be quite satisfied with the change which has been effected by the new order of things. The furious declamations of the rebel leaders and newspapers did not at all represent the spirit of the people. They had suffered for years in every conceivable way, from the terrible tyranny of the rebel leaders; and Gen. SHERMAN at once removed some of the most odious restrictions which they had long groaned under; and this was duly appreciated by the citizens. They have been treated with kindness and in a conciliatory manner; and our army have exhibited toward them that demeanor which is the result of discipline, and that chivalry which is characteristic of the American soldier. Gen. SHERMAN has appropriated none of their houses or private property for military purposes, and in all respects has interfered with them as little as possible. On Sunday last, the churches were opened as usual, service being conducted by the resident clergymen; and our soldiers mingled freely at service with the citizens of both sexes, and mutual courtesy and respect were shown. Gen. GEARY is Post-Commandant, and he has established an excellent provost system, under which citizens are not required to have military passes to move about the city, such as were previously required from every one, black and white, male and female. Gen. SHERMAN himself was temporarily staying, by invitation, at the house of an old resident of Savannah.

abstract: -- More than one thousand dollars was realized by the promenade concert given by the Thirteenth Regiment at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, on Wednesday evening, for the benefit of solers' families. The affair was very successful....Mrs. LIZZIE BELL, of this city, is engaged in raising funds to establish a home for the orphan daughters of soldiers. The Home will be located on the Hudson River, near Poughkeepsie, opening in May next with 100 children. Mrs. BELL has testimonials from Edward Everett, Millard Fillmore, Gen. Hooker, Gen. Wool, Senator Sprague, Mayor Gunther, of this city; Mayor Lincoln, of Boston; Mayor Knight, of Providence; Mayor Faxton, of Utica; Mayor Fargo, of Buffalo; and a large number of distinguished clergymen and citizens....The ladies managing the Bazaar at the Everett Rooms, corner of Broadway and Thirty-fourth-street, for the benefit of sick and wounded soldiers, have been greatly disappointed in the sales owing to the inclement weather. Now that fine weather has returned, it is hoped that the many attractions offered at the Bazaar will receive proper attention and patronage. The object in view is a worthy one, and the Bazaar will close of Saturday evening with a grand concert, for which eminent amateur and professional talent is engaged.

abstract: A GENERAL RAISE OF CITY OFFICIAL SAL[???]. -- She Board of Aldermen on Wednesday evening adopted resolutions and ordinance, fixing the following rates for the salaries of municipal officers, to date from Jan. 1: Mayor, $7,500; Chief Clerk Street Department, $4,000; First Book-keeper, $3,000; First General Clerk, $3,000; Deputy Superintendent of Repairs and Supplies, $3,000; Superintendent of Roads, $3,000; Superintendent of Wharves, $3,000; Keeper city Hall, $2,000; Chief Clerk Croton Aqueduct Department, $3,000. In addition to the above, resolutions were also adopted increasing the salaries of the clerks in the Mayor's office, the Street Department, Croton Aqueduct Department, also the Bureau of Arrears, Comptroller's office. The salaries of the Clerks of Fnlton, Catherine, Essex, Clinton and Union Markets, were increased to $1,000 per annum.

abstract: London Times on Sherman's March; Conception of America
snippet: London Times on Sherman's March; Conception of America
lead_paragraph: The London Times demonstrates very conclusively to itself that SHERMAN'S march must ruin him, yet has the grace to say : "If this enterprise be brought to a successful termination, Gen. SHERMAN will undoubtedly be entitled to the honor of having added a fresh chapter to the theory and practice of modern warfare." Well, this "fresh chapter" is added. In the face of the old rule never to break connection with a military base on penalty of destruction, Gen. SHERMAN has marched from the mountains to the sea, safe and triumphant.

abstract: The Farragut Fund is completed, and the subscription books are closed. The sum collected exceeds $50,000, and it has been invested in 7-30 bonds. All the contributors are invited to meet the Admiral at the Collector's office, Custom-house, at 11 A.M., to-day, where the presentation will take place....A discourse will be delivered to-morrow evening by Rev. E.P. ROGERS, D.D., at his church, Fifth-avenue, corner of Twenty-first-street, by request of the Young Men's Christian Association, on "The Relation of Religion to Law and Lawyers," in which special reference will be made to the late Mr. NOYES.....At a meeting of the New-York Teachers' Association, held Saturday evening at the hall of the Board of Education, a plan was submitted for the establishment of a Teacher's Aid Fund, the object of which is to relieve necessitous teachers, and the widows and orphans of teachers. The final consideration of the matter was postponed until the next regular meeting of the association, which will be held in February.....The ice on Central Park Lake and Fifth-avenue Pond was in good condition yesterday, and was crowded by skaters.

snippet: Georgia Campaign and his Humanity; What the Finished Year has Done
lead_paragraph: No year of the war has been so effective against the rebellion as that which closes today. None has brought us so few reverses, so many successes, in our military and naval operations; and in all the other ways none has so decidedly turned the scale in our favor.

abstract: Neutrality and Border Thieves; and Canada Neutrality
snippet: Neutrality and Border Thieves; and Canada Neutrality
lead_paragraph: Simultaneously with the announcement that Judge SMITH, of Montreal, has released one of the rearrested robbers, and given him the chance of appearing as a witness to prove the belligerent character of his Confederates, we have a proclamation of JEFF. DAVIS', declaring the pirates concerned in the attempted capture of the steamer Michigan, on Lake Erie, to be Confederate officers. The coincidence of these judicial and executive proceedings is made specially remarkable by the fact, that the robber discharged by Mr. Justice SMITH offers to swear that the piratical enterprises on the lakes, and the St. Albans robberies were part and parcel of one scheme. The witness further alleges that this scheme was concocted in Chicago, in August last; that its prime object was the release of the prisoners on Johnson's island, and that, failing in accomplishing this object, then a system of plunder was to be instituted similar to that employed at St. Albans.

abstract: Street Sweepers' Strike, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: In its laudable efforts to retrench expenditures and stop leaks from the City Treasury, the Citizens Association of New-York procured from the Legislature at its last session, the appropriation of $300,000, as a limitation of the sum to be used in the work of keeping the streets clean. This amount was generally claimed at the time to be entirely inadequate, on the ground of increased price for labor. Street-sweepers, who received $1 and $1 25 per diem two years since, and were satisfied with their wages, have refused to touch a broom or handle a shovel during the past year for less than $2 per day, and the dirt-cartmen during the same period have obtained so cents a load for removing the sweepings, instead of 25 cents, which was the price from time immemorial before the war. To override this little difficulty of the $300,000 restriction, an arrangement was made on the part of the city authorities with Mr. FRANCIS PALMER, President of the Broadway Bank, to advance sufficient money to pay the laborers and cartmen, on receiving from them an assignment of their claims, coupled with a note for the amount, having attached to it the signatures of the Comptroller and the Mayor -- it being understood that Mr. PALMER should get his funds back by suing the city and obtaining judgments. In this manner about $800,000 or $900,000 have been expended, and judgments against the city to that amount have been placed in Mr. PALMER's hands. At the eleventh hour, however, Mayor GUNTHER has discovered this course to be altogether illegal, and has determined to sign no more requisitions for these claims. He contends that City Inspector BOOLE has no right to employ street-sweepers, and that in appending his signature to any note indorsing their claims, he becomes personally responsible. He is also advised that the judgments obtained by Mr. PALMER against the city for $800,000 odd can be set aside. Therefore, yesterday morning, when a deputation of the street-sweepers waited upon him, to get his official autograph to a note for $108,500 to the Broadway Bank, being the amount of their wages for the past nine weeks, he refused to put his name to it, asserting that his signature should not be written to any such note, "though the ashes were to lie in the streets as high as the second-story windows." Meanwhile, the street-cleaning is entirely suspended, the laborers are in a distressed state for want of their wages, and unless the matter is settled soon, the city is likely to meet the fate of the ancient towns of Herculaneum and Pompeii. It is proper to add that the City Inspector and Comptroller have no conscientious scruples, like the Mayor's, respecting the propriety of placing their names to the note for $108,500 before alluded to; and, indeed, their signatures were already affixed to the rolls before His Honor interposed his objection.

abstract: Dusenberry, Mrs, Poisons her Family, New-York
snippet: Dusenberry, Mrs, Poisons her Family, New-York
lead_paragraph: FAMILY POISONED -- A MOTHER ADMINISTERS RAT POISON TO HER CHILDREN, AND POISONS HERSELF. -- On Thursday night Mrs. ELIZABETH DUSENBERRY, of No. 5 Goerck-street, gave her children a large quantity of PARSONS' rat poison, and, putting them to bed, watched them until near morning, awaiting the result; and then, feeling assured that her children slept the sleep of death, she took a large dose of the poison, and prepared to die. Mr. DUSENBERRY, who is a night watchman, reached his abode in the morning, and went to his couch without suspicion of the tragedy which had been enacted in his house; nor was he awakened until about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, when his son, GEORGE H., aged 4 years, expired. Then the dreadful truth revealed itself to the father, and assistance was at once summoned, intelligence of the poisoning having reached the Thirteenth Precinct Police, Officer LEACH was sent to learn the particulars, and, if necessary, to make arrests; but on entering the house he met the mother, and she freely confessed her crime. He, therefore, took only her into custody, and immediately reported to Sergt. SMITH, at the Police Station. Police Surgeon BLIVIN was sent to attend the children, and he, after making an investigation, expressed the opinion that the children's systems had become fatally impregnated with poison, and that death must ensue within a few hours.

abstract: The remains of Hon. WILLIAM L. DAYTON, late Minister Plenipotentiary of the United States to the Court of France, arrived yesterday by the steamship Lafayetts, from Havre. At 12 o'clock the body was taken from the foot of Barrow-street, North River, where the steamer landed, and without escort was conveyed to the City Hall, where it is now lying in state. The entire arrangements for the reception of the remains and the delivery at the City Hall, were carried into effect by Vice Consul BROOKS and Deputy Surveyor BROWN. To-day, at 1 o'clock. The body will be taken to New-Jersey, under escort of National and State troops, Mayor and city officials and members of the Chamber of Commerce.
lead_paragraph: The remains of Hon. WILLIAM L. DAYTON, late Minister Plenipotentiary of the United States to the Court of France, arrived yesterday by the steamship Lafayetts, from Havre. abstract: the Loss of
lead_paragraph: -- The facts connected with the loss of the transport North America are painful enough, even in their baldest aspect. The loss of one hundred and ninety-four lives, out of a crew and passenger list of two hundred and fifty-nine, is, by its mere magnitude, an appalling disaster. But, when we find in the details of the terrible story that out of the entire number on board the North America, two hundred and three were sick soldiers -- a large majority of them, probably, unable to help themselves in the extreme crisis, we have to leave to imagination to picture the horrors of the catastrophe. The scene becomes yet more heart-sickening, as we read the statement of the chief officer of the ill-fated vessel. We have no doubt that statement presents the main facts of the situation, from the time when the condition of the vessel had begun to be appreciated. But we have seldom perused a record so little satisfactory, as to the actual means employed to prevent the sacrifice of life. We do not wish to go into details. But we ask attention to the fact that, between the time when it was found (22d Dec, 1 P.M.) that water was rapidly gaining in the hold of the vessel, until the last boat left her -- six full hours had elapsed, and that for five of these hours a vessel, perfectly prepared to render relief, was near by.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- "Norma" was given here last evening to one of the finest houses of the season. It brought Mr. MARETZEK's campaign to an end. On Monday, the fine troupe which we have so long enjoyed, will appear in Boston, and elicit the peculiar criticism which attends any effort in that superior place. The performance last evening was thoroughly Satisfactory -- all the artists were in fine voice; the applause was frequent, and the impression left was decidedly favorable to Mr. MARETZEK's return.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- "Norma" was given here last evening to one of the finest houses of the season. It brought Mr. MARETZEK's campaign to an end. abstract: The Gold-room was advanced to 229 yesterday morning, but fell back to 227 per cent. There was an advance in the forenoon in the Government Gold-bearing Stocks of @1 per cent, and in the afternoon a recovery on the Stock of the Erie Railway, ...
lead_paragraph: The Gold-room was advanced to 229 yesterday morning, but fell back to 227 cent. There was an advance in the forenoon in the Government Gold-bearing Stocks of 1/2@1 cent, and in the afternoon a recovery on the Stock of the Erie Railway, the President of which, in a note to the editor of this paper, emphatically contradicts the rumor of the non-payment of the January Dividend. The market for Money steady at 7 cent. to the Brokers.
